description:
Delicious burritos!! How does this place only have three stars on yelp? My coworkers and I were super surprised because we were quite satisfied with the quick and pleasant service, the yummy burritos, and the sauces! They even gave back a credit card that a coworker accidentally left at the counter! How kind of them. 

Tall ceilings that really open up the space, cool murals and decor like a huge guitar, tables all around, sauces and sides in a little salad bar area, busy during lunch (but luckily we passed the lunch rush), and honestly a really good burrito.
author: Katrine U.

description:
Don't go here unless you want to get scammed.

I came here last weekend and the guy at the register told me my card was declined when I tried to pay so my friend paid for me and left them a very generous tip ($4 on $13 nachos). Today I find out that I was charged for these same nachos as was my friend. 

Nachos were below average as well, so if I could give this place negative stars for dishonesty and mediocre food, I would.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Horrible customer service ! I would not return here or suggest it to anyone I know. 

It was my first time here and I had heard great things about their food (food is delicious btw), so I decided to give them a try. I went into the shop and wanted to experience everything about it by eating in. However, even before I could order the workers basically kicked me out because I asked to use the restroom first. I don't know about you all, but when my bladder is full, I can't clearly think straight. So, I wanted to use the restroom and wash my hands so that I'd be good and ready to get a good look at the menu and enjoy the food.

Here's my story: 

They keep the restroom door locked and I asked them for the key or if they could open the door for me. They told me someone was in there and to use the restroom next door (at the coffee shop). I decided to wait and after 7minutes of waiting at the door, I knocked on it. (No one responded). I asked them if they had a spare key because it appeared that no one was in the restroom, the lady told me that they only had one key and that I had to wait. 
By this point, I'm getting ready to pee my pants, so I decided to go next door and use their restroom (customers only- cash only), I would've bought something because I had to pee so bad, but I only had my debit card on me and I wasn't about to waste $3 that I didn't have to pull out $20 for an item worth $2. I went back into the Taqueria and to my surprise, the SAME worker who had told me there was no spare key... was opening the door for an elder lady. I immediately began to cry because I felt discriminated and treated unfairly and at that point I didn't know what to do. 

I wanted to walk away and treat myself to lunch somewhere else, but I had plans to enjoy some great Mexican food, plus I had to pee extremely bad.

The elder lady exited the bathroom and I went in to pee and thought about not giving them my money, but I had just used their customer only bathroom. So, I bought a regular burrito. The price on the menu read $8.70 for a regular burrito , but somehow I ended up paying $11. I didn't even care to ask how that happened, I just wanted to get away from their presence. 

When ordering, I was not asked if I would be eating here or to go.. && I think at this point the lady could tell I was upset. She did ask me if I wanted cheese on my burrito, which I responded with yes ma'am, but THERE WAS NO CHEESE ON MY BURRITO! 

I didn't even get to enjoy the burrito fresh because by the time I got to my car, I had thrown up on the sidewalk and cried for literally 10minutes straight. 

It sucks because I wanted to enjoy their margaritas as well and to try something new that I had seen in a photo, but just that first experience threw everything out of the window. I couldn't even bring myself to ask them what the item was called.

I couldn't give them 1 star because I have to admit, the food speaks for itself... but the workers should learn to respect ALL customers, not just the eldest ones. 

The only thing about the BURRITO was that it was SUPER DRY, they DON'T PUT ANY SOUR CREAM or SALSA or SAUCE on the burrito, but other ingredients were ALRIGHT. I ended up eating half until I was able to make it home to SACRAMENTO and put my own salsa in it.

I hate that I wasn't able to look at their menu and unfortunately I just can't support their business.
author: Lanisha S.

description:
Highly Disappointed.

I was expecting more from the Birthplace of the Mission Burrito. 
The three star reviews seem very justified now.

I ordered the regular carnitas burrito.
When it came to purchasing my order, the guy that made it told the cashier it was chicken.
I said "No, it's carnitas". Everyone was confused. 
Then, she proceeded to charge me for chips, which I didn't even ask for.
I then bit into my burrito, and it turned out it was chicken. Dry, flavorless chicken. I had to put so much salsa on it just to get any type of flavor.

Overrated. 
Never again.
author: Ron Z.

description: The original Mission style burrito everyone in this country is trying to duplicate. I use to come here as a kid and grew up on La Cumbre. The burrito wars are half a block away with Pancho Villa and El Toro going at it for decades on and around the Valencia corridor. A place to pay homage to the Originals.
author: Juan V.

description:
Came here for some late night DRUNCHIES.. totally stealing that from another reviewer.. 

Not sure what others are ordering, but this was one of the best burritos ever! I even had some the following day when I was sober, so it wasn't just the drunchies. 

We had a chicken burrito with everything. I don't like how other places put salsa in their burritos, this taqueria does not. 

My only negative was the nachos were definitely drunchie-ish. Too much nacho cheese, but it was satisfying.
author: Nicole G.

description: Went here January 2016 because it was on man vs food. I was alone on my short trip to SF and always wanted to go here. The burrito was great and the atmosphere was nice. Its like a no frills, hole in the wall place thats good.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
So much amazing Mexican food in the Mission, but I made the rookie mistake of grabbing one of the first ones I saw without scoping the options first. 

Don't get me wrong, the food here wasn't terrible. Nothing to write home about, but passable. Prices were reasonable too. Two deluxe veggie burritos and two (kinda watery) margaritas for just under $20. 

I was less than amused by the customer service though. We both asked for refried beans and reminded the guy behind the counter as he put black beans on. We then got an annoyed look and were basically told one of us was getting black beans. We reminded him again and rather than make a new burrito, he scraped half the black beans off and put refried on top. Um, rude.

It'll do if you just need something cheap, relatively filling, and close to Bart. I def recommend looking for something else though with all the amazing food in the area.
author: Audrey S.

description: Okay. So I'm actually still here processing the food. It wasn't that good. I think it's more of a 2.5 but I'm giving it a 3 for good service. We got the carne asada nachos. It was sooo underwhelming. The meat was cold and it was chewy. The pico de gallo was not flavorful and the overall experience was just bad. I'm so disappointed it wasn't hot! It was lukewarm. It was 12 bucks. There are so many better options nearby. Overall...don't fulfill that nacho craving here. The carne asada could have been a lot better.
author: Natalie M.

description: I could barely eat the super taco because it fell apart in my hands. Definitely not worth the money.
author: Chantel W.

description: Let's be real, you were probably here for some a late night burrito or some carne asada tacos after a night of drinking in the Mission. I walked up to the counter, but some how they ran out of carne asada and al pastor, so I went with the carnitas burrito. It came with rice and the meat, since I requested no beans. I drenched it with their slightly spicy green salsa, which made up for the bland taste of the rest of the burrito. It ultimately does it job as a reasonably priced late night Mexican restaurant that is conveniently located near the bars.
author: Ronald M.

description: I love the artwork on the walls - almost as much as the great food - I tried the carne asada burrito- the meat was tender and tasty. I could have eaten three of them - the location is the heart of the mission what better place for a top of the line authentic Mexican eatery?
author: Louis M.

description: Terrible service but tacos are amazing. Get carnitas or al pastor. They have a toppings bar you can add more guacamole or salsa or limes yourself for free
author: Jessica S.

description:
Fast forward four years later and I find myself looking back at my review/the comment and realized I had not been back in quite some time. 

Suffice to say after many many visits this year the food is better than it was the first time. 

Overall Thoughts

While not my go to burrito spot, it does the job
author: Eddie W.

description:
Wow, what happened to this place. I haven't been here in years, well why would someone come here instead of Pancho Villa right around the corner, but I remember it being decent.

I ordered an Al Pastor super burrito. The tortilla was stale, the pastor was chewy bland and full of gristle, the entire thing was just a bit above room temperature. I expect IT trouble later.

Also this IS NOT the birthplace of the Mission Style Burrito, El Faro at Folsom and 20th is.
author: Manny F.

description:
I've been hanging out at La Cumbre for decades. During my teen years, we would stop here for tacos or burritos before or after wandering what was then a non-hip but oh so cool Mision(there's an accent on that O, son.) Then I developed a monster crush on my fellow Peruvian, Mission native Benjamin Bratt, and he declared La Cumbre one of his spots. As the years have gone on, the Mission has changed but La Cumbre has continued to deliver down-home eats in a no-frills ambiance.  
My bestie and I have been looking forward to a girls night out with margaritas. When we learned a neighboring restaurant was closed for the holidays, we began to look for another option.  Thankfully, La Cumbre does serve margaritas.  We ordered our food and pitcher of strawberry margaritas. I chose the #7 veggie burrito which comes with guac, sour cream, and your choice of salsa and beans and even tortilla for you foo-foo foodies. I asked for spicy salsa and black beans and said not one word about my tortillas de harina. The burrito was tasty and a perfect complement to all those dranks. As for the margaritas, they were fresh and sweet, if slightly too sweet. We added some salt to our glasses and all was right. 
The place was busy in waves and some of the customers need to relax. You're in a taqueria, homey. This isn't Chipotle.  One girl said in a whiny voice, "I'm waiting for my turn. I was next" when I went near the register to grab napkins.  "You're good, hon. Order your food." Pendeja!  Still, La Cumbre has maintained its old school vibe.
author: Julie C.

description:
Came to famous "La Cumbre" looking for some good Mexican Food in SF. And let's just say, I was very disappointed. I remember this place having batter food and service. 

Decor-out dated and in need of repairs. Tables all lopsided and dirty. I like the the theme and layout, but it really could use some TLC. 

Service-ladies didn't seem to know what they were doing. They kept asking each other what was in the burritos we ordered and the cook didn't have answers either. 

Food-I ordered a Cali Burrito and it had nacho cheese it, what! I've never had it like that and threw the flavor off. My family also ordered burritos and they said they were only mediocre at best. 

Price-WAY over priced. 3 burritos and nachos for $51.50! Not worth half that and will not come back again.
author: German R.

description:
This place was on Man Vs Food and is famous for supposedly inventing the Mission burrito.  The food here may be a little pricier than other places, but since it is the first place, it will always attract a crowd based on the publicity.

I am one of those who caved in when visiting San Francisco to try the Adam Richman Burrito (ARB). It is $25 and twice the size of a normal burrito, the thing is about 2 feet long, filled with 2 types of meat and stuffed with rice and beans with other toppings.

Usually with a giant burrito, you lose taste for quantity.  This thing was awesome from first bite to last bite. I realize it is a little steep, I realize that this place is not fancy, but honestly, if you are going to a Mexican joint wanting fancy, you really should have a reality check...
author: Robert G.

description: Honestly this place seemed a little sketchy for food, but my burrito bowl was good (albeit just slightly better than Chipotle)! It's a really hectic ordering experience (they put in the wrong protein for my friend's order) that's kind of like Russian roulette since you don't get a say in how much of the salsa/sour cream/guac etc you get, so if you have precise tastes, don't come here. The carnitas was a good texture, and the rice was a great flavor.
author: Alice Z.

description:
I grew up in SF and went to HS at Mission, so my level of tacos and burritos rating is savage. 

This taqueria was disappointing. When I got there with co-workers, there as only 1 person in front of us and it took forever to get our order. There really is no place on the menu that told me what meat they had, and so I went with the steak. The burrito was sizable, but it was not very good. The steak was overcooked, as they put it in the microwave before putting in the burrito and there is not enough pico di gallo salsa. I only ate half and tried it the following day and it was just un-inspiring.
author: Mei L.

description: A must when in San Francisco! I had the steak Fajita in a burrito. It was delicious!!!
author: Jeannie B.

description: It seems to me that the reviews here and a microcosm of what's happening in the Mission, those who maybe don't get it, moving in and expecting the place to be something it isn't, or something they want it to be. La Cumbre is a hole in the wall burrito joint, nothing more, nor does it seem to be making any effort to try to be more or to market itself as such. There are many higher end, more refined Mexican restaurants all over the city. At a place like this, I expect someone to take my money, make me what I ordered, and that's about it. I saw a couple people whose orders went awry, and that's a bummer, but several of us all came in at once, so they had a bit of a rush and everyone seemed very happy. I had the carne asada burrito and have been back for it twice since. Everyone was very friendly, food was killer, always been very happy, always exceeded my expectations.
author: Josh M.

description:
After seeing this restaurant on TV, decided to give it a shot. The meat alone, it's very delicious. You can tell they marinate their meat. The steak and the chicken. I couldn't really taste the chicken in a burrito, but the steak was very juicy on my taco. The staff was nice enough to recognize that i had not been there before, so they allowed me to try the meats before i bought anything.

Very pricey. The restrooms are clean. Dining area, there were seating available and clean. Salsa bar available and clean. The restaurant can get smoky sometimes due to cooking. I would definitely return here again.
author: Paris S.

description:
Ok, another favorite taqueria. My daughter brought me here, yes the place that originated the mission burrito, and it did NOT disappoint. Really good. I love mole so I had a mole burrito and loved it. It is a taqueria and its busy but they're quick so with just a tiny bit of patience you can get a table. Anyway, it's busy for a reason, and busy with locals. It has a small salsa bar and I tried all of them. They're all really good but very different so I suggest tasting them. Put a small amount in the plastic cup and find what best pairs with your order and don't be afraid of the green salsas. 
None were exorbitantly spicy but two had some kick, which I loved. Anyway give it a try!
author: Mark M.

description:
This place apparently invented the "Mission" burrito (which is what Chipotle makes). We were very excited because of this. I was a bit disappointed, but my friend was not. 

I expected the "super" burrito to be bigger than it was. It's probably only 10-15% larger than a chipotle burrito. That said, it was a quality burrito. The meat was absolutely amazing. The rice was great. The biggest thing lacking was the salsa. They had a decent selection of salsas, but I have extremely high salsa standards, and this didn't meet them. My friend thought it was amazing though. 

My 4 star rating is an average of mine and my friend's. I'd give it a 3, but my friend wants to give it a 5.
author: Andrew S.

description: This place is literally a part of San Francisco history. It's the iconic home of the California style burrito. I'm not sure how one can prove that, but this place is definitely old-school and I've been going here for years. I don't know there's anything about this place that changes my life. But it's a good old fashion standby for a California burrito but never seems to disappoint. If you're in the Mission district and I've never checked it out it should definitely be on your list to try at least once. After all it's part of history.
author: Robert C.

description: Best Mexican Food in the world!!! Grew up on it. Discovered the one in San Mateo initially and loved the food ever since 1993 and blunts.
author: Vincent V.

description: I was tempted to leave a four star review because the kid who took our order screwed up and gave us small drinks (when we paid for the large) in the wrong flavor. But, the food was AMAZING! The carne asada tacos were so good! The seasoning was on point! I'd actually leave a six star rating if I could, because one of the gals who work there more than made up for the kid's screw-up. She treated my daughter (who has a good allergy) like a princess! She served her beans and chicken with her quesadilla, and even gave her a mini-horchata. We've been eating at four-star places on this trip, but none have gone this far to make it a memorable meal. We will be here next time, Lord-willing!
author: Liz G.

description: If you could break food down to feel good and tears this place would be like the movie coco. I literally enjoy every last bit of the vibe from the restaurant and the food is absolutely amazing. I recommend it to anyone who loves burritos. Most certainly will be here everytime I visit San Francisco. Must try
author: Steven W.

description: This spot advertises that it is home of the Mission burrito. I got a regular steak burrito and it came with rice, no beans, and a bunch of pico de gallo. It was an edible burrito and it satisfied any hunger for the rest of the evening. Doesn't take much to make my belly happy and full. Been here right near 16th and Valencia for a long time.
author: Denise C.

description:
This is purely a review based on their super burrito.  

Had one recently filled with carnitas.  My first time here.

It was worthy!

Great taste and a good value too.  It was $10 and did come with chips.

Serve-yourself-salsa bar was decent too.
author: Lewis C.

description: It was delicious or quick bite that we saw on TV I loved it a lot for being famous and for a quick bite you should try it
author: Angelica L.

description: Poor service today. I ordered online. It said 10 minutes. I waited for a few and then walked to pick it up. It was pretty busy. I paid for my food and patiently waited. 20 minutes passed no one said anything. I asked the cashier what was my order status. He seemed confused and walked in circles before finally asking someone. He then informed me that it was now being prepared. Unacceptable!!!! I requested my money back and left. I am very disappointed. Their food is great!!! I was looking forward to it.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Ate here today for the first time since I moved to Mission in 2009, a lot has changed.

I got an asada burrito and two al pastor tacos to split with my friend. The tacos at first seemed a little stale because of the tortilla but figured the burrito would make up for it. Sadly it was the same experience.

I'd to Taco Bell before going here again.
author: Weston S.

description: Asked for regular burrito. Guy made mistake and didnt say anything till the end and was charged for super.
author: Hurui K.

description:
My friend and I each got one super taco ($5 ea) and agreed they were delicious. I'm not sure why this place has a 3 star average because I thought the taco was a delicious- although I cannot speak to the burrito quality. 

The super tacos were packed full of goods and put together nicely. I will say the order of chips I got was a little on the skimpy side,  but I'm sure I could have requested more If I needed some. Pretty clean inside (though the bathroom was out of order) and the staff was friendly. 

While Taqueria Vallarta on 24th/Balmy will continue to be my favorite taco joint, this one hit the spot to keep the sustenance going for a weekend day in the mission.
author: Anna M.

description: I have gone there twice now and I think they have a really good burrito. It's a good amount of food for cheap and the wait time is short. Also guacamole is included without extra charge.
author: Brett J.

description:
The two things that keep me coming back:
1. Petite Super Burrito: Don't mind if I do! I love that I can get a baby super burrito because I never have enough stomach to eat an entire super burrito, but I want all those extra toppings without having to worry about holding my leftovers or keeping them fresh while I bar hop along Valencia!
2. Salsa bar: Endless corn, limes, and that ranch-like-dressing that I get every time but am never sure what it really is. If I'm feeling bold like I wanna try the green salsa and my spice tolerance is up for it, I can do it! All because of the salsa bar. Thank goodness.

I'm not a huge fan of the bathroom key though - I find those to be pretty unsanitary. Luckily I've only ever had to use to the bathroom twice while dining here!
author: Jenny L.

description: Solid burrito that gets the job done when you're in a jam and trying to get to the Roxie to watch some Guillermo del Toro double feature show. Not gonna be the best burrito of your life but if you're hungry and need to feed a beast, a shrimp fajita burrito with extra side of carne asada can practically feed two grown adult as a meal, or go at it alone if your hunger is beast-mode level. I personally find the grilled veggie bits like sweet bell peppers, carrots, and zucchini in the fajita a nice touch actually-a way to get some your vegetable intake too.
author: Taffany H.

description:
Deluxe burrito with pastor meat was good! Flavorful and somewhat on the saltier side.. 

There were pineapples which was a nice kick.  

Portions were good, not too bulky
author: Amy V.

description:
Amazing burrito recommended by Adam Richman from man vs. food!! My husband loved it and the flautas were delicious as well with their green sauce. This is definitely authentic Mexican food!! 

They also sell margaritas and beer!
author: Xiomara S.

description:
Don't fucking advertise until 2:30 then close at 2. 
You dumb fucks. People walk and take Uber's to your location only for it to be closed. Hence why you have shit reviews.
author: Carlos M.

description:
The workers here are slow. Place is dirty. For food I ordered super nachos but substituted the nachos for fries. The entree was presented very well. The taste was just too much and didn't seem authentic. The carne asada pieces were dry and rough. Overall I didn't like the super nachos.

The first time I came here I tried the mission style burrito. Next time I'll just be sticking with the burritos. It's huge and filling, and it tasted pretty bomb!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
My friends and I were looking for Mexican food in the area, and we wanted to give this place a try since one of my friends saw this on Man vs Food and Anthony Boudain apparently visited this place.

Food: I ordered the Grilled Chicken Quesadilla. I felt the flavors were very bland and the portions were small for it's price. There were barely any ingredients and nothing was very special. However, the orange mayo sauce was pretty good as well as most of the other sauces at the sauce station. Chips for nachos are 50 cents.

Service: The lady who took my order had me repeat my order 3 times because she kept forgetting what I wanted to order. It made me confused when she kept asking thinking I had ordered the wrong item. She took my other friend's order as well and she had the same experience for making her repeat her order several times for her to understand what she wanted. However, the cashier was pretty nice and started a conversation as he was charging me. He helped us clear our table as we left as well.

Ambiance: A little runned down but has an authentic Mexican restaurant feel to it.

There are many other Mexican places within walking distance. I don't think I will be back soon since I can find much more flavorful Mexican food nearby.
author: Allie Y.

description:
Food was standard Mexican, service flat-out sucked.

The guy they have assembling the orders doesn't speak any English. At all. Neither did he appear to understand my Spanish. I asked for my usual: rice, refried beans, pico de gallo, and flour tortillas to go. Apparently no one has ever ordered this because it seemed to confuse him greatly. There was an issue with the sizes, then he kept attempting to toast the tortillas when I kept saying I wanted them cold (they congeal into one if heated before being wrapped). 

Then when it came time to pay, I was charged nearly $14! For some miniature sides! And they don't even give free chips. It may have been a mistake, because she lowered the price to $9 (still too much IMO) when I mentioned that the rice and beans were both a small.

There's some interesting decor inside, but on the night I visited, the air was thick with smoke. Perhaps they'd recently burned something, but if this was the case it sure took a while to dissipate. I returned hours later to use their restroom and still couldn't breathe.

The food, once I'd taken it home and reheated it, was pleasant enough. Not outstanding, but there was nothing to complain about.
author: Ellery D.

description: Food was good that is for sure. However they were somewhat rude to anyone not speaking Spanish. Would recommend to an outsider for their original burritos. Good overall but rude
author: Robert S.

description:
My ex told me about this place. He used to frequent it when he was stationed in Oakland in the 90s.  He asked me if it still existed, and it does.  So when I saw it on a recent outing to the Mission, I knew I had to try it.

I ordered a chicken tamale plate.  For $13, it was a bit expensive, but it was a pretty big tamale, which came with a salad, beans, and rice.  The tamale didn't skimp on the chicken, and it was good.  Not "I'm so coming back here" good.  Though if I were to come back, I would get something less expensive.

The people working in the back are friendly and patient.  There's also lots of seating inside.  They do need to fix the bathroom door though.. It kept swinging open (when unused) and I was facing it. I don't like seeing a toilet when I'm eating.
author: Vira P.

description: The carne asada had a nice charbroiled flavor but it was so tough! La Cumbre is not what it used to be.
author: Review L.

description: $5 for a super taco, which includes rice, beans, pico de gallo, watered down guacamole, sour cream and your choice of protein. Unlimited sides such as corn, radish, cilantro, onions, salsa, and lime are offered on the side. I ordered the carne asada and al pastor super taco. The super tacos are served on small normal sized street taco tortilla shells so eating it can be quite messy. DO NOT ORDER THE AL PASTOR!!!! There are huge chunks of pork fat, pure fat (refer to my picture)! I felt my arteries clogging up as I was eating it. It was such a gross feeling. The protein was no where close to flavorful, so you might have to pile on the salsa and lime for it to be tasty. There are plenty other taquerias in the Mission, I would keep looking.
author: Amy T.

description: Came. Didn't eat. Was paying for the food when we saw a cockroach scamper across the counter. We mentioned it to the woman who charged us, asked for a refund & told her we didn't want to eat the food. She then went through how much everything cost instead. Didn't give us a refund. Gross. Bad service. Go somewhere else.
author: Holly A.

description:
La Cumbre bills itself as serving the original mission-style burrito, and in fact they used to. I was a weekly regular during the 80s and 90s when I lived and worked nearby. It was wonderful, the best burrito around. I returned this week for a nostalgic visit. I am saddened to say, it is not the same.

The hallmark of the mission-style burrito is in the steaming of the tortilla first with the cheese steamed into the tortilla before adding the other ingredients so that the cheesiness is the center and surround of the thing. La Cumbre now *grills* the tortilla before beginning preparation, no steaming. This adds a charred grill flavor to every bite that is a noticeable overlay and, for me, takes away from the perfect ingredient bite. Also, because the cheese was added last, it was not melted. 
(Note: mine was the first burrito of the day, so the griller should have been at its cleanest so I can only imagine that this taste gets more pronounced as the grill is used during the day)

No longer a mission-style burrito, and that may be fine for some, but not the original taste and not what I was looking for.
author: Jodi D.

description: Watch what they charge you here before you hang over your card. They overcharged us for two meals, then when questioned their default response is to tell us we each ordered the next expensive meal, then then they didn't understand the question.
author: Nathan M.

description: Well, I opted for one food channel dining option for this trip.  This was featured on "Man vs. Food".  The infamous "Mission Burrito."  Nice medium size place, friendly service and the burrito was good.  Basically everything in it, I opted for beef.  The meat was seasoned and cooked well.  Beautiful wall painting on wood.
author: Sam H.

description: If you are in the mood for a classic San Francisco Mission burrito, this is your spot. The 1967 carne asada burrito is excellent. It comes with steak, beans (I prefer whole black beans), salsa, guacamole and sour cream. There used to be long, long lines in the 1980s but tech hipsters haven't discovered this place yet. Or maybe the prices are too high. That's my only complaint-- it should be $7.50 not $9.50.
author: Scott F.

description: a very unpretentious place to eat good food. Their margaritas are really cheap and quite refreshing! I like their taco salad and I did not try anything else yet.
author: Morgane R.

description:
Came here for some late night drunchies, and all I can say is that I've never been so disappointed in my whole life :(. After reading so much about this place and it's "original mission burritos" i thought they would be good, but i personally found the burrito, the salsa, and most of the experience, very underwhelming.

Nothing particularly horrible about this place, just not a very good mexican place for some pretty high places, located in a neighborhood with a lot of very good mexican places.
author: Andrew T.

description: We went here like so many others because we seen it an episode man vs food. We were looking to get the same burrito he had on the show. The super burrito! It was said to be a 2lb burrito so we were expecting it to be huge. We had planned to share it know we wouldn't be able to finish it. We were sadly disappointed. It was your standard burrito that you'd get at any local or chain restaurant. It was good just not what we were expecting. The service was just okay too. They seemed very standoffish and focused more on closing the place rather than quality customer service
author: Danyielle L.

description:
The carne asada burrito it was great. Very close to the "almighties" you eat south of the border. 
The service it's average, except for the owner of the business who works there and it's very polite, candid and helpful. 
The building it's a landmark constructed 120 years ago. In case you care about history and architecture.
Bottom line, if you are looking for good food and don't care much about service, La Cumbre it's your place. I'm not sure you can find a better burrito on this side of the border.
author: Marcelo B.

description:
What's my #1 thing I order at taqueria's? (if they have them) NACHO FRIES!

I was pleasantly surprised to find out that when I ordered nacho fries with steak, they gave me real thick strips of juicy steak, not the chopped-up, char-black meats at other places. Fries were also topped with sour cream, guacamole, cheese sauce (I prefer shredded cheese though), and pico de gallo. The portion was so big, I needed help from multiple friends.

Boyfriend got his favorite, BBQ chicken burrito. He tells me this place has the best BBQ chicken. 

Downside is that there's only like 5 parking spots, but the San Mateo Bart station is right next door for more parking.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Salty. 

My friends brought over nachos and ended we up tossing it because it was salty. We had a few bites.
author: Angelica C.

description: Worth a visit to add to your culinary history bucket list--the self proclaimed origin of the two fisted, aluminum foil wrapped mission style burrito. No nonsense, hole in the wall in its original gritty state. Beef burrito was ok and its descendants have done much more with flavors, but an inexpensive, tasty way to partake in where it all started.
author: AustinSLin ..

description:
This review is following the tip I left behind when I was here. The reason for the one star review is greatly influenced by their etiquette. A couple of friends and I were in the city for a night out, after having a few drinks we wanted some some good food. This place was open and near by. The place was not packed nor was it empty which made for a quick order. The ordering process is pretty easy, the fishy part is that they have no prices anywhere on the wall no even a menu. I went with my go to, a super asada burrito. Go up to pay, see the dude charge me for the burrito (~9.00) then he tacks on another dollar and don't know what else and the total comes out to be ~$11.50 with no drink, just the burrito. Now I saw this, and questioned it but just paid it because I didn't want to deal with it. My friend who ordered tacos and a drink paid $23 for some average tacos. He too thought he got charged extra for something he didn't want nor received. Now the guys working here vary in age and the younger one working here was polite with us. Unfortunately we got rung up by the older employee who gave off a fishy vibe. There are many reasons why he would have done what he did, maybe he believed everyone going there was too drunk to notice, or maybe he took advantage of the non-Mexican folk (I don't look as Mexican as others). Bottom line is that a business that operates like this would not receive my business any more. For anyone else visiting here late night, ask for a receipt and keep an eye out.

The Food: As I said above, the food was mediocre. The rice was hard and not cooked properly. Not the traditional Mexican orange rice, it lacked flavor. The steak was ok but their cuts of meat made it kind of tough. The portions were good if you're paying the price before getting ripped off. Source: Being raised in a Mexican home serving Mexican food 7 days a week

The Staff: Read above. 1/5

The Restaurant: The place does offer plenty of seating and a salsa bar. 

Am I going back: Heck no!
author: Jesus C.

description:
FOOD:
I got the chicken burrito here and it was so so. For what you pay, you can find bigger burritos elsewhere in the mission. They give you a quarter basket of chips when other places such as coyotes gives you a whole basket. The burrito wasn't bad but nothing memorable. I feel like the place is only known since the man vs food guy came here. But honestly get a burrito from pancho villa or coyotes or la taqueria. 

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? No.
author: Kelley Y.

description: SFs award winning burrito joint never ever disappoints. Juicy but never wet. Flavorful but never overseasoned. Proud yet still humble. Ed and his friendly staff has nailed the perfect burrito. Great place for families and solo diners alike. A bit loud and chilly inside but the 3 kinds of hot sauces will keep you warm. A SF icon that hasn't grown too big for its britches.
author: Ben G.

description: I ordered a super taco last night (carne asada). The tortilla wasn't steamed, the meat was burned.  This is not the first time I've had bad food there.  This place used to be the best, now, unfortunately, it's the worst taqueria in the mission.  Awful.
author: steven r.

description: The.best..burrito.round.great.tate.food.on.valencia.st.and.great.price.all.comeon.in.and.eat.thank
author: Charles W.

description: Best burrito in the Mission and one of the only that stays open after bars close! Will return!
author: Lijah V.

description: I love taqueria la cumbre . Their deluxe burritos are bomb af !!! The meat here has its own delicious flavor , especially the pastor . I've never had pastor like this before . Both locations are delicious and great . I've tried their quesadillas too . MUST CHECK THEM OUT .
author: Kassandra A.

description: This was my second dinner here and both experiences were really great. Great burritos and delicious enchiladas. The margaritas were big and tasty. The staff is very friendly and I like the fun decor on the walls. I noticed they had Man versus Food from the Travel Channel here and I can see why they picked the place. It's a taqueria so it's more casual and pretty fast if you're in a hurry. But it tastes better than most taquerias is I've been to. They have vegan offerings too. This place deserves better reviews; I know what people are thinking.
author: Pachamama J. B.

description: Went after a night of dancing. It was open and close to the club...The food is served from "hot" plates. We had steak burrito and nachos. The steak burrito was bland and monotonous. Just kind of a bland mush. The nachos were luke warm (the meat and cheese). The nachos were better than the burrito but niether was good. I think if i were drunk like many of the patrons I would have found it delicious. However,  I will not be returned to find out.
author: Ameshia A.

description: We came here with a friend while wandering around the Mission on New Year's Day. My carne asada super burrito was pretty tasty (and had a lot more flavor in my opinion than the carnitas super burrito Ashley R. got, but it still wasn't earth-shatteringly amazing, and definitely not more than $9 good. I added on a 50 cent order of tortilla chips (also just OK) and my after tax total came to $11.91, which to me seems like WAY too much money for a burrito and a tiny handful of chips in the Mission, especially when great burrito spots abound, many of them offering super burritos for less money.
author: Nick Z.

description: I was kinda scared trying this place because it was kinda empty after watching it on man vs food. But the food tasted delicious and the crowd was always coming in gradually. It is like a real Mexican chipotle style burrito making place. They grill the meat on order when you get your burrito and put what you want and don't want in it.  Also also melt the cheese quesadilla style before they make your burrito. I will definitely come back and the workers were friendly. My only complaint is the parking is horrible since it's in the club and bar area and I wish they gave more sour cream in the burrito
author: David M.

description:
Had the weirdest interaction at La Cumbre the other day. We're there New Year's eve night, about 9 PM. The owner is there, and my friend's credit card is taking a little while to process. The owner says something akin to "See? Taking a long time to process credit card, our new president doing a good job...Visa can't handle all the orders!" We both look at him a little baffled, and ask for clarification. He replies that Trump is so good for the economy that people are just going crazy making purchases, and Visa can't keep up. 

Wish I was kidding. We asked him if he was kidding, and he just looked at us dumbfounded--didn't we agree? Hmm...no, my friend, I don't think someone who has even started their job is responsible for a slow credit card transaction. OK, so politics aside, I don't care what people believe, but the reasoning was just so idiotic as to be funny enough for a yelp review. 

Secondarily, I'll say that the quality of this place has just plummeted. It used to be one of my staples, since I have been here in the Mission for about 10 years now. My girlfriend had stomach issues after our trip there a month or so ago, and swore it off. My stomach is made of iron, and I can eat street food in most developing countries without problems, so for me, a good burrito is about ingredients and flavor combos. At best, La Cumbre is mediocre on both, and often the $10 burritos are 90% rice or soggy with their highly watered down sauces. 

There's far better burrito options in the city, especially in the Mission. If La Cumbre is going to be absurd enough to claim to be the "birthplace of the mission burrito" (which is painted brightly on its facade sometime recently), it better be good, and, well, it's just not. 

On the upside, the people that work there are usually very friendly.
author: Scott C.

description: This is a nice place for lunch. The place is clean, cheap and quick. I ordered the veggie burrito. The burrito was nice made, not skinny tiny burrito. It tasted good, quantity was good. If i'm in the area, I will visit this place again.
author: Gagandeep S.

description:
This place is nothing special. 
Will not return. 

- Place looks grimy dirty
- Restroom was out OOO (Out of Order)
- The cashier barely spoke any English
- Tables were sticky 
- Flies in the food/kitchen area 
- Refried Beans tasted like a churro, very sweet
- Asada was fatty and rubbery 
- Caritas tasted boiled and not hot
- Orange Fanta was out of service that I asked for
- serves black beans with bean juice (needs a strainer for the beans) on top of hubby's nachos and got bean juice all over the bottom of his nachos. 
- Didn't have crunchy tacos like I was hoping for. 
+ Food was fast 
+ Salsa bar, if you BUY chips
+ Food presentation looks nice
+ Guacamole was perfect
+ inexpensive 

Overall it was nothing great, we went here because Man VS. FOOD Adam Richman went there.
author: Cali Girl M.

description: I've been coming here since I was 5. This place is the best. Every bite exceeds my expectations with delicious flavor.
author: Gabe Y.

description: I ordered the Mission Style Burrito with everything: cilantro, onions, mild salsa, rice, carne asada, and cheese. Best burrito I've ever had - hands down. Definitely what you want to eat at 1am on Saturday night :D
author: Jack F.

description:
That was not a good vegetarian burrito. At all. I asked for a vegetarian burrito but did not specify between the regular, deluxe or super. I assumed by saying 'vegetarian' I would get a regular. When the burrito arrived with lettuce it was a bit of a disappointment. The lettuce wasn't even crisp. What the burrito lacked most was flavor. 

Since I was with friends I ordered a separate asada burrito for my fiancé which I hoped would have more taste. It did not. His look of disappointment and dismay, that I had strayed to some other taqueria different from our usual better places was enough for me to acknowledge that I would probably never return to Taqueria la Crumbre again. The chips are not made in house. Well, I don't know that for a fact, but they certainly were not fresh tortilla chips. At least, the tomatillo salsa was good.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Actually the worst place to eat if you have a dairy allergy, possibley ever. After ordering 2 all veggie burritos, both came with cheese, which i caught as the girl made then and as i said " no cheese no cheese" she takes half of it off and leaves it, then the older cook lady says it wasnt cheese, only lettuce. I open them and both are cheesey. i take one back as i discovered one before the other, and they remake one, and after i tell them the second one was cheesy, the lady gave me the worst attitude and treated me like a child and went to the register and gave me $7 for the $7.50 burrito i ordered, and told me that was that, as if i was being too dofficult for asking for a vegan burrito.
So if youd like to avoid dying of a dairy allergy,  go else where, or even if you want good serive, go elsewhere. LITERALLY ANYWHERE ELSE.
author: Max F.

description:
Awesome spot to have some of the best mexican food in town, the place looks like your tipical hole in the wall restaurant, which is great, because this place is all about the food.

I ordered a Mission Style Burrito, which was pretty good and tasty, a little bit more expensive than some other taquerias around the city but overall it was pretty inexpensive, the good thing about Taqueria La Cumbre is that they have a salsa bar and you can pick up as many salsas as you want, you can also ask anytime for another basket of chips, which were actually pretty good.

If you are in the area you should definitely come and have a bite at this pretty cool place.
author: Tomás S.

description: My hubby enjoyed his Super Burrito, and if I were ranking the veggies and refried beans I had on their own this would be much higher...but the star of my dish was supposed to be the steak in my steak fajitas, and it was SO hard to chew or cut with a knife I gave up.  Disappointed.
author: Keri M.

description: I tried to place an order via phone to save time, and I was informed they don't take phone orders. What does that even mean?
author: Fabian M.

description: Great quesadillas - well worth the trip from bart coming home from Oakland. Foods about as good in the afternoon as it is at 2am
author: Maxwell C.

description: Had the veggie burrito. Reminded me of my childhood and ordering $.99 burritos at Taco Bell. Pretty bad. Considering it's in the heart of the Mission, you can find better.
author: Cass C.

description: This place is absolutely amazing. My friend Kellen and I came in today for a couple burritos and were literally treated like Kings. The owner offered to switch the channel to a game while we had Margaritas. The burritos were fantastic and the tomatillo sauce was just incredible! Service was quick and really welcoming. I definitely recommend this place to anyone!
author: John O.

description: Probably one of the worst taco shops I've visited. Bland tacos -- dry carne asada loaded with rice, beans, & veggies. Two tacos were enough to fill me up but in my book it's waste stomach real estate, ugh! It's not a cheap taco shop either. What really brought it down from a potential 2 stars review to 1 star is that my friend saw a roach. Unfortunately, after a night of drinking and not very many food options still open nearby, we ate & left. Even after some drinks the food is not good?! That must say something.
author: Ruby C.

description:
Lalala this place is rad...if you are craving tongue tacos, this is 
the spot.
author: Melody R.

description:
This is "cheap" Mexican food that really isn't all that cheap. Their burrito is a dollar more than Pancho Villa Taqueria and definitely smaller in size. They also charged $2.25 for a can of Arizona ice tea that clearly says 99 cents on the side. The owner was defensive when I brought this up, not a very friendly response. Also the chips aren't free with your meal (isn't there a California law that guarantees this right?). 

All and all, I can see why this place is mostly empty when I walk by. Compared to other places, their food quality doesn't make up for the high prices. Bummer because I liked the inside of the restaurant and the staff was friendly, and I always like to root for the underdog.
author: Paul W.

description:
I love the salsa stand on the side where it's self serve. 

Foods good. Huge open space. At night there's a band that plays out front. Food is made fresh. People are nice. Seriously one of the better burrito places to get food at in the mission. I've never had to deal with waiting in long lines here but the price is awesome for the size food u order. A must have when you're in the city
author: Linda L.

description: Love the fact they make mini burritos!!! Perfect for a light dinner. Chicken was very tasty, but I wish they added a bit more protein to the mini burrito.
author: Aj C.

description: Very very good foods.  Self service.  I asked for more chips and ready to pay for it, he said don't worry about it.  All their meats are seasoned and perfectly grilled to perfection.  There's a lot of other competitions  around.  I'm into food porn.  But let me tell you one thing, these people can cook!  Once you have eaten here, you will never go to Chipotle again.
author: Mike W.

description:
Made order. Got to cashier. Order had disappeared, go to back of the line.

Also, lack of veggies makes for a disappointing burrito.
author: Shridhar G.

description: Pricey for a mediocre place. Gets fairly crowded at night when the bars close, but at least there's a lot of seating.
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
This place is okay. Nothing too exciting about their menu or the flavors. The burritos are okay.
Their grilled chicken was very far from having the grilled flavor, and more wet than any other grilled chicken I have had.
It's not a bad burrito, but the flavor just blends In and is subtle.
author: Jad A.

description: How sad! The once best taqueria/burrito joint in SF has taken a culinary corkscrew into oblivion. Many moons ago, my fellow SF'ans and I would flock here before a music event, after climbing in Glen Park or that sheer wall in Corona Heights, or even for a late-night bite. The tongue burrito I had was by far the most flavorless dish I ever had. Sad. Perhaps they been sold off too many times. Perhaps. R.I.P.
author: Kevin F.

description: Charged me and my 2 friends extra for the wrong order. When i realized what happened they wouldnt make the correct order or refund us for the food we never got. Awful customer service, so bad i actually took time out of my day to write a yelp review.
author: Aïdan S.

description:
Okay so my first time here.. By looking at my fellow yelpers review.. Didn't get my hope high.. 
But once we order.. N got all the salsa n peppers n onions n stuff..!! 
I order the meat combo burrito $8.00+... Reg size was pretty yummy.. Very small portion of chips.. But hey I used that paper dish to get all my salsa and guacamole and corn..!!! Great great great.. Will come again!!
author: Crisy G.

description: We visited San Francisco from Houston, a city plenty familiar with Mexi food. This place was well worth our walk exploring the city. It offers burritos and tacos,  rice and beans, and meats including carne asada, carnitas, and even puerco en salsa verde. It was delicious and authentically Mexican.
author: Anahi G.

description:
Yeah it Was Amazing! way back in '82 ....COULD BE FIXED EASY!   I KNOW what went wrong.. in EARLY '80S it was THE only PLACE for a hotly grilled steak burrito!!!!.
.Dripping with flavor!. .They TOTALLY BLEW IT ABOUT '83?  ..La Cumbre was the Hot Spot.. BUT, due to lack of product inspection ....THAT is When the FAME ENDED!!  They had the ENDLESS line of us people for Freshly grilled Steak Burritos...always about 25 feet long!!!

Why? Rapidly Grilled skirt steak burritos with beans and Salsa.......Very Juicy meat, chewable and FRESHLY dripping Steak in Small Burrito. $2 then..we bought 2.

 I sensed the grillers wanted a RAISE!  Started making Big Chunky CHOPS not Chewable! Everyone left. Owners never sent in taste testers so THEY thought EL TORO was drawing customers away.. LIE.
 El TORO just opened down the street and the dummies who owned it assumed everybody wanted RICE and all this other crap and THAT is WHY the LINES DIED! NO.. THEY STOPPED CHOPPING STEAK FINE ENOUGH TO EAT ...CHUNKY AND CHEWIE.. UGH....Spit it out! 

 LAZY! SLOPPY original Dad probably left it to a relative and never bought a product when lines died.

Like El Faro ... no more Juicy wet burritos we all loved in lines,  because someone got wet biting it. 

Family SOMA, Mission, Noe Valley since 1887, I know Mexican Food .: The Great Bob Johnson and Johnson's Tamale Grotto ...First Mexican Restaurant in SF 1906.. My Dad's best friend and blindfold Chess mate. So I KNOW MEXICAN .. My GRANDMA was a cook: Clara Sanchez from HORNITOS.. Spanish Land Grant Sanchez'
author: Leifur M.

description:
Turning back the clock, I use to work nearby and we would make La Cumbre one of our lunch time stops.  Now years later, eating at La Cumbre seems like a distant memory.  But recently I was going to be in area to have my car serviced, I had La Cumbre in my plans for lunch.

Walking into the restaurant, the ambiance and set-up was how I had remembered it.  You wait in line at the counter, place your order and then watch your burrito get prepared. Pay and grab a seat at one of the tables and enjoy your burrito. 

This visit, I had a regular grilled chicken burrito with black beans. Your burrito comes with a quarter basket of chips and your choice of salsa at the salsa station. The burrito was tightly wrapped and the chicken was tender and flavorful.  It's a good burrito, but since my last visit, I've had better burritos.
author: Al L.

description: Disappointed  $ 12 dollar burritos... nope not coming back I did not even get chips or a drink. I get that it's San Francisco but you can get the same thing down the street for a lot less.
author: Hazel H.

description:
Stopped in at La Cumbre for the first time in ten or fifteen years (since I stopped working in the area), and was very disappointed in the quality of what my wife and I were served- nothing like what I remember. Her chile Colorado was fatty and tough, the rice undercooked and the sauce- well, uninteresting is the best I can say about it. She left most of it on the plate; no point in even bringing it home. My shrimp burrito was mostly rice and beans, with some cooked vegetables and far too few, very small, shrimp that didn't really taste like anything. 
Not sure whats happened to the place. Used to be my fave, back when the Mission was the Mission, but if yesterday was typical, it's gone 'way downhill, maybe skating in its reputation. Very sorry to see it. There are lots of taquerias in the nabe. Next time I'll try another.
author: John B.

description:
I got the super nachos with beef. The total came to 11.42. I was a little surprised to pay that amount for nachos but expected something fantastic.    The nachos came out with processed cheese and fluffy guacamole. The cheese tasted like taco bell cheese or cheese whiz.  The guacamole had some kind of filler in it and tasted "light". 
The best part of the dish was the beef - but they charge you an extra dollar for beef.
author: Cin D.

description:
I'm not quite sure what brought me to La Cumbre after the Carnaval parade. I remember coming here eons ago when it was featured on man vs food and not thinking all that much of it, but for some reason it felt like I had to pay them another visit since I was in the mission. Ahh I hope I remember how mediocre it was next time I'm here.

The girl taking our order was so rude. She had a hard time understanding us and would stare at us slack jawed when we ordered. She looked pretty annoyed with us, actually. When we paid we saw that we could get a small boat of chips for $.50 so I ordered two. Those were the nastiest chips ever, they were so stale... I was pretty over this place by then.

The food was just okay, nothing stood out to us and that says a lot because we were pretty hungry. I ordered the garlic shrimp and steak burrito but I'm pretty sure the girl could care less what kind of shrimp I wanted, so I ended up with a regular shrimp and steak burrito. It was average. Not bad by any means but definitely not a anything special. 

I don't plan on coming back here. If the food was phenomenal, I might get past all the rest but unfortunately that's just not the case. Bye Felicia.
author: Cristina P.

description:
This place is pretty good. Some would argue that it's overpriced, but many burrito joints in the Mission are. And this is coming from somebody who lived in San Diego, knows burritos, and used to get fish burritos for 4 bucks. I will just say this now. I got the steak burrito, or carne asada as it is better known. This burrito probably had the most meat I've ever eaten in a burrito. To say that they are overpriced is not fair, because they put a lot of meat in them.. I've been to a few places who charge maybe a dollar less but there is substantially less meat. Overall it's not the best burrito I've had, but the quality of the carne asada is very good. Big chunks of meat as if cut from a grilled steak.  I've had burritos where the carne asada looked like ground beef. 

I can't comment on the facilities, as I ordered mine on Eat24 to go. Gentlemen who gave me my order was nice, and spoke perfect english. Don't let the ratings fool you. Give this place a try for yourself.
author: Shock S.

description:
La Cumbre supposedly has "the original Mission burrito." I thought El Faro had the original Mission burrito, but whatever.

The shop itself has a heavier emphasis on fajitas and fish, but I decided to go for the carne asada burrito. It was decent, but it wasn't anything too fancy - I could have easily gotten something bigger/meatier/fresher at a dozen other shops in the area.
author: Casey S.

description:
It's SF Review week, and I want to share some places I visited on my latest trip to No CA.  TLC is on Valencia and 16th in The Mission.  I came here w/ my crew after closing down Elbo Room up the street.  This was after checking out Casanova (passed - no sightseeing), a drink at Blondies (boring) and GFU (no translation necessary) at Elbo Room.  

I wanted a caldo, but the only soup available was the menudo.  The menudo was very good.  The broth was skimmed of any fat, there was plenty of tripe, the hominy was nice and fresh, and I was also given a big bone w/ plenty of meat on it.  Additionally, I was given 6 piping hot corn tortillas to dip in the soup, or make tacos de tripas:  4 Stars.

The service was very good.  The food came out quickly.  In addition, the server who took my order helped me carry my other plate w/ rice, onions and oregano to the table:  4 Stars.  The ambiance was OK.  This is a production line kinda place. You can see them preparing your food as the line moves from the back of the place to the front where the salsa bar is:  3 Stars.

La Cumbre means The Summit.  I wouldn't say that this place is the "peak" of late night Mex places I have been to.  However, the food is hearty, the service is good and the ambiance is OK.  An added plus is its walking distance from Elbo Room!!!
author: Joe P.

description: There is a lot of hype about this place so I decided to try it out. Carne asada burrito was decent but not up to par to some other places around the area. Service was lackluster. It was nice going for historical reasons, but not sure I'd go again.
author: Ismael T.

description:
Just finished eating here. My fiancée had a vegetarian burrito and I had a chicken burrito with cheese. The food was delicious. The man preparing my burrito melted the cheese onto the tortilla before piling high my ingredients. The salsa bar was a great addition to my lunch where I added some cilantro and onions. The burrito was quite large and worth the price. The only downside was that chips were .50, but hey that's still cheaper at some other places. 

Some folks complained on Yelp that it looks dirty. This is a typical hole in wall joint. I personally loved it's ambiance and the workers were super friendly. I will definitely return here in the future!
author: Ally F.

description: wish I could give 5 stars but have to give 4 stars because it just doesn't feel like it is a clean restaurant when you walk in and not being able to speak Spanish makes you feel a little intimidated but with all that said and even the icky feel of the building the star is still the food my burrito was one of the biggest and baddest (really good!!!!) I have ever tried carne asada, cheese, lettuce, sour cream and more cheese (hey I don't eat beans, guac or salsa) what can I say except DELICIOUSNESS in every bite.  My wife had a super taco and said it was really tasty with guac salsa and some really great carne asada said it was great also.  Hey even our margarita was authentic here.  We even saw what Adam Richman had when he was here as somebody ordered it.  Wish we had more people with us so we could have had more food it was that GOOD!!!!!!  Parking will be an issue in this part of the mission so u better off to UBER here.
author: Tim R.

description:
What a shame that its mention on the Travel Channel's Man Vs. Food program didn't yield more cred for its tasty burritos. In fact, a cursory look at several of the Yelp reviews speak to being disappointed at the quality based on the overtly unctuous claims the constantly smirky Adam Richman was making on that show. First of all, I think looking at Richman as a culinary taste-maker is a likely mistake since he looks like he would eat anything without much discretion. Now if Anthony Bourdain said their burritos were great, well... 

Second, the $6.25 Super Vegetarian Burrito I had the other night was really good - full of fresh guacamole, shredded cheese, black beans, rice and a bounty of grilled vegetables (see photo). I also noticed how the staff worked extra hard in accommodating orders. I was there with five out-of-town colleagues who were looking for a typical "San Francisco dive experience". They actually waited on us like it was a regular restaurant, which I thought was above & beyond the service we would have received at similar-level Mission taquerias.

Cancun, El Farolito or Pancho Villa would simply expect you to pick it up yourself. Now I'm more motivated to return and try the $6.75 Vegetarian Taco Salad or the $5.75 Rice Bowl accompanied by one of their $3.75 "Fruit Sensations". The chips and salsa we shared were probably a bit more standard-tasting, but frankly my humongous burrito was so filling that I barely noticed with my bottle of Corona (or two). It was about 6:30PM on a weeknight, so it wasn't crowded. I'm not sure when the punch-drunk clubbers and aromatic hipsters start to show up in droves.

FOOD - 4 stars...a stellar veggie burrito as far as I'm concerned
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...roomy but in need of more comfortable stools
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...table service? wow...
TOTAL - 4 stars...in the battle between Ed U. Vs. Food...Ed won (...sorta)!
author: Ed U.

description: yuck! i ordered garlic prawn burrito but instead tasted chewy meat. rice, re fried beans and whatever ingredients there were all got meshed up.  will never come here again.  first time, last time. puke
author: Paulette T.

description:
I mean... you can't go wrong with burritos. 

Super burrito w/ Lengua (-beans): 8/10. Like I said, burritos are burritos, delicious no matter what.

The horchata and sauces are what saved the day. Corn is a great addition! Keeps your mouth from melting off your face.
author: Gary W.

description: Nothing spectacular but pretty good. Had the carnitas deluxe burrito. I judge most Mexican restaurants by their retried beans. These were just ok. A little bland. Carnitas were very tender and juicy. Not crispy or greasy. Good distribution of items too.
author: Danielle H.

description: I wanted to have a mission style burrito, so we went to the original. Loved it. The carne asade was great.  A little pricey but everything in San Fran is.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Very disappointed. 

I used to come here in the 80's as a child and continued through my high school years. This place had a special place in my heart as it was the first taqueria I had ever been to. I loved the smell of the carne  asada being grilled and the hustle and bustle of the large crowds waiting to order.

Present day? The place was empty. There was no aroma of fresh carne asada being cooked. I still decided to order, big mistake. First the lady making my burrito removes some foil over some precooked carne asada. From what I noticed it was the last of their leftovers from the previous night because, there were no other customers inside the restaurant and it was barely enough to spread to the mid point of the tortilla. 

I paid and began to unwrap the foil from my burrito hoping by some magical power the burrito would be as good as I had during my childhood. Unfortunately, no such luck. I would say my burrito was 90% refried beans and rice. I got to the about half way through my burrito and there was no more meat. Just tortilla and little pieces of rice and beans.

I left disappointed but, since I'm lucky enough to live in the City there are plenty of other options when it comes to burritos! I hope at some point they get back to what made them a local favorite.
author: Mario O.

description: We recently ordered a large quantity of food from here and I must say it was a pleasant experience. The owner Ed was  nice and very cooperative. It was for a celebration of life and we needed to feed 40 to 50 people. He did a great job. The food was great and they ate it all. I would definitely order again.
author: kathy w.

description: Food has went down hill, aggressive verbally abusive street musicians drugged out in front ready to harass you while you try to get a nasty burrito. Sad because I had a lot of fond memories here when I was a teenager, used to be one of the best now one of the worst. Also has live shitty music without permit all night to 6:30am.
author: Gracie A.

description: First visit here and had to try the #1 Super Burrito.  Service was good and explained the various menu items.
author: Dan M.

description:
CARNE ASADA IS A RIP-OFF! 

Ugh. I hate wasting mah moneys, even like $1 or $2 of rip-off causes me pain. 

I got a stupid yet delicious Deluxe Burrito, on the menu for $8.75. When I got to the register, I got charged over $11. (literally like double the price of a veggie burrito. absolutely ridiculous, who are you La Cumbre). 

Apparently they have some new stupid policy for a $2 extra for steak. I got my burrito with Carne Asada, so I fell victim to this! 

It's not helpful to have these random signs on the cash register and like one on the clear glass that separates the food from the person order. These signs are the ones that "notified" us - jk they're rude pieces of paper that you usually ignore because they're alongside the other signs that show various "specials" and new things not on the regular menu. 

Anyway, their menu is electronic and on the monitor - would it be so hard to have just updated your damn prices on there instead of misleading the customers with a lower price on there + relying on the customers to, in addition, read the paper signs? 

People go here drunk so we need you to make things simple for us! k thanks!
author: Monica B.

description: I have never been so disappointed. I love burritos and was so excited to try this place especially after seeing it on man vs food, but it was totally not worth the headache of finding parking. Everything was so flavorless and pretty pricey. For two burritos and a handful of stale chips it was $35. I couldn't even finish it so I gave it to a homeless person who I'm sure enjoyed it more than I did. Save your money.
author: Jessica P.

description: Does the job and hits the spot.  Not amazing or terrible.
author: Amy J.

description: Original mission style burrito spot. Just okay. I much prefer chihuahua. I got the vegatarian mini burrito. The place didn't look so clean so I was worried about ordering meat right before an early morning flight home the next day. Burrito was pretty bland and basic. The salsas weren't bad though. Next time I will try a different place or go back to chihuahua.
author: Laura W.

description: This is a great, casual restaurant with solid food and friendly staff. If you're in the mood to try something different, order the prawn fajita burrito.  It's delicious and the prawns practically pop in your mouth.
author: Rebecca L.

description: My father took me here when I was a kid and always loved the place.I used to recommend this place as the best burrito in town but sadly report that this was one of the worst burrito I have eaten. My partner and I took a bite of our burritos and it was really bland and I had to drench it with sauce. The meat was cold and no flavor. Que Paso raza I am really disappointed and feel cheated. They seem they forgot to cook. Some many choices in San Francisco sorry me no come again!
author: Alberto G.

description:
Great spot to get casual Mexican food. Nothing fancy but good food :)
I haven't tried anything here I didn't like, carne asada is great and the burrito sizes are good, I recommend the deluxe, it's just enough. If you are feeling like a beast then go super! Chips come with every order and the margaritas are only 4.50 :-)
author: Cavendish C.

description: Yesssss.  Maybe it's that I only come here when I'm tipsy (or worse) but this place hits the spot.  Go for the super burrito and then load up on the house salsas.
author: Jonathan S.

description: The atmosphere in this place is everything I want in a taqueria, which I loved. I am a transplant from South Texas, and this was my long-awaited introduction to Mission Style burritos. My burrito, a Supreme Meat monster on a spinach tortilla stuffed with delicious and flavorful carnitas, was so tasty--UNTIL I bit down on a large bone. My friend and I laughed it off, him joking that I must be really lucky because he'd been to several taquerias and never gotten a bone, and me mentioning that this is what I get for moving away from my pseudo-vegetarian dietary choices and eating meat again. The burrito was so good I was willing to keep eating it despite the bone. Generally not one to hold negative feelings towards bones, I persevered! Surely another bone couldn't possibly be in my meal! Alas, two bites later, I found another, larger bone. Strangely saddened, I retired my unfinished burrito, leaving it sadly abandoned in its red, plastic basket. Fear not, dear Reader, I soothed my sorrows with my friend's horchata and my refreshing Mexican Coke. Three stars over all, one lost with each bone.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
We love watching Man vs. Food on the Travel channel and this was one of the spots recommended by Adam Richman.  We all got the super burrito, which comes with everything on it.  From the burrito stand point it was very good.  The staff was friendly and patient as we made our way through the ordering process.  I washed it down with a Corona despite it being 11:30am, but hey, it's the weekend and who cares?!?  Nothing complements a burrito better than a cold Corona!

Overall the burritos were good and it was nice taking in the history of the first "Mission Style" burrito.
author: Brian S.

description: I seen this place on man vs food, and I thought the super burrito was going to be huge, but it was small. I have had a way bigger burrito with more flavor at "la charrita" in fairfield ca. This place was over priced and the chips we're stale. Would I come back here? No! It was hard to get a parking spot here, then after finally finding one, I got this rinky ol' small  burrito; it made it totally not worth the drive or the pay. The super burrito is $9.25 and smaller than a grilled stuff burito from TacoBell. Ugh.
author: Jose F.

description: The food is pretty bomb! Nice selection of salsa's from the salsa bar. I ordered a steak deluxe burrito with salsa on the side (so it doesn't make the burrito soggy). All the ingredients complimented each other well. Sometimes when I order burritos from other places the rice tastes bland or the beans smell funky. The cashier (a younger lady) was very nice and friendly but the older ladies asking you what you would like to order weren't so friendly.
author: Cindy C.

description:
What happened here? I've been coming here for over 20 years (and even sometimes went to the San Mateo location), but everything has been going bad over the last few years. Tonight was the last time I will visit, unless something changes.

The burritos used to be the best around, and now they are just kind of bland. Combine that with the decline in friendly service, and they have problems. The nail in the coffin comes with their pricing. They are the most expensive burrito around, and definitely not the best any more. Tonight, they charged $10.50 +tax for a burrito (that was bland) and it doesn't even include chips!

The only reason I am giving them 2 stars is because this place used to be great, and has the potential to be again. Advice to management: bring prices back down to appropriate taqueria levels, hire the nice ladies back, and add some spices to your food. Plus, stop adding random things (like falafel) to your menu, and perfect the traditional burritos that used to be so good. Your outrageous prices and decline in flavor and service are the reasons that this place is not as full as it used to be.

I am sad to say I don't think La Cumbre will be around much longer - unless they address these issues. La Cumbre, are you listening??
author: S H.

description:
La Cumbre may have been featured on T.V.  some time ago but their fame is no thanks to their customer service and quality in the taste of the food. 

Today my co-worker and I went with all of the office interns to have lunch at La Cumbre. We both ordered a prawn burrito. They mixed up the burrito orders and they didn't get the orders right. 

Because we were the last served, and to not miss out on eating together, we asked for a partial refund of one burrito. The female employee said she couldn't do refunds. So she offered to make them over again. We were okay with that but she demanded that we give back the burritos that were already bitten into. We didn't see why we should give them back. They're going to go into the trash anyway, right??? 

We asked that they at least offer them outside to countless folks who don't have to eat around the Mission. She refused. 

So she took the burritos and then we waited another 10 minutes for our prawn burritos. 

I suspect they use the same contents to remake the burritos. Otherwise why would they be so insistent on taking back the burritos? They obviously didn't take Customer Service 101. 

My prawn burrito was mediocre. 

The only star they get is because I had their roasted salsa while I waited and it's good. 

I will never return. I will make sure our interns don't either. #byefelicia
author: Judith G.

description: Must have new cooks since man vs food...portion was small order was wrong...asked for hard shell tacos got pre made shells...no flavor in black beans...I will not go back..have eaten at least at 8  man vs food restaurants. ..with out regrets..until now...worse ever
author: Chris E.

description: Where's the beef!?! Ordered a super chicken burrito and there was about 8 small pieces of chicken in there. For $10.33 that shouldn't happen. The ingredients are all good but when they screw out of the main protein, that's just being cheap and I won't be back. Better deals on Mission. This supposed to the the best but I can say that it is.
author: Jim M.

description: Been enjoying Steak Burritos here for 36 years. Its a great burrito with more than a pound of food.  You never miss these places until a Thursday night rolls around  and your 3500 miles a way. Taco what?
author: Jim M.

description: A disappointing pilgrimage to an old favorite. Bitchy service, dirty tables and the carne asada burrito was bland, rubbery and so so so sad. Shoulda gone to the Pupsaria around the corner
author: Sarah M.

description:
Ive been wanting to come here since I heard the skatemaster tate song "la cumbre" on bones brigade video 4 public domain back in '92.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-DqHUD0EG0M&feature=youtube_gdata_player
The food is good. The price is fair. They grill the meats and chop them up right in front of you for your order. Eddie van halen likes the place too...

Edward D. From la cumbre sent me a couple gift certificates for repping la cumbre on my tattoo. Ill be swinging through SF end of may for steak burritos!  Thanks eddie!
author: Brian W.

description:
1. Summary:
Great burrito, great value for money
(Points: 8/10)

2. Food:  
Had the mini veggie burrito, and the mini grilled chicken burrito.
What I liked about the mini burrito was that in a single bite, you got a combined taste of all the ingredients, as opposed to just rice or beans, which can be quite bland.
Salsas were flavorful. Chicken was tasty and well grilled.
Want to try the fajitas+falafel burrito next time.
(Points 8/10)

3. Ambience :
Very bare-bones - go here only if you care about food.
But there was a guy playing live music, which was pretty good!
(Points 6/10)

4. Price: 
Very reasonable
(Points: 9/10)

5. Variety:
They had a good mix of vegetarian and non vegetarian burritos.
(Points: 7/10)

6. Service:
The cashier was the bottleneck, but the actual burritos were being prepared quite fast.
(Points: 6/10)

7. Value for money: 9/10

8. Wishlist: 
-

***Note - I personally care about food the most and hence my overall rating is more biased towards food and less towards other factors like ambience, price, service, etc.
My taste buds are more used to Indian flavors, so I'm not able to always appreciate foreign flavors, although I love expanding my horizons and trying out new foods.
I am mostly a vegetarian, and occasionally eat meat, so my orders have a heavy bias towards vegetarian items.
author: Tejas B.

description: This place is the real deal. By far best burritos in the City. Do yourself a favor and come here.
author: K F.

description:
My friends and I were bar hopping and some of them wanted to grab tacos. I was still pretty hungry so I was down to get some myself. Deluxe carne asada taco please! And horchata!

The descriptions sound promising but upon receiving my meal, I wasn't impressed. The taste was equally unimpressive. Lacking in flavor and the corn tortillas were not good at all. My Mexican friends were upset as well.

The horchata, however, is made the way I like it (although quite a bit sweeter than I would like). Quite good!

I doubt I would go back here for tacos ever again. Reviews are making me curious about the burritos though.
author: Sofia R.

description:
3 stars for the food.  For the home of Mission Style burritos, I expected better.   The burrito had one flavor: grease.  Now, don't get me wrong. I think grease in a burrito is a great thing.
