But the carnitas I ordered were soft and mushy, the tomatoes had lost all texture, and the beans barely registered as part of my burrito.  Everything tasted pretty bland and unseasoned, not even salted, and it was a pretty underwhelming experience.  

-1 Star because I got some bad food poisoning, and I'm pretty sure it was from here.   They don't refrigerate their burrito toppings, like salsa and guac, and they had no AC.  It was during this heat wave, so I'm pretty sure it hit about 90 in there.  That's the perfect zone for bacterias, and they definitely seemed to be having a party.   

They also charged my friend for cheese and guacamole, even though he ordered a super burrito that comes with them as standard ingredients.
author: Josephine F.

description: I saw this restaurant on man versus food over the weekend. It was an old episode from around seven years ago. I work in San Francisco and I frequent the Mission area quite often. I've had better burritos for around seven dollars within a few blocks of this establishment. It may be the birthplace of the mission style burrito, but the one I had wasn't that big and did not have a lot of pork or sour cream in it. I probably will not return to this establishment anytime soon. It's overpriced and was lacking enough pork.
author: Dan M.

description:
A group of us were hanging out at a nearby bar on a Saturday night around dinnertime. The plan was to grab dinner somewhere but as the group got bigger and the wait for dinner spots got longer we decided bar food would do. What do you know?  We are at a bar that doesn't serve food (I forget the name of this place). Anyway they said we were allowed to bring our own food so we looked on yelp and this was the closest spot. 

Based on other reviews, we should of went elsewhere but we gave it a try.... disappointment.  

I got a carne asada burrito with almost everythinggggggggg they had on it... the lady making it kept trying to wrap it up before I was finished with my additions.  Wait, can you add cabbage, and lettuce, and that sauce... what's that sauce?  Yes, she hated me.  Anyways with all the additions it still lacked flavor and wasn't satisfying. I even had quite a few drinks earlier so you would think anything would have been tasty ... not this burrito.  I somehow missed adding cheese, or do they not have cheese?  All burritos I order have cheese...  or extra cheese. Where was the cheese? Maybe this burrito was so disappointing because I messed up ordering, was rushed or they don't have cheese.  Anyways I won't be back to find out.
author: Danielle H.

description:
Good spot for vegetarians! Wonderful salsa bar with a good variety of salsa, sauces, side veggies, etc. Try the green sauce. Not your standard green salsa. 

I had the fajita veggie burrito with no rice. They got my order right!!!!! My order came with a chips and the tortilla was soft and it was not soggy at all. The veggies inside the burrito was crisp and fresh. 

Place was packed and well patronized by locals. Staff are friendly. Centrally located in the Valencia area. Bartable. 

Removed one star because the bathroom was closed. ;-( Not available for use.
author: Kitty D.

description: Overpriced and bad quality. The food is not fresh and it sits out so your burrito or tacos arent very hot. I know my burritos and this isn't a spot I would recommend. People who give this place a good review don't know their Mexican food or have never tried other spots in the Mission. Or they are techies who don't mind paying $4 for toast and have no standards for Mexican food.
author: SF N.

description: Smells good  in here waiting for my steak fries to get ready. I like how they chop u the meat and take there time making your order
author: Kentara W.

description: This update is loooooong overdue. I received a response from the business about a week after i posted my review. They sent me a coupon for a free burrito. I went back and found out that they are no longer using little plastic cups to measure out the meat.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: The experience was one that I'll always remember. The staff is very nice and give great suggestions and smiles. I ordered the Super Mission Style Burrito made with Carne Asada (The Original) and a Tamarindo Soda. The Burrito had a great home feel attached to every bite I tasted. Flavors are able to be identified and not overpowering.
author: Joel V.

description: Tacos should not be served with beans and rice in it.  This taqueria isn't the one of the better ones in the Mission.  It was just OK, if you need a quick fix and you're too lazy to go walk one more block to Pancho Villa.
author: Wendy S.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for this place yet.  This is the burrito spot, hands down. 

When ppl want recommendations for Mexican food I ask them what subcategory they are looking for (tacos, coctels, Milanese, pozole, best chips and salsa, prawns, burrito, wet burrito) there's different places for each that I recommend.  I used to not eat red meat- stupid, not for any reason other than we ate a lot of it growing up and I was just totally done with it.  One night after dancing and drinking in the mission we ended up at La Cumbre.  They were cooking this sizzling glistening carne asada and I was captivated by it (I was also wearing this random slip over my clothes that I had found in a bag of discarded clothes I found on the street for comedic affect.  There is no shame in my game.) I ordered an asada burrito and I never looked back. The other thing that makes this burrito stand on a different level aside from the glorious meat is the flour tortilla.  Now I'm not sure if u will know what I'm talking about but let me try: u know how most flour tortillas are kinda sticky or tacky esp after being steamed and wrapped in foil?  Those kind often have what I can only describe as an artificial flavor to them, But then there's homemade legit flour tortillas that are not sticky and have a Powderly floury feel to them? And they don't taste artificial and like sour they taste fresh and just like a real flour tortilla should. These tortillas are too legit to quit.

I intended this to be just a short and sweet review just telling people to go have burritos here and, as usual, I have gone on and on but just go have a carne asada burrito at la cumbre.
author: Emma H.

description: They tried to short change me by giving me two out of the twelve dollar I was expecting, waited for my reaction and then gave me the remaining 10 dollar. It was after midnight but I wasn't drunk enough to fall for that old trick. Burrito was not particularly good.
author: Kristian L.

description: Good food, but lack of effort to add a few extra ingredients to my order lands them in the 3 zone. Effort is everything people.
author: Matthew P.

description:
Open late. Super friendly staff!

The man who took our order (maybe the owner?) took the time to learn our names and give us a good recommendation on margarita flavors. 

We even got to try some samples of their meat before we ordered!!
author: Cassie B.

description:
The service is fast but the food is too over priced and its not even all that good !? 
Just for a plate of nachos w/ chicken sour cream and guacamole was $11.00  really ??? I was surprised it came out that much , so I assumed "well if the food was kind of pricey " it must be really good ! 
Umm .. I was wrong  
Probably, wouldn't be going back to eat there anymore!
author: Issa B.

description: The beef was not good at all... :( The places was fine but since there are so many other places near by...we should have gone elsewhere or just had a bacon wrapped hotdog.
author: Lily P.

description:
Well, now I can say I tried it. I have to admit that we came all the way here just because I saw it on Man vs Food and Adam Richman claimed it was the first Mission burrito. What I didn't consider is that it may not be the best burrito. 

It was okay. The price was decent and it got the job done. The staff is begrudgingly nice because I think a lot of their customers are tourists and they thrive from word-of-mouth.

Problems: the burrito was SUPER messy. This wouldn't be an issue if I didn't have a similar burrito a few days later from an awesome taco truck in Fremont. The burrito was rather tasteless. How does that happen? I even threw some salsa and stuff on it. Tasteless. The bottled beer we ordered was totally old and skunked. I asked for a new one and the guy seemed annoyed and gave me another. Same taste. That is NOT what Dos Equis tastes like, dude. Maybe don't leave your bottles in the sun next time.

It got the job done and I was super full off of rice and beans. But I won't really be likely to recommend this place to anyone else.
author: Melissa F.

description: So I have been here plenty of times and had no problem, but I had an interesting experience last Friday. So I ordered a burrito (vegetarian) and I see the person making my food put some meat in it. I said to him I don't want any meat and he responds "are you sure?" .... I said no and he responded with a bit of tude and put that burrito aside and proceeded to make me another one. Then at the end he scooped up some rice with meat in it and put it in my burrito. He definitely saw that little piece of meat but folded up my burrito anyway and gave it to me. At this point I was starving so I just paid for my burrito and ate it carefully looking out for that piece of meat that guy spitefully put in. However the owner was nice and gave my friend and I mints and was super pleasant. Everything except the meat in my burrito (which luckily was at the end so I didn't eat that part) was delicious and the owner or manager was super nice. But that guy who made my burrito was super rude for no reason. I was considering giving 4 stars since I have never had a problem here but now I'm remembering how rude that guy was who purposefully put meat in my burrito so we are back down to 3. Sucks cuz I really liked this place plus it's open late but that last experience I had was off putting :/
author: Meera V.

description: Nobody does a burrito this well. Tortillas are never chewy or soggy, the carne asada tastes even better than it looks on the grill. Yes, some places will give you a little more food for a dollar or two less, but it will not taste this good. My parents have been coming here since 1970, and not for nostalgia: in San Francisco, restaurants either excel or die off. The combination of friendly service and excellent food keeps me coming back.
author: Jack P.

description:
Definetly the best taqueria around. The staff is friendly and the service is always fast. 

Their burrito's are REALLY yummy. Especially because of their orange sauce..
author: Styn V.

description:
After the owners review, I decided to come back for the second try. For the record, I do not like the owners response. How they use USDA grass fed beef and organic meat if they can. First off, all meat in the America needs to be USDA approved. Second, what's the point of a yelp page if people can't express their feeling. 

Came here when they were opening.
1. 2 ladies were making the food. One wore gloves and the other didn't. No comment. 
2. Got a super steak burrito. Let me tell you about grass fed beef. Grass fed beef's meat do not have any favor where you have to really put a lot seasoning on the steak for it to taste good. The steak was good but I'm sure it's not grass fed. It's what the owner says.

Overall, try the place yourself since someone have different taste buds and observation.
author: Jasmin T.

description: I threw my food in the trash. I mean...rice in a taco?? Gross.
author: Felicia J.

description: My cousin, whom lives in SF, recommended me this place. This taqueria is in the not so nice part of SF, parking is not as hard to find compared to other areas, but is is definitely worth the visit. I got here a little after they opened, so I was the only one there. The two ladies were very nice and answered all my questions, since I couldn't decide what to get . My kids are special eaters so they made them some scrambled eggs with fries on the side (not on the menu). I opted to the supreme nacho, regular burrito, and carne asada plate. All of the food was really good .
author: Liz C.

description: I ordered Tacos de Lengua and I got a small plate of heaven handed to me. Their lengua isn't cooked the way most tacquerias quickly pan fry lengua, it's exteemely tender and comes with a ton of juice. This of course adds to how amazing it is!! You really son't need to add any salsa or other toppings because the flavor is so exquisite, you'd want to experience it unaltered. My boyfriend ordered a carne asada burrito and liked it; the place has been featured on many food shows for it' burritos but I'd reccomend going "off the [b]eaten path" of food and try something a little less popular or well known. You won't be disappointed!
author: Autumn A.

description:
My favorite veggie burrito in the mission. Large burritos, but a smaller cylinder shape so that it's not too intimidating to eat. I just love how la cumbre has all the ingredients mixed together so that you're not just getting big bites of rice or sour cream. The veggie burritos here are also not as dry as places like Cancun (sorry boyfriend, I know you prefer Cancun but you're wrong). They melt the cheese right on the tortilla which is delicious and amazing. Horchata also good. Pro-tip: they have free salsas to the side. Get the fresh limes and squeeze that over your free chips to kick them up a notch. 

Ugh now all I want is a burrito. Why do I write reviews when all it does is make me hungry?
author: Claire G.

description: I came here to give it a 2nd try nope still meat has no flavor so disappointing don't waste ur time  and staff is rude  never again  don't waste your time going here
author: Remysbarbie M.

description: Decent Mission-style burritos. Lots of salsas and sauces to add to whatever your order. Quick and friendly service. Not as mind blowingly delicious as La Taqueria or El Farolito, but it'll do in a pinch. They also charge you an extra dollar over what the menu lists for Carne Asada... sure, they have a sign about it at the counter, but still...
author: Seth G.

description:
This was our go-to spot after going out on weekends. We would always be sure to make it home before they closed at 2:30 AM (we weren't the only ones with this idea). It's bright, there's a lot of seating, the line moves fast and there's actually a bathroom!

A carne asada petite burrito ($4.75) is the perfect amount of food! It fulfills your drunchies without making you too regretful in the morning. Don't forget the chips and to load up at the salsa bar. Nom nom.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Unfortunately, like other restaurants in this area in San Francisco (Mission district, Valencia street, etc) have a cockroach problem. I ate here and the food was good and I can see the staff attempting to keep it clean as much as possible, but one night I was out with two buddies and we came here after bar hoping and there was a roach. 

After seeing that, it kills it, like forever. I also worked in commercial property management and became good friends with professional pest control companies. The gave me the scoop on some restaurants in this district.  That's what happens in a big, condensed city. Ignorance is bliss but again I saw it once and that's all it takes.
author: Marie S.

description: Yummy food but most of all amazing service! They also make margaritas and what's better than Mexican food with margaritas??
author: Mina S.

description:
This is hands down one of my favorite Mexican restaurants in the mission. The food is high quality and the meat is cooked well. It doesn't have the crazy wait of other places and has sweet staff.

I like getting super tacos. It a real meal.
author: Aaron S.

description:
I've been here a handful of times over the years and it's never been very good, but I always forget that when one of my friends sings their praises. Seriously, my Facebook always has some ridiculous status update about how their burritos 
~lyke totally rawk~

The last time I came here I decided would be the last time I ever ate here. My burrito was bland, boring and blah. Not horrible, definitely edible, but not bursting with flavor and sending little mariachi band members to my taste buds like my friends promised. I got a chicken burrito, which is usually one of the hardest foods to fuck up EVER. It wasn't bad, but not good enough to change my mind about coming back. 

What really put me off here was how dirty it was. The tables were obviously in need of a good cleaning or at least a wipe down. The floor looked like it was crawling with cooties. The tables were out of napkins in the dispensers.

Adam Richmond must have been paid really well to say this place was the best burrito in the city.
author: Bianca U.

description: Saw this place on the food channel and decided to check it out. I was disappointed as it didn't live up to the hype! I had lengua taco's and the lady asked what kind of sauce, everyone knows salsa verde is the correct salsa for lengua however she said they didn't have green sauce. After she smothered the tacos in some sort of broth from an adjacent tray I then found out they had the correct salsa at the salsa bar. The lengua was extremely chewy like rubber. The Al pastor tasted like salty chorizo and their super burritos aren't that super in size. I wouldn't recommend to anyone looking for authentic Mexican and I've had burritos that tasted better from the taco truck! Shame on the food channel for misrepresenting this hole in the wall!
author: Michael G.

description:
I first heard about La Cumbre from seeing it on Man vs Food. Little did I know that La Cumbre was the birthplace of the mission style burrito.

You know that saying, "the dingier the taqueria, the better?" Well it's true. La Cumbre is definitely not dingy. There's colorful murals and all sorts of fun chotchkey thingies. Definitely a taqueria to play it safe with coworkers or to film on tv. 
 
My carne asada burrito was just ok. The carne was lean but bland. The rice a little undercooked, not really flavorful and fluffy. Even though I ordered it spicy, it was barely that. Definitely more style than substance. The $8 bucks for the burrito buys you the ambiance. 
 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=1pcT2gUF3VMSk1r43hwGsw)

If you like La Corneta, Gordos or even Pancho Villa, you'll probably like this. I think I'll stick to my grimy taquerias.
author: Earl G.

description: Best burrito I've had all day! I'll never eat another burrito again. Not even tomorrow or the next day or the next day. Man the chips were not bad either.
author: Jonathan S.

description: Pretty sure the hours provided on yelp is incorrect went there at around 1 am and got their supreme taco. The tortillas were bland and not toasted and fillings not that flavorful. Had better nachos in the east coast and expected better from a store in the mission. And it's not that cheap either. At least they gave nachos...
author: Ruby C.

description:
WOW 5 stars for AMAZING customer service in their catering department! Edward was absolutely amazing to work with. Let's just say he started off his confirmation email with, "First and foremost, I and everyone at La Cumbre wish you the best birthday possible. I am submitting a proposal for your review and approval." and ended with "Please let me know if we can be of service to you. It is our privilege and honour to be at your service. I will call, later today, to confirm the order". 

Multiple times, he helped us go back and forth to plan my boyfriends birthday party. He called and emailed and adjusted the order to make sure we were happy- always sending a confirmation email so we were in the loop. He also wished my boyfriend happy birthday multiple times which I thought was very sweet of him. The food was ready exactly when they said it was and everyone enjoyed it! We ordered prawns, chicken, veggies, rice, beans, chips, and guac and had SO much left over that we're still enjoying it this week :) 

I'd recommend anyone to cater their party food from La Cumbre just due to how nice and responsive their catering department was. Ed will help you out so that you're completely happy and satisfied with their service! Make your party a little less stressful by having a reliable caterer!
author: Victoria L.

description:
Went here after the Giant's game.
It was unusually hot in the city (80+ degrees) so when we walked in, it was like stepping into an oven. The door was open for the occasional breeze.

Felt bad for the employees that were stuck inside that hot box all day. Just sayin'
They were super friendly :) Smiling in spite of being inside while it was so gorgeous outside on a lovely Sunday.

I ordered a cheese quesadilla with guacamole. They are the first ones to actually put the guacamole in the quesadilla instead of just handing me a guacamole on the side. Can't go wrong with it! It filled me up.

We sat in, wished there was outdoor seating, that would have been phenomenal. Just sayin' It was crowded when we got there a little after 6ish. It started 

They have a restroom that you have to ask the cashier for a key, fyi.
author: Camille C.

description: They are nice. Someone was in the bathroom and they let me wash my hands in a sink behind the counter
author: Lenny V.

description:
What a gem!

We were greeted with smiles! These people must've been having a great day. The employees behaved like they were lottery winners that just... you know.. love coming to work? For the people? They were great. Gave us free taste tests of the meat too.

I tried 2 different burritos and ordered the veggie salad for myself. It was cheap and light... except that when it hit the table.. it was gigantic. The taste! Incredible! I'd LOVE to go back to this place and if I'm craving Mexican food. This is where I will go!

The only downside was the bathrooms... 
It was pretty gross. Sticky floors, puddles, horrible smell. The kind of place where you don't put the key down because you don't want to have to touch whatever it rested on? My mom went later, she opened the door and closed it immediately. We had to go somewhere else. Haha. 

But anyway. Great place. Good food. Great service and a decent beer selection!
author: Nora N.

description:
Stopped by and picked up the massive 2lb burrito for the family to try out and all I can say is 2 pounds of no flavor. 

The meat was so bland was it just cooked in water with no seasoning? 

Way overpriced even for the size it was mostly beans.

Sorry guys but I think I have had a better burrito off of a roach coach
author: iron s.

description:
I *really* wish taquerias would label their salsas so I don't take a huge mouthful of pico del gallo and have it destroy my mouth. 

That being said... 

What I loved about this place was burritos came in petite size. Considering I can't finish a regular burrito, petite seemed perfect! I still couldn't finish what I had though! Surprise!

We ordered a petite vegetarian burrito and a regular grilled chicken burrito. Filling and ingredients were fresh and good, but I found the vegetarian burrito could have had a *bit* more flavour to it. I might consider adding a few more extra fillings to it aside from beans, rice, lettuce and cheese. My companions burrito, on the other hand, was really happy with his. Apparently the chicken is freshly cooked, not pre-made shredded stuff.

The price is also super good, especially if you get the smaller option.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
This place is awesome. I do not understand why there are so many negative reviews! 
Last time I was here I ordered a HUGE regular veggie taco which came out to like $2.75 after tax. $2.75, yeah... Amazing. Super delicious and they have a great salsa bar. Oh yeah did I mention TWO SEVENTY FIVE and I was hella full. Came in thinking I would need two tacos but one was enough. 

Fresh food, the service is great for how nutty Valencia can get and plenty of room to sit and enjoy. 

*By the way if you say you got sick right after eating the food it is probably because you drank too much whiskey over at Casanova.
author: chad l.

description:
Go-to spot for a burrito in the Mission. Sure, there are fancier burritos out there... but this place does it right. The owner of this place is awesome, and the staff is always super friendly - no matter the time of day. 

Being a Southern Californian by birth, I judge Mexican food pretty hard - and La Cumbre fits the bill.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Not sure why this place doesn't have more stars. The service is impeccable and they remember your name even though it's an order at the register type place. 
We got the nacho fries and they were really decadent. Crispy golden fries covered in tons of cheese, meat, sour cream, and guac. So glad they didn't overload on the beans. We got the horchata which was really refreshing. Will definitely return.
author: Cynthia G.

description: Used to the best burrito in Bay Area but now is average at best.  Steak isn't cooked fresh anymore but is stored, pre-cooked, in a brownish pile.  Not enough cilantro. To add insult to injury, the burrito was cold inside.  Yuck.
author: Patrick R.

description: This place is a joke. The burritos are super small and they have about 3 pieces of meat. I basically ate a been and rice burrito and paid like $10. They were out of potatoes and bacon and it was early in the morning and not busy at all. I do not recommend this place.
author: Hilda P.

description: This place is one of the oldest and finest Mexican places in SF. I've been going here since 1985, and native San Franciscans know the quality of the food here. No other place in SF (or anywhere that I've found) serves skirt steak burritos! The guacamole is the BEST! They have a new grilled veggie burrito which is fantastic. I LOVE it's down home, authentic atmosphere, and it's one of the few remaining old school taquerias left in SF. Visit them today, you will be so happy you did!
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
The deluxe grilled chicken burrito was 2/5. There were hard black bits throughout the burrito which I think were very burned pieces of chicken or maybe grilling buildup? Too bad I got the burrito to go and had no recourse to return it.

I do appreciate the quick service.

I had heard about this place for a long time and can now check it off my list.
author: Rebecca B.

description: Best of the best and don't get me started with costumer service they totally kill it love this place and the people that works there totally recommended
author: Alexander G.

description: Absolutely authentic and delicious. I have recommended this place to many friends and family. Always a great place to go after a day at Dolores park.
author: Pouria S.

description: Ordered their Carne Asada Super Burrito. Where's the Steak? Chunks of Tomatoes? Lettuce? Back 15 years ago your Super Burrito "belonged"on a pedestal. Now It belongs in the Garbage can! Along with your Integrity! You Fucked Up Royally! I hope Gordon Ramsay pays you a surprise visit & tells you litterally "Get your head Out Your Ass!"
author: Thomas H.

description:
Burrito was very large and the meat that I had was fresh. Everything just sort of came together to be one giant messy burrito. Probably because I ordered a super burrito. Although, if I order a super burrito a few blocks away at El Farolito its much better. Good salsas, all hot. 

Cashier could not have been more unfriendly.
author: J A.

description: An old classic.  Interior was clean and the service was quick and friendly.  My chicken super burrito was tasty and the horchata was excellent.  I did notice that the wrap on my burrito was a little sloppy, but that's not a deal breaker.
author: Patrick S.

description: For the money, it can't be beat. Loaded taco with some chips for $3.00. The food is good to. Margarita deal is worth a look.
author: J S.

description:
Haven't wrote a review in a little over 8 months but had to log-in to Yelp to review this.

I feel hesitant about saying this, but this is probably the best burrito I've ever had. Weird seeing as how I've been spoiled by the burritos in Southern California.

Could having this burrito while only having alcohol in my stomach at 3am be a reason why I give this burrito such a high praise? Perhaps. Though, all my friends who tried this burrito can vouch that it's the best burrito they've ever had, too. I just touched down in Long Beach from SF an hour ago and all I can think about is this burrito. Not going to lie - a part of me is thinking of driving up JUST to get this.

Apologies for making raising your expectations about this place. Clearly there are other people who don't agree. I definitely think it's AT LEAST worth a shot.
author: Alex S.

description: We stopped here after seeing the burritos featured on Man vs Food.  We were not disappointed!!!  We got the 'Adam Richman burrito' and shared it between the three of us!  Huge portions and absolutely delicious!
author: Kim S.

description:
This place looks like any sort of taqueria where you order at an "assembly line" and then pay at the counter. There is also free chips and a salsa bar.

I got some grilled chicken enchiladas. The beans were good, as well as the chicken. However, I'm not sure what they meant by enchilada"s" -- I thought more were buried underneath the lettuce but there was nothing there. In terms of the amount of food it was underwhelming.

I wouldn't mind stopping here again, but definitely only if there aren't other better choices. There are too many taquerias in the city to waste your time at an average one.
author: Alice C.

description:
Had the deluxe burrito ($6.95) with "chile Colorado=choice meat w/red sauce", spicy salsa and pinto beans. This thing was decent-sized and quite good, though I could only eat half of the darn thing (it was either too much food, or the spiciness did me in). Even a medium-sized=24oz horchata ($2.25) was not enough to save the taste buds. FAIL.

Feel that it's a tad above the average taqueria and got the fourth star due to the friendliness, them being "the first taqueria in SF" in 1967, plus being repped in Maxim magazine's August '09 issue as one of "72 places to try before you die" (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=N0jmiH8mywEYH5vBHUySvA). The ceiling is very high, which helped to air out the place a bit. Great wall decor as well. Lots of seatings (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=WEgayFnHJEb1_4MBBCwyIA), and saw hipsters, yuppies as well as families eating here.
author: Peter L.

description: We came here because we saw Adam Richmond talk about them on man vs food. We got a carne Asada super burrito & a taco plate (1 green chicken & 1 green pork). The carne Asada was okay, but both of the green meats were fabulous... Whoever makes that green sauce is killin it! Their salsa bar has a great selection, but they should label them because the orangey one is way too spicy. All in all, we're glad we came in tonight :)
author: danielle a.

description:
It is with a heavy, heavy heart that I must bid adieu, forever, to La Cumbre. It once served up the finest burrito in all the land, every time, and it was always worth the wait, whenever there was a wait.

But there is rarely a wait any longer, and it's because La Cumbre now serves up the worst, most offensive, prison-like slop in all the land. The tortillas are rubbery. The beans are sewage spill. The meat is chopped squirrel. 

Shame on everybody involved for turning a go-to, never-fail icon into manatee vomit.

Update Oct. 25, 2013: I now see that Edward somebody has responded to the initial review above.

Edward: Your product is crap. It used to be the best. That's when you got your good reviews from Unterman, et al. Maybe you should pay attention to the other 1-stars you get on here. La Cumbre sucks. I used to love it. Why did you let it get so bad?
author: Yowz A.

description: Unacceptable quality for an a mature burrito. These people have no idea on how to assemble a quality burrito and you're just wasting your money going here.
author: Yoav E.

description: Best. Taqueria. Ever. And trust me, after 17 years in the Mission, I know my Mexican food. ;) The food is so fresh and well-made with high quality ingredients and skilled preparation. And as if that's not enough for a Mission taqueria, the owner and workers are so incredibly friendly and kind. Couldn't ask for more. OH yeah, their beef is grass-fed and free range, and their avocados are organic! These people are proud of their food and put a lot of heart into it, and it shows.
author: jen b.

description:
La Cumbre is my go-to taqueria. There are a few reasons for this:

1. Their meat is MUCH better than Pancho Villa down the street. I wonder where Pancho's comes from, but I dare not ask... The chicken (pollo) at La Cumbre is amazing. I think they marinate it in pineapple sauce or something. The bottom line is that it's delicious and is slightly sweet and goes great with black beans. I usually get a taco or burrito with that combo. 

2. Their horchata is perfectly sweetened. Not too sweet, not too watery. This is a rare quality in horchata. 

3. They are open later than any other taqueria around 16th and Valencia (except on Sundays. That's the Lord's day, after all...). 

4. Last and certainly not least, the owner (Edward) is a true community member and an all-around wonderful guy. I mean, just the fact that he's responded to all the reviews here on Yelp is one excellent indication that he cares deeply about his restaurant and the community it serves. He also gives back to the community around him. And, finally, he gives great life advice. He's made me smile on more than one occasion after having a tough day.
author: Carrie J.

description:
Meh. Chewy, flavor-less carne asada. Torta buns that look just like a regular hot dog bun. Everything there pales in comparison to many of the other taquerias around the area like Cancun or Los Coyotes.

I feel like this place only thrives because of its prime location. I guess it's possible to create a business based around the 2am drunk crowd!
author: Kazu O.

description: So there's a story behind us finding out about this place.  My husband wound up meeting Jack Black at a work event in Miami prior to flying to meet me in San Francisco.  Jack asked him when he was returning to New York, and when he said he was going to SF, Jack recommended trying Taqueria La Cumbre.  The burritos were great!  We both had the chicken burrito; it had great flavors and was filling.  We'll definitely be back the next time we're in SF.
author: Megan L.

description:
La Cumbre has been around for decades.  It was one of the few places that served burritos that reminded me of the food I grew up with in East Los Angeles.  I would always come here after living out of state and out of country.  A friend sent me a La Cumbre teeshirt when I was in Africa with the Peace Corps.

Over the years there are now hundreds of places that serve burritos in the Bay Area. Everyone has their favorite places that meet their tastes.

Huzby and I had lunch here recently for old times sake.  We both got the grilled veggie burritos with rice and beans.  (I had cheese on mine).
We both thoroughly enjoyed each bite.  I've never had the meat burritos so I can't vouch for them.

We now have several favorite spots for Mexican food in the East Bay so we no longer need to come to La Cumbre as a destination spot.  But if we are in the Mission again we'd definitely stop here again.

Food is more like 3 star but an extra star for their salsa bar which includes salsa, onions and cilantro.  

Service is still friendly.
author: Rinky N.

description: One star because Yelp won't let me write a zero star review. OK, one star for the clean restroom.. My husband and I went here today to finally try their burittos. We split one (thank God we didn't order our own). We frequent the Mission and know a great Buritto. There were five guys working behind the counter and 3 other patrons eating. Our buritto was ICE cold and because we split it, I got all the cold meat and cold beans and my poor husband got the wilted lettuce and cold rice. Was there chesse on this super buritto? We couldn't find it....Small buritto but that's ok because it was not really edible. They offer chips for ONLY 50 cents!!! Seriously? Who makes you pay for chips? The other couple that was there ordered "plates" they had to ask if they could have some tortillas and  then had to wait, pay and pick up their tortillas at the counter because none of the 5 guys working here could walk 4 feet to deliver them?!?!? Save your money and go to Taqueria Cancun on Misson Street and get one of the best burittos or street tacos around!
author: Kim M.

description:
After living in SF all these years I finally made it to El Cumbre. The holy grail. The authentic SF Mexican....

Well, their nachos come with ballpark-style orange nacho cheese goo... And their guacamole is mushy avocado paste with no other ingredients or seasoning.

I am baffled as to how this place is always busy, and as to how it's managed to stay in business so long. I will never go back and you should probably avoid it at all costs.
author: jared c.

description:
Apparently Man vs. Food aired an episode here...

...apparently, that guy is a great actor.

The burrito looks great, and I marvel at the craftsmanship in the foil wrapping because it's so tightly rolled that it could double as a lethal weapon.  The flavors, however, are bland--especially for a "Super" Burrito.  $8+ is asking a lot for a boring burrito, and the complimentary chips don't suffice.  There is a large menu, however, so feel free to navigate it.  But if you really want a good burrito, I'd suggest putting in the Yelp homework because I've enjoyed better elsewhere.
author: Diane N.

description: One of my very first Taqueria experiences ever in NorCal. I used to TA for this professor in college who took us to the Clarion Alley murals and we'd eat here while in the area. This was my staple with Ti Couz for many years before the SF dining scene exploded. Carne Asada, Buche, and Lengua are the go to's. Ive since discovered many different regional style taquerias all over the area but I give La Cumbre props for opening my eyes to it.
author: Kim N.

description: I stumbled on this place by accident while I was waiting for a friend to meet me for drinks in the Mission. I really had to pee (sorry, TMI) so I figured I would be classy and order a taco and a beer. The carne asada is BEYOND.  I am a self-professed taco-holic who loves me some El Castillito and La Taqueria but there's definitely something about this place that's just as good - if not, dare I say.. better?? Maybe because it's less of a scene and the people working were so friendly that I forgot for a second I was even in the city. Seriously, hit this place up! There's live music and tons of space to sprawl out and enjoy some cervezas with your friends.  Salsa bar on point, too.
author: Kristine L.

description: Great affordable authentic food and great service! We had the Carnitas dinner and Carne Asada dinner plate. Yummy! Definitely will be back again!
author: Christa B.

description: My friends and I went here after wandering around the mission and trying to decide on a taco joint.  We were having trouble deciding on what to order and were given tastes of the chicken and beef. Both were wonderful but the chicken is truly awesome!  We ordered 4 super tacos and a fajita plate. I normally stick to tacos or burritos in the mission because you can't go wrong with those options.  But the chicken fajita plate was the best I've ever had! The staff was very helpful and courteous. I will definitely be going here again.
author: Katie P.

description: I saw this place on travel channel one day and finally decided to check it out. The tortillas were flavorful and had a good color to them and the meat was very well seasoned. I got the steak burrito. The guacamole had a nice lime taste to it. I also sampled one of the chicken tacos and I was very pleased. Also, the Spanish rice perfectly complemented the meat cheese and sour cream combination. The only reason I do not give this 5 stars is because although the food was very good, the bathrooms were dirty, some of the tables were not cleaned properly and the staff was very impatient. Overall, however, I would definitely recommend a visit.
author: Alex C.

description: Ordered a deluxe burrito with pork and a side of chips with salsa and guac. The staff members were so kind--asking how our day was, what our plans for the holidays were, etc. I am definitely making this my go-to taqueria in the Mission. Also, portions are plenty and all burritos already come with a side of chips (so no need to order more!)
author: Sarah M.

description: Been coming here for more than 20 years.  I love that it has never changed.  The selection on the menu is grande for meal, meat, beans, salsa.  Consider price, quality, dive atmosphere, consistency -  5 stars
author: Phil G.

description: Today was my first time here. Really enjoyed the black beans on tacos. This is really really rare to find a restaurant that serves black beans on tacos. Restaurant has a traditional Mexican feel to it. 40-year-old tradition. It all started here.
author: Jermaine E.

description: My husband is a burrito fanatic and really wanted to check this place out after seeing it featured on "Man vs. Food." We shared chips, guac, and a steak burrito. Not very impressed with "the first mission style burrito." The meat was good (you can taste the flame-broiled sear) and the fillings (rice, guac, salsa, beans) were fine. The chips were on the tough side and neither of us were a fan of the smooth, blended, store-bought guac. Worth coming back to? Nah. We're happy with our favorites down here in L.A.
author: Laurice F.

description:
I have been here a few times now. While I understand they invented the mission style burrito, I don't think they have completely perfected it or maybe I don't enjoy the authenticity.  Each time I order a burrito here,  what I get is:
 A very soggy tortilla
 A hunk of stale lettuce
 A soggy mix of onions and tomatoes
 A piece of pre cooked meat that they put in a bowl and steam to reheat right in front of you.

Yeah there is some plain guacamole too and lots of cheese. Overall not a fan. I think this place has location in its favor being right on the corner facing Valencia. I would rather walk around the block to Pancho Villa any day.
author: Greg G.

description: The burrito was very good the steak was very good can't wait to go back again I found this place when I was watching man vs food and I had to go see if it was good and it was
author: Eduardo T.

description:
This is one of those authentic-looking Mexican places with a very deep menu that may satisfy someone who enjoys obscure Mexican dishes (at least to a Gringo).

However, if you're just looking for a tasty burrito I would avoid this. I had high hopes waiting in line because the pollo asado and carne asada had just finished cooking and looked mighty good as they were sliced up by the cook and transfered to their respective bins. 

Unfortunately the super burrito I ordered was extremely disappointing. I requested half chicken / half steak (ordering pro-tip) and found both of these meats to be extremely tough and full of fat and grizzle. The 'super' burrito was supposed to come with guacamole but instead it just came with fresh avocado - which is cool as well and there was a decent portion of it, but it just had no flavor; the difference between guacamole and avocado is there's actually seasoning and ingredients that add flavor. There wasn't really any flavor in the rest of the burrito either and I ended up throwing 2/3rd's of it away which I almost NEVER do. Plus I was kind of drunk and it should have tasted a lot better.

PRO TIP - There are plenty of better places to grab a burrito in the area.
author: Alex V.

description:
La Cumbre looks good, even classic. Maybe that's why I give it another "final chance" once a year. But it never gets any better. Just not very good food... everything I've ever eaten here has been kind of tasteless, blah. When you're this close to El Buen Sabor and Cancun, there is simply no reason to pay for bland burritos.

Mark my words, the actual quality of the cooking here is nowhere as good as the decor.  They just have this amazing ability to make a burrito that tastes like... nothing!
author: Eric O.

description: very big fan of La Cumbre. Burritos are off the chainnnnnn. My mouth waters thinking about it. Great value here and very vegetarian friendly. I could wish upon a star that there was a la cumbre back home.... but theres not. So i must drive almost 500 miles every time i'm in dire need.
author: Shelby H.

description: What can I say that has not already been said?? The food quality has gone down. Used to be my go to for burritos but after a few disappointing experiences I don't go there anymore.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Taqueria La Cumbre is another restaurant featured on Man V. Food that I've been waiting to check off my list. Finally, on a chilly, foggy day I was able to experience their amazing burritos.

After searching up and down Valencia Street, I finally was able to find a meter only a couple short blocks away. The restaurant has plenty of religious statues, candles, murals, and only a handful of tables. The menu is hanging high on the wall and is pretty straight forward. They have super burritos, deluxe burritos, regular burritos, tacos, and other delicious Mexican dishes. Once you pick what you want, you choose your meat and condiments then watch them prepare it right in front of you. They even chop the meat right when you order it. Now that's fresh!

After a long day of hoofing it around the city, my stomach was practically eating itself. I decided to splurge and order whatever sounded good. I went with the regular nachos with spicy salsa and the deluxe chicken burrito. My eyes were definitely bigger than my stomach because this was a ton of food! The nachos were the simple chips and cheese type but still tasted great. The burrito was beyond amazing. It was jam packed with generous portions of chicken, guacamole, salsa, beans, rice, and cheese. The first thing I noticed about the burrito was when they grilled the tortilla, the cheese was already on it. That melted the cheese and made it amazingly gooey in every bite! Also, each bite was just as delicious as the last.

The ladies behind the counter were all nice and seemed to enjoy their jobs which makes the dining experience that much better. Especially at a tiny, casual place like this, it's rare to find happy employees.

The atmosphere was very homey and what you would expect from a small mom and pop shop. The employees were all getting engrossed in the soccer game on the TV but it didn't take away from the service or high quality of the food.

When we got there the place was pretty empty, but as we were leaving the lunch-hour rush was starting and it was filling up quick. If you don't want a long wait, get here early!
author: Kevin R.

description: Terrible! Used to eat here 23 years ago and it was excellent! It was our favorite burrito place. Not sure what has happened, but in recent years the food quality is BAD! We've given this place multiple tries for nostalgia's sake, but after today, we are DONE! Sloppy, cold, barely any meat! Even the chips were stale and difficult to eat! The gentrification has hit the burritos, lettuce seems to be the main ingredient.
author: K B.

description:
What a terrible little taqueria. First time I came here I had a $5 bill on me, so I ordered something that should have come out to less than $5 based on the price on that giant handwritten wall menu, instead it was more than two dollars above the posted price. I asked what the cost was pre-tax and was told a higher than posted price. I pointed this out, and assumed that was the end of it, I mean, it goes without saying how illegal it is to charge a different price than what you advertise on the menu, so when the cashier just shrugged and said "the menu is old" I was kind of blown away. I called for the manager, and he simply pointed to a sign on the wall that said "prices may change". That's obviously not enough, either legally or responsibly. Their sign is dry erase, why do they think they can get away with this? 

Anyway, I bit the bullet, overpaid, got my Nachos. Absolutely disgusting. As gross as Nacho cheese normally is, this was a particularly soggy, smelly, and SMALL portion. Couldn't even finish it and nobody in my party even wanted to try it. 

Which turned out to be pretty smart because I spent the entire next day with food poisoning. From fucking Nachos. 

Avoiding this dishonest and disgusting taqueria. Much better ones in the neighborhood like Cancun.
author: Jules S.

description: Average tasting Carne Asada Burrito. Average tasting salsa. Good place if your hungry and want to get food quickly. Up sale up sale up sale.
author: Brendan J.

description:
I brought friends from out of town for a bite of La Cumbre between bars in the Mission district last week-end.  It was very conveniently located between Thieves Tavern and the 500 Club, so that was a good.  Also, there wasn't much of a crowd here.  The service was courteous and efficient.  You get in line along the frond counter aisle area, tell the servers what you'd like, then pay at the end of the counter. It is the same at most taquerias in the Mission, of course.  
I ordered a chorizo burrito with everything on it - beans, rice, cheese, sour cream, guacamole.  It was a big burrito, and very filling.  It definitely hit the spot.
author: Roland C.

description:
Most sorry excuse for a Taqueria I've ever been to. My boyfriend and I went to San Fran last week and after seeing this spot on Man vs Food we were quite excited.
We both ordered regular burritos with carne asada (because who can mess up a damn burrito???!) it was awful. No taste. Poorly made. I'm full Mexican and never in my life have I been more disappointed. 
If you love food, please save your money and don't eat here.
author: Gabriela S.

description:
Drink a couple beers after work, contemplate/smile at the pretty woman in their logo...she's got her ammo, her flag, some music, a little tequila in her..

hardworking staff, consistent burrito. convenient, glad it's still around
author: C L.

description: Came here before a show at the Greek theatre.. Only good thing was the chips and salsa!
author: Stephanie M.

description: These are my favorite burritos. Deluxe carne asada, refied beans, the hottest salsa. Just do it.
author: Isabella G.

description: Stopped in here at 2 AM for some post-drinking eats, and ended up with the next day's breakfast as well. There was no line at this time, although most of the tables were full and this is 'The Home of the Mission Burrito', after all.  My friend went with the standard burrito, I got an egg/cheese/peppers/onions quesadilla.  The portion size was huge - I had to split it between then and the next morning.  Tons of cheese, and overall good flavor, especially with the salsa bar.  The fresh tortilla chips were pretty good too.  I would come back again.
author: Ben K.

description:
Cool: I asked her what kind of meat she recommended that day and she chopped up 5 kinds in a dish with a toothpick to try. 
Bummer: None of them were all that good. The best of the five I tried that day was the Polo Asada so I got the plate. 

Cool: The plate was plentiful with plenty of corn tortillas so you don't have to go back and ask for more. Also, there's a nice salsa bar in the corner. 
Bummer: I woke up at 5 am the next morning with some La Cumbre's 

Revenge. The facilities weren't clean at all (usually inversely proportionate to how good a taco joint is) but could be the culprit to my blowing A all morning.
author: Matt D.

description: This place is a bit dingier than Pancho Villa, which I usually frequent, but wanted to check out some other taquerias. I had one of the vegetarian burritos and eliminated the cheese/sour cream to make it vegan. The beans and guac were kind of runny, but overall it was pretty aight. The staff is really endearing, though - they make me wish I loved the place more!
author: Shendi X.

description:
Yeah I came here after seeing Man vs Food.  So what?  How do any of choose a place to eat?  Recommendations of others, and I trust Adam's big taste.  I went in expecting to say LA has far superior tacos and burritos, and I'm at least half correct.

We went in after closing time, but they were nice enough to let us in.  We were the last order of the day, but they didn't half-ass it.  Even with two really annoying customers in front of us, they kept their cool and gave great service.

They had only carne asada since it was so late in the night.  No problem, I was getting a carne asada burrito anyway.  I was surprised how much care they took while cooking it, and it was by no means overcooked or under seasoned.  I was really happy with the end of the order.  After they wrapped up the burrito, she asked if it was okay.  Que?  Well, actually I like a little more beans.  Ok!  All the right options, hot or mild salsa, yes or no onions/cilantro, what kind of beans.

So why not that last star?  The fiance got a deluxe veggie taco.  $3.45 got her a small taco tortilla, beans, cheese, guacamole, and lettuce.  So what makes that deluxe.  Let's go back... what makes that $3.45?!  If you charge that much, make it worth it.  I'd be pissed if I was a vegetarian.  I would call that a mini soft tostada, and charge $2.  With no meat, I don't see how they can charge that much.

As for the salsas, all amazing, especially the green avocado salsa with onions.  But I liked the red just as much.  I can't wait to come back.  Oh, and it definitely keeps up with LA burritos.  I'll still take my El Atacor and Guisados down here, but this gets the job done in the Bay Area.
author: Matt C.

description: Historical and very traditional place.  Representing the Mission District...Visited the location, easy to find, parking was easy.  Service was great.  Place is big, has that old school Taqueria feeling.  Food was not that good.  I ordered the Carne Asada and it was very tough, no seasoning.  Burrito was stuffed which is great just didn't have that taste that i was looking for and is so accustomed to eaten from within the Mission.  Will probably try again, just in case that was a bad day.......But no time soon.
author: Nic C.

description: Ok, this isn't a five star restaurant. The utensils are plastic.  But, the service and food were 5 stars!  The salsa bar was good.  My enchiladas, rice, beans and salad were great!  Loved the music.  Edward, and the ladies, you rock!
author: Blondie R.

description: Love the vibe of Mission. Coworker is a big fan and we had to make a stop - another coworker was scared for her life, going there at night - yes, she's a bit prissy. Large portions, super friendly owner... fresh preparation. Nice, authentic blast for suburbanites.
author: Chris C.

description: Great Burrito, friendly service, only draw back is parking is impossible....not their fault though!
author: Jon B.

description:
Tried their carnitas & fish tacos. The carnitas was pretty good but the fish taco was something special. Delicious~

Gonna  try the beef tongue next time ^_ ^
author: Cheung L.

description:
I'll admit it. In my quest to win a professional MMA fight, I allowed myself to fall into the camp of carb snobs who believe that if one is to eat carbs; said carbs must be consumed within the 20-minute post-workout window and either in the form of oats, fibrous vegetables, fruit, quinoa, or Quest bars. A trip to La Cumbre was what it took to realize how far I'd strayed from the true path.

During a visit to San Francisco, a local friend informed me that burritos are kind of a thing in SF, so we headed to La Cumbre to grab dinner.

Service was speedy and excellent, smoothly guiding me away from even the slightest bit of cilantro. I ordered a pollo asada, and it was delicious. Their burritos are steamed rather than grilled, which was noticeable from the first touch. After taking a bite, I was sold. The chicken was moist and well-flavored, the rice was a perfect complement, and the soft yet springy texture of the tortillas capped it off phenomenally. The spicy sauce could have been spicier; but overall, this is easily the best burrito I've ever had.

I'll definitely be back, both before and after that fight.
author: J C.

description: The service was much better this second time.  I had the regular burrito with carnitas and I was good.  I like that their condiments are spicy and unlimited.
author: Richard T.

description:
I've been saying this for 10 years - this is the best burrito San Francisco has to offer.

When I was in high school I"d go here to eat a burrito before punk shows at the old MIssion Rex. If anybody remembers those days - memory lane!
author: Doug R.

description: Dank burritos. Hands down the best burrito I have tasted. Chipotle dsnt even compare.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
Very, very shitty food. I've tried many taquerias in my stint as a UCSC college student, and this one is less than stellar. Shitty service, crummy ingredients, and bland meat add up to a one-star review.

I had a steak burrito and my friend had two tacos. Both of us agreed the meat was bland and not fresh. Their guac looks like something poured out from a product pulled off the shelves of Costco rather than being made from fresh avocados. The salsa was soggy and flavorless. Even the chips were bland. Limes and extra salsa from the salsa bar couldn't save it.

I'm not much of a Chipotle person (all for authenticity) but honestly Chipotle's food is miles better than this taqueria's - save yourself the trouble and give your business to another taqueria instead.
author: Felix C.

description:
I was really excited to head to Pancho Villa for a good burrito, until I realized it was closed because it was past 1 am.

Still on the golden quest, and too lazy to walk the 16 blocks to El Farolito, I settled on this. (I really need to reevaluate my life if I consider this an actual deterrent to getting the best burrito in the world, because I ended up with this and... thats bad.)

I took one look and I was like..well... I'm ordering the freshly grilled carne asada because everything else looks weird, and tacos because that burrito looks whimpy. 

Got my tacos. Carne was juicy! So it was actually alright, but the cheese weirded me out. W/e. Not my top choice for burritos, but not awful.
author: Emily D.

description:
You always see it. It's always filled with drunks. Is the food good? Nah... it's aight.

We got some burritos that tasted like any other burrito out there. It wasn't even that cheap. It was like $12 or something??? Ridic. Should have been sprinkled with golden flakes for that price.

Also got some horchatas, and to be fair, the portion of that was freakin' huge though. So that was worth it. Aside from that, the location is great but the food is bleh. I'd only come back on a drunken stupor.
author: Paul B.

description: Burritos were pretty good once they got it right. The lady behind the glass just could not get anything right. I overheard the guy behind me having the same problem as I did. Almost like they were messing with me on purpose. The guy at the counter was SO RUDE. He literally flung the food at me and said "here's whatever you ordered", to which I responded, "carnitas burrito" and he said "whatever". WOW. Unbelievably rude service. The foods not worth the attitude.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Can't get enough of this place. I try other Mexican joints in the neighborhood, but I can't stay away from La Cumbre! The food is so fresh, the prices are so reasonable, the lines moves so quickly, and the employees are so nice.

My go-to is the deluxe chicken tacos (w/ spicy salsa and black beans), but you can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The chicken is superior to the carnitas, in my opinion, and if you like lettuce in your burritos / tacos, go with Super anything. Recently my boyfriend tried the chicken con salsa and I think he may be a convert.
author: Kera Z.

description: I have been coming to La Cumbre for over 20 years when I'm in the area I make a point to get carne asada burrito, yesterday was no different.  I just want to say a special thanks because it was going to be a to go order because I had my dog with me.  When the owner realized this he set us up with table, chairs, chips, salsa etc. outside in front; very nice as he did not have to do that. Oh and did I mention the carne asada was as delicious as always!
author: Kelly a.

description:
In regards to the responce from the business this is my reply please read below....


Hello Edward, Everything you stated was great as well as what i said in my review "not all restaurants are for everyone and that is innevitable" Yes Edward, unfortunatelly i am a true yelper and i believe in fairness, Really and trully yelping is much rathering comfortable than telling management up front sometimes because you see many managers do not have proper management communication skills and make people feel a bit odd. Avoiding an awkward 30 second conversation about a burrito would make me a less selfish and un ethical person on my behalf therefore yelpers like me turn to YELP. Please accept my critisism as not all reviews are meant to be positive and i beg to differ on this review being "troublesome" as you say. My intent is not to run you out of business my fellow san franciscan rather to share my personal experience. it is a total lack of proffesionalism to not accept any negative feedback which actually helps improve your business as times are changing. I apreciate your personal responce and I think that your communication with the public shows lots of care for what you do however, you cannot really ask someone who does not like salsa to try it out. Good day and best of luck in all your future restaurant endeavors.
author: Eli A.

description:
I had a carne asada super taco and shared a super chicken quesadilla.  At 2am, the meat was really fresh!.  The carne asada pollo asada was juicy and very flavorful.  The quesadilla was packed with guacamole which was amazing.  The super taco was also huge.  Everything tasted fresh, even there salsa bar.  

I only give it 3 stars because I grew up in LA, so there are taquerias my palette longs for.  

This place is not bad, but it isn't the greatest I've had either.  If I am in the area, I would come back!
author: Raymund S.

description:
The BEST taqueria in San Francisco. The original & still the BEST. Best corn tortillas, best beans, best horchata & best carne asada.  
(OK. Their guacamole's pretty .... Not good). Their cheese is 
fresh & sliced (not shredded). They make their 
tacos on a steamer (not a grill) so tHey're soft & succulent instead of greasy or crispy. If you're an organic hipster who
 has to have sprouts & lettuce on a whole wheat tortilla, then this place is not for you (try La Taqueria up on Mission @25th).  BUT! If you like Homestyle Mexican tacos just like Mom used to make, then give La Cumbre a try. Don't forget to taste the Horchata. While waiting, you can gaze upon the large painting of La Adelita (Mexican Flag With Cleavage). But beware:.  La Cumbre is definitely addictive.
author: Lucia M.

description:
After seeing this place on "Man Vs. Food", AND being a favorite place of one of my favorite bands (The Ramones), I had to finally give this place a go. 
The Pollo/Steak combo burrito was amazing. So damn good. My favorite place when I am visiting San Francisco!
author: Rick Y.

description: The food isn't as good as it's hyped up to be. The servers were rude and very standoff. I overheard the Cook say that the carne asada will be ready in 5 min (and it was), but the lady making my taco said "No more carne asada tonight. No more! We have chicken or pork only..." The only good thing about this place was the Cook who stepped in and told the server "it will be ready in 5 min," and he apologized and was actually very nice -- he gets 5 stars. It's quite obvious the night crew servers are lazy and not happy.... maybe they should find a new job.
author: Merlino T.

description:
The food is pretty standard for taco shops these days. Being from San Diego, my taco shop standards are quite high. The food is pretty good and quite fresh. I had a carne asada burrito which had some nice features that are not too common - beans and rice, lettuce, for example. On the other hand, like many other cost conscious places, the guacamole isn't just avocados - it's cut with (probably) sour cream. I hate it when places do this and I therefore can't bump up the rating to a 4. Prices are reasonable, the staff is really nice, and they have a lot of tasty meat selections, but that kind of guacamole is just not acceptable. Take a lesson from Chipotle and offer some great guacamole - I'll pay more for it!

Oh, and the horchata is fantastic!!
author: Topher W.

description:
Yeah- my review.. this particular one may be a tad biased.  Just a tad.

Here's why-

- I walked over an hour (30+ blocks) for Jay's Cheesesteaks, also in the Mission District BUT the damn place was cash only.  I did not want to incur fees by using the ATM machine plus I did not see an electrical outlet so I can charge my phone so I was miffed off ; I decided to go to where Adam Richman visited (host of Man vs. Food aka my future husband)
- plentiful seating
- accepts Visa/MC
- friendly service (the girl that rang me up was cute and welcoming)
- fast ass service
- I got my burrito before entirely viewing their massive bulletin board menu
- one negative: SPICY salsa was so NOT spicy (maybe they gave me "white people spicy")
- carne asada was TENDER.. and I mean EXTREMELY TENDER
- before I forget, I ordered the all meat burrito (no beans and no rice) but I did add sour cream to it but unfortunately they gave me sour cream on the side.. seriously.. I want it INSIDE my burrito!  
- I sat for some time whilst responding to texts, taking pictures of my food and its surrounding, and making sure I get my battery to at least 50% before heading out for desserts: Hot Cookie

I would come back here just for their carne asada.
author: Tram N.

description:
I love the fierce loyalty the fans and locals have for their burrito/taco shops, but sadly most if not all have never had burrito's/tacos and Mexican food all across the country to really know regional differences in marinade, tortilla, rice, beans, condiments, even style of guacamole. I consider my Mexican food palate refined as I've been to over 200 shops in 8 states on both sides of the border and even though I went here late and after heavy drinking it was overall a sad state of affairs for Northern California Mexican food let alone the San Francisco Mission Style burrito.

Taqueria La Cumbria, home of the mission style burrito. What is a mission style burrito you ask? Well I looked it up online and it's a large flour tortilla wrapped in foil and filled with rice, beans, meat, and other condiments like guacamole, sour cream and eaten by unwrapping the foil slowly as you go down and pouring salsa with each subsequent bite. If you've never been and are a bit more mainstream this Chipotle. The flour tortilla is a west coast thing.


With that being said I didn't enjoy the carne asada, I loved how it was fresh cut to order, but not fresh cooked, it didn't have that sizzle off the grill freshness and the flavor was forgettable. The salsa's were ok, but the flavors didn't differentiate and or pop and the fresca was bland. The burrito overall was lacking in that each of the flavors were ok, but the melding and the flavor in each bite left me regretting not getting adobada or using a hotter salsa. The guacamole was the thicker kind with no noticeable lemon and no visible cilantro/onions

Like most shops in the area they were open late night, so I did go here after hitting up some nightlife and yes it was packed, a good sign. I should have gone the extra mile, literally and gone to La Taqueria, which apparently I hear make a larger rice less mission style burrito.
author: Walter M.

description: Helpful service and great portion sizes of good food. Chicken burrito especially was good.
author: Ash W.

description:
It gets 3 because I enjoyed my shrimp quesadilla but my hubby was sadly disappointed. 
Hubby's parents are from Mexico and his mom cooks some amazing food that leaves me 10lbs heavier every time we go back home, we also live in Austi Tx where wonderful authentic Mexican is everywhere.
I got the shrimp quesadilla and although there was too much cheese for me I really loved the sauce they put in it with the shrimp. I thought it was pretty good.
Hubby got the burrito from man vs. food and was very disappointed. He said he didn't understand how a burrito with so many things on it could taste like nothing. 
He said he prefers Chipotle burritos hands down.
author: Tazia S.

description:
The BEST burritos come from La Cumbre!!!

I have been a customer at La Cumbre for years & I go back for so many reasons...  

Their food is delish!!  I really love their veggie burritos wrapped in Spinach tortilla, their Deluxe Nachos, or their regular Chicken Tacos.  Lover is a loyal fan of their Carne Asada, in her Delux Burrito or on Super Nachos.  They serve wholesome, authentic, fresh food. 

Their Salsa Verde is PERFECT, made with the right amount of cilantro & onions.  Then they have a refreshing, mild, red salsa with baby cubes of avocado, another one just the same minus the avocado, a regular red sauce perfect with tacos, and of course Pico de Gallo, mild (without Jalepenos) and hot (with Jalepenos).  They also have Jalepenos, raddish, corn etc... in the Salsa bar, but believe me, everything in this tequeria is amazingly delicious & succulent.

Their customer service is quick & friendly (they are extra polite to me since I visit them so frequently!)

Tacos = $2.5 Veggie = $1.99
Burritos = $5-7
Nachos = $4 - 7
Dinners with beans, rice, salad = $10 - 14

They are not only my favorite tequeria in San Francisco, but they serve exactly what I crave when I think Mexican!!!!
author: Amethyst Popkiss A.

description:
Honestly, I didn't see a big difference in this taqueria compared to taqueria next to my house in Rodeo.  Their meat is precooked, but in small batches because there's a little grill next to the meat.  They have a pretty good salsa bar.  I got a super burrito which has everything including guac and some chips for 8 dollars.  With a big can of arizona the bill was 10 bucks. Kind of expensive for a burrito that tastes like everywhere else.  The rest of the menu items were expensive.  And what the hell, no tripe tacos? (it didn't show on the menu) I got the lengua (tongue) and the meat was tasty. 

One thing that was disappointing was the lack of real and fresh aguas frescas.  They had horchata but it was made in one of those machine thingies and probably from a package.  I'd say pass up this place and go to ANY OTHER cheaper taqueria near by.  There's like 50 of them.
author: Meena N.

description:
First off, the service was crappy. They were not attentive or concerned. Just ready to get you in and out. With THAT said, we are from Texas and were taking a road trip and decided to stop here because of Man v. Food. My sister went in and asked how the meters worked and if we were in the right parking spot, and the girl at the front looked at her like she was a moron. My sister clearly said she wasn't from here and the girl at the counter said "Well that's for delivery." and shrugged. Didn't even suggest to my sister where to park or help out in any way. We eventually found a parking garage around the corner and walked to this place in the rain (we bought umbrellas though). While ordering our food, it seemed like they just wanted us to hurry up even though no one was behind us. Must be a San Fran thing though because they have so many people to get through during a day. Seemed like the cooks/servers were constantly flirting with each other and not paying attention because I didn't even get my cheese in my burrito like it said. She nodded when I asked her if she put cheese in there, even though I didn't see any. 

The food however, was delicious. It was much better than Chipotle and thats the only place where I've had such a stuffed burrito (and Chipotle is my favorite place to eat as well). My son had a quesadilla which was HUGE but he was happy with it. My sister ordered the Carne Asada and special ordered enchiladas for her son. She wasn't very happy with her food in the end though and kind of bummed because it was her idea to come here. I LOVED my burrito and ate almost ALLLL of it which is very rare for me. 

The prices were adequate and affordable. If I'm ever in San Fran again, I'll come back.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Great they are open late night when no one else is but their burritos are flavorless.

I've been here on a few occasions and it always seems the the pico is watered down and the burritos are always blahh.

Not a bad spot if you are starving and drunk and want to wait in line with a bunch of college kids and bro's but I would rather wait and make a pb&j at home.

But the staff behind on the counter seems pretty tolerant with what they are dealing with which is good for them, because I would be spitting in peoples food if I had to deal with the late night crowd that comes in.
author: Diana D.

description:
Apparently I did a poor job of judging Adam Richman's reaction when he ate the burrito here. He made it look so good, but it turns out he just did a good job of fooling me.

I tried the Deluxe carne asada burrito, and fortunately I ordered it wet. If it wasn't for the sauce, the burrito would have been too dry. Even with all of the ingredients, it just lacked flavor. Had the carne asada been good, the burrito could have been saved, but alas, the meat was too tough. I had read some of the reviews here prior to going, and some said the meat was tender and some said it was tough. I went with hopes of getting the tender meat, but it wasn't meant to be.

Adam, you got a lotta splainin' to do.
author: Ken K.

description: La Cumbre is now one of my all time favorite Mexican joints, they pack a good amount of proteins in my usual Steak Prawn Quesadilla Suiza. So delicious!
author: Jess C.

description:
It was better at one time, but I still like to come here for the occasional burrito. I'd have given it four stars instead of three, but feel they overcharge the price between a super and a special burrito. The super basically has about two tablespoons of lettuce and a split tomato slice, which isn't worth the additional charge. If I had known, I wouldn't have ordered the super.

I think the meat tastes good -- we almost always order steak; the additions are tasty too. This is a neighborhood place, and I think it fits the neighborhood.
author: Mark D.

description: This place has changed tremendously over the years. The first time I came here - about 1985 - this was the place to get the massive tortilla-wrapped stomach torpedo full of delicious carne asada or even cow tongue .... mmmmm. They had salsa in squeeze bottles, and it really was the only meal you needed to eat for like 24 hours. Fast forward 3 decades; the neighborhood is completely different, and the restaurant has updated quite a bit as well. A salsa bar replaced the squeeze bottles, there is an admittedly cheesy boasting statement muraled on their storefront, and flat screens show the menu. But still it's a great value, and I appreciate the updated menu. I tried the grilled vegetable plate tonight and highly recommend it!
author: Galen R.

description:
After reviewing this restaurant over 1 year ago, I am updating my review giving this place  4 stars! I ordered a Delux chicken burrito with everything and the chicken was cooked and marinated to perfection.

The only down fall I had today was that there was only one lady making the burritos with a line over 14 people It was very hectic to say the least. 

Another thing is the restroom. There is no sign that says that people need a key to get in the bathroom so I had seen over 3 people walk to the bathroom door wait and then realize after 5 or more minutes of waiting they needed a key to get in! oh no!

SUGGESTION:  please put a sign at the door that tell your customers they need a key to get in the bathroom. 


Other than that I WILL suggest this place to friends. They have improved there recipes I'm sure, I can taste it!!!!

And the service although was hectic with the large line and one lady making the burritos WAS VERY FAST! 

good job taqueria la Cumbre!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
The food here is amazingly delicious. Well to be totally honest, I guess I really mean "If I've ended up here it's likely I'm fairly intoxicated and at that point any food is likely to taste amazingly delicious."

So I guess the four stars is more for the fact they're open until 2AM daily? Yea, that sounds about right. 

Plus I saw TLC (I'm not talking about the hip hop trio, this is short for Taqueria La Cumbre) on 'Man vs Food' so it MUST be good right? The Travel Channel does not lie.

Huge convenience factor with TLC being on Velencia in a thicket of bars (Valencia/Mission/16th St) and close to multiple public transit options.

So is the food really amazing? I honestly can't recall... yes? I just remember being much happier with tacos from TLC floating around in my liquid filled stomach. I'd say that means yes, I'm a fan.
author: Justin N.

description: With myriad options in SF for good Mexican street food, why you ask, would I give La Cumbre 5 stars? I used to be a La Taqueria loyalist, then it was Farolito. Now, when I'm in the City or in San Mateo, I choose La Cumbre because of the quality of their food. Yes, you can get a basic burrito anywhere in The Mission but their ingredients are inferior. I like that La Cumbre's meats and seafood are of high quality. I had their potato flautas last night at a Pajama themed charity event and they were delicious. I even like them more now that I know that the folks at La Cumbre are do gooders too!
author: vinney a.

description: Give me all the veggie burritos! My boyfriend and I are on a quest to find the best burrito in the city and I think La Cumbre might be the best so far.  I've been there before where the staff has had to redo a burrito 4 times to get the right one, but the burritos are so good that I don't really mind how the staff is (especially when making burritos on a Friday or Saturday night when it's crowded with inebriated fools).  Best place to grab a veggie burrito after the bars in the mission.
author: Amber G.

description: Ever since I saw this place on Tv I wanted to visit. I was In San Fran following my Dodgers Once we got back in our hotel I looked it up to see how far it was. It was only about a mile and a half and knowing San Fran traffic and parking we decided to walk there. That was the best decision we made. We got their and ordered their signature burrito which is not for the small stomach. Their green salsa was delicious there was just enough for my burrito. When we were done we could barely move.
