We did not want to walk back to the hotel but glad we did. Burrito was amazing will visit next time I'm in the Bay.
author: Adam G.

description:
Wasnt really impressed by this place ... The workers were nice but the food wasnt really good the meat in carne asada pollo burrito were dry ..the rice was kind of hard and the black beans werent cook all the way through ...the carne asada plate meat was dry.
Pastor taco dry and mole was so so ..salsa and chips were good but thats not what we came for... really disappointed .. especially when it took us 20 mins to find parking walk 4 blocks to destination.. wouldnt go there again ... taco trucks in los angeles serve better food ..
author: Elena M.

description:
Pretty damn good when you're drunk AF after bar hopping in the area.

Had the garlic shrimp and steak burrito and all I remember is that the shrimp was amazing but the steak was tough and chewy. I didn't like that there was a man in there with a guitar walking up to people asking for money either.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: The food and the owner alike will leave you with a terrible taste. Feel free to read his replies to reviews, where he accuses customers of sexual harassment and being racist just for providing honest feedback. Bottom line, the establishment cannot improve if management is hostile and in denial that food is WAY subpar. I have given them a try a couple times and each has been the same experience: not so clean restaurant, rude employees, and stale food
author: Christina M.

description:
This place is over-rated. Just because it was on the Food Network doesn't mean it's good. They use Costco canned chicken That's just not right! 

It's cool that the super burrito originated here, but there are plenty of other taquerias and other Mexican restaurants in the city that are far more superior.
author: Alan A.

description:
There was a time in my life where I ate at Taqueria La Cumbre so much that I actually didn't crave it anymore. That was years ago and I'm back for more.

I came here last night with the ladies after our workout for dinner. We wanted something inexpensive and convenient. One chicken asada super taco with chips and a small Jamaica drink did the job and under $7.00. The chicken was awesome and freshly grilled. 

I'm glad to be back La Cumbre, I missed you.
author: Rebekah T.

description: My husband really hyped this place up because of man vs food. I have had way better burritos. The horchata was delicious, and the beans were great. No impressed.
author: Connie M.

description: On our way to spending an afternoon drinking beer and eating mission style burritos in the park, I picked up a steak burrito at La Cumbre.  The burrito was enormous and overall was very good, but the real issue was the steak was overcooked which was a pretty big bummer.  I could tell from one bite that when these folks are at the top of their game, their burritos are probably second to none, but my one experience landed me with a deliciously filled burrito that happened to have a layer of tough steak.  Again, I do honestly feel just from the rest of the burrito that this was a bad luck experience, and I do think that if I ever have another shot at it, the mistake will not be duplicated.
author: Michael K.

description: The food is goooood very good. It was my second time here after seeing it.on the food network...The had the steak super nachos...it was huge... The grl who took the order was not friendly... Not a plus at all..
author: Sarah A.

description: Carne asada burrito was fantastic. I may or may not have been heavily intoxicated. Whatever. They have free chips and a great salsa bar. Possibly my favorite burrito joint in the mission.
author: Myles P.

description: The place is pretty but the workers look unhappy!!! There very cheap withy the food they measured out the meat and the chips!!! And the cashier decided to spray windex in the glass that separates the food!!! Which for me was a big NO NO!!! I recommend you to skip this place
author: Ana M.

description: Ya I came trying to get a burrito and it tasted like crap, it got me so sick that I had to leave and threw up in the parking lot.  I don't know who the owner is but he should pay attention to the yelp reviews and improve the quality of the food. I recommend going around the corner to pancho villa.
author: Jarrad N.

description: This used to be my favorite Mission Taqueria, now it's one of my least favorite.  Over the course of the last two years, the prices have steadily increased while the portions have decreased.  They seem to be trying to cater to the new, moneyed demographic in the neighborhood, but are failing miserably.  They, for example, installed ridiculous electronic menus that serve no purpose but to strain your eyes.  Do yourself a favor and walk to the Cancun around the corner on Mission St.  I'm giving it two stars only because I have had, in the past, many many great meals here.  But those days are long gone.
author: Christopher F.

description:
Went because of Man vs. Food.
I'm a huge fan of super burritos. so it's cool to go to the birthplace and all. But that's just it for me.
It's decent food but not worthy telling your friends about. dang it.. is it worth writing a yelp about?
I like Gordo's better. First mexican food I've had in the mission. i need to do more exploring but got start somewhere..
author: Dennis A.

description: First off, as a longtime San Franciscan I believe in supporting longtime shops and restaurants. With so many negative changes in our city over the years, I take comfort in retuning to places that I love. I've been coming to La Cumbre for decades. Back in the 80s it was the BEST steak burrito in The City. I used to often travel from the western reaches of San Francisco all the way to The Mission just to partake in one of their delicious, succulent burritos. There were lines out the door for the place. Flash forward to today and I find La Cumbre to be a sad, faded imitation of what it once was. The other day I walked in, the place was nearly empty and the food looked like it had been sitting around all day. No meats on the grill. Only old meat getting cold in the bins. I had a sad, cold poorly made, bland burrito. I could not finish it, it was below mediocre. It was simply terrible. I don't know if the place went through an ownership change over the years, but they used to take such pride in the place, such pride in the quality of the food. It was fresh. The meats were cooked fresh and served hot. That is now all long, long gone. The whole attitude of the joint is sad now. I'll not be back again.
author: Bob S.

description:
Take the hangover of new year's eve and add the excitement of getting delicious mexican food, add them together and you will have a giant pile of disappointment waiting for you.  I had the worst quesadilla of my life that morning...and I once had a quesadilla that put me out for days thanks to some ferocious bacteria living inside.

We went here on New Year's day because it was the only Taqueria open...probably the only way they get business.

How do you say gross in Spanish?
author: Andrea L.

description: Ive waited to go here for a long time and i dont know if it was anticipation or the burrito i got, but it was just another taqueria to me. I live in the east bay and we have places out here that have better burritos. I will say that their meat was really good though. But overall...nothin special.
author: Jeremy Y.

description:
I completely forgot that La Cumbre was featured on MAN vs. FOOD.  La Cumbre supposed to have been the birthplace of Super Mission-Style Burritos in San Francisco.

Here's Man vs. Food at La Cumbre on You Tube:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a0JMYH-Y9N8

Well, I didn't go to La Cumbre for the burritos but to get some TORTAS.

And La Cumbre can proudly claim the honor of popping my torta cherry. Never had torta before ("hiding in shame" )  considering my guy's  Latino. (But what am I saying--I know more Spanish words than he does.)

Anyway, I had the CHICKEN TORTA http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=verfJGccjt0B96jSAKT-5g and got BF the PORK TORTA. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=APvZ0XNvYmiy6L4Yz9VDdw   I know I'm a torta newbie but my chicken torta was delicious. (BF enjoyed his pork torta, too.) The chicken between the bun was tender with the charbroiled smokey taste to it.  

The friendly Latina server gave me a thumbs up for ordering everything on it--sour cream, refried beans, etc.  Well, as Carlos Mencia says--"Filipinos are beaners of the Asian culture."  True, at least in my case.

 We watched the episode of Man vs. Food again while savoring our tortas with a side of Deluxe Nachos! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/iEbNZymY3kEbPG7wP1i19w?select=BjtX5vHy6tUQjapUS0Lo9g Yey, I was there today!!  (I'm such a sucker for places to eat featured on TV!)

Torta=$5.50 each. SUPER-CHEAP, BIG A**, LOADED MEXICAN SANDWICHES!
author: Leah E.

description: Went there last Friday June 26, 2015 for 1 REG steak Burrito and 1 Corona almost $15.00 dollars! Never again! after 33 years of going there-I'm going around the corner from now on for 1 SUPER steak burr and 1 corona for cheaper
author: Sergio C.

description:
Haven't been here in ages, but I used to eat at least 1 carne asada burrito (super) per day, all through the 80's when I lived near bye. Throughout the 90's, when visiting the city, we always made a pit stop at La Cumbre. Anytime family in the city was coming to visit me, they would bring me a La Cumbre burrito. 

Fast forward to the 2000's and being stuck in Las Vegas. Whenever friends come to town, they know I'll pick them up at the airport and take them to their hotel, for a price! La Cumbre steak burrito and a loaf of sourdough! I miss these two things the most. And they ALWAYS bring them for me! 

I can promise, whenever I get back to the city to see home, I will stop at La Cumbre. It's just too good of a memory in my mind for over 30 years.
author: Larry F.

description: I enjoyed my carne asada burrito very much and they are open quite late. My buddy got a plate meal and seemed to enjoy that as well. I'll come back sometime and take better notes but for sure this is a good spot especially for late night eats :)
author: Christopher Steven O.

description:
Love, love this taqueria... The first time I came here, I was probably around 7-8 years old. My Mom would bring me here every weekend for a big fat carne asada burrito all for little old me.

Times have changed and so has my palate... and although I have had better burritos in other taquerias (*cough* Mariela's *cough*), there is something about La Cumbre that touches my soul and keeps me coming back.
author: Julie B.

description:
nacho cheese fries!!!!!!!  shut up your face!!
+friendly staff
author: anna c.

description:
Post a day of Dolores Park sun bathing, what better to do than have Mexican food in the Mission?  Nothing! 
 
So, like the 537 other people who have already reviewed Taqueria La Cumbre, my friend and I came here thanks to Man vs. Food.  I was weary - it only had 3 stars, and there are so many 4 star places within a stone's throw...
 
But, we decided to risk it anyway. 
 
To start with, the service was less than friendly.  Yes, we came about 15 minutes before closing time, and I understand that can be annoying, but we only ordered burritos.  We weren't staying for hours, luxuriously eating an extravagant meal and holding up their evening.  Also, I KNOW the staff must speak and understand enough English to be able to answer a question or two about the food...but they pretended not to. 
 
I was debating the super veggie burrito ($6) and something with shrimp or salmon ($9 - $10), and ended up going for the super veggie - beans, rice, cheese, guac, pico de gallo, sour cream.  My friend got the same, but with some sort of meat.
 
So, we sat down, ready to eat our burritos.  I got up to ask the girl behind the counter for a knife to cut my burrito in half:
 
"Excuse m-"
 
"CLOSED!"
 
"I just need a knife to cut my burrito."
 
She pointed to the silverware off to the side of the register. 
 
Anyway, the burrito was really nothing special.  The beans didn't have much flavor, I couldn't taste the salsa or guac at all...my friend said his burrito was just okay too.  We both ate half of our respective burritos, took the other halves home, and let them rot in the fridge before adding them to the compost.
 
A definite must NOT try.
author: Ashley M.

description: I visited this place for the first time on June 27th for dinner after seeing it on man vs food. I had the carne asada Super Burrito, which was just ok, nothing special. The lady who made it was not friendly at all. Then at the register as I was getting ready to pay I ordered a soda and asked if it comes with chips, as I saw the chips in the bin next to the register. He put some in my basket, but never said there's an extra charge. Later when I checked my receipt I noticed a $1.00 MISC charge. I would not go back here again.
author: TBird M.

description: Pretty good burrito but awesome service. Great people running the restaurant here.
author: Isaac R.

description: I could have just ordered wrong, i'll definitely start with suggesting that. I got the shrimp taco and the fish taco. Unfortunately they were overflowing to the point that i literally could not pick them up to eat them. I tried and was a met with wet guac and everything spilling out. You have to either eat half with a spoon first so you can pick it up, or eat all of it that way. The crappy part is that with a taco, I want to taste all the components together. Besides that, there was very little flavor in them. Would have loved some spices of some sort and some salt and pepper even. Walked 1 1/2 mile to get there. Bummer. Pancho Villa around the corner was 100% better. I'm a visitor but when I was in town and there last time it was amazing.
author: shana s.

description: Ordered Nachos with Chicken after bar hopping with my friend.  It was just okay. Their chips are store bought and not made by the restaurant.  I have had better nachos somwehere else.
author: Claudine V.

description:
La Cumbre is my go-to for a delicious, reasonably priced burrito. I eat there at least three or four times a week and have never been disappointed with my meal. The quality of the meat is much better than that of certain other burrito places in the neighborhood and the atmosphere is much friendlier than the trendy, outrageously expensive places posing as authentic Mexican and Latin American food up the street. I get the grilled chicken and it is always so tasty.  The salsa is always fresh. A really great meal costs under ten dollars. The staff is gracious and kind. You'd be hard-pressed to find this kind of stellar service from other burrito places in the neighborhood.

I have been going to La Cumbre for over 25 years and have never had a negative experience. These people will make every effort to get things right. They have never gotten anything wrong with my orders, but I have seen them handle crowds and complicated orders with grace and compassion. They will treat you well and your food will taste great. It's a great spot to get a quick and delicious meal without a lot of hassle and complication. I also know that they do orders for special events, so if you are planning a party or hosting people for a game or whatever, they could save you a lot of trouble by doing the cooking for you.

Newcomers might be interested to know that La Cumbre has been a neighborhood institution since 1967.  So many people have walked through here and called it home - famous baseball players, famous musicians - several of them have left mementos which adorn the walls. It is a place rich with stories and you can really feel that vibe as you are sitting there.  For all of us who have been in the neighborhood for decades, it's been a part of our own story too; its reliable food and comfortable atmosphere have seen us through many a late night movie outing, helped us get that first date off the ground or fortified us before our favorite bands played at clubs that no longer exist today. I hope the younger generation just coming to the Mission will have as many great conversations inside those walls as we have had. Our neighborhood has weathered many changes but  La Cumbre lives on. When a restaurant lasts more than forty years, you've got to know they're doing something right!
author: Heidi-Jane S.

description: Perfect burrito the way it's supposed to be made (meaning with lettuce, rice, beans,sour cream, etc.). Saw on TV that this was the original SF spot for burritos so we had to try it and we were not disappointed. Watching the lady cram so much food into the tortilla I didn't think she would be able to close it but somehow she rolled the burrito perfectly!  If you are visiting from out of the area you definitely need to stop by and see how real burritos are made.
author: Duane C.

description: Not a great experience, ordered a Shrimp taco, shrimp was so over cooked and had zero flavor. They charge $4 for a small side of guacamole!!! Will not be back.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I too saw this on Man VS Food. And quite frankly its really good. 

Yeah, it's a basic Taqueria setting & whatnot but the meat is so juicy & fresh it's amazing.... 
I love this place & try to hit it up every time I'm in the city.
author: Vanessa X.

description:
burrito inventors or not, these are by far the worst nachos (w/ stingiest portion size) i've ever had in california.

- no real guac (watered down fake green bs)
- no real cheese (it's cheez whiz or some other plasticky cafeteria cheese)


seriously? you're a taqueria in SF. get it together. never coming back here again.
author: Money M.

description: I would give it 5 stars but they asked me around 4:00pm if I wanted the lunch special and when I got to the counter they said no longer a lunch special. The Wednesday special was amazing tho. It was a chili reno with a kick to it. It came with beans and rice and a hot home made tortilla. Mmmmm, the salsa bar was good too. A+ on quality and price. They just forgot what time it was, I get it... I will be coming back soon.
author: Jess C.

description: I have eaten at LA cumbre since 1984 and I still think it is by far the best Mexican food in the Bay Area.... And the people are super friendly in top of it.... Joe
author: Joe O.

description: It's in the hood but don't worry it's still safer than LA. The food is really good and this is a real Mexican spot where you get home style flavor! a must stop if you're in the area!!
author: Adrian S.

description: I love this place and go quite frequently. My office is in the Mission so we've tried nearly every taqueria nearby, and La Cumbre is my favorite! Great, fresh food with excellent service and they keep the place VERY clean.
author: Michael D.

description:
This is my first review in my Vegan the Mission series.

This place has several vegan options, including not just the typical rice, beans, salsa taco or burrito, but a "fajita veggie" burrito (which I've had twice and which is really good, thus the four stars) and a fajita/felafel burrito, which somehow seems very San Francisco multicultural. Friendly service and no language barrier.

Prices quite reasonable for vegetarian items.

I'm definitely adding this to my list. 

Disclaimer: I'm a don't ask don't tell vegan, so cannot guarantee vegan-ness of these items.
author: Charles B.

description:
This is the best burrito in San Francisco. It's so filling, cheap, fresh... delicious. All other burrito establishments in the area are inferior to this one. 

If you disagree, you are wrong.
author: Jay S.

description:
After a night out with some friends, we were craving some Mexican food and pretty much went to the first place we saw. 

Damn... we should have yelped this place before we decided to come here.

My friends and I ordered:
1. All beef burrito
2. Deluxe nacho 
3. Cheese quesadilla with salsa
4. Plain nachos with cheese 

What was wrong:
1. My friend could not chew through the tortilla... beef was WAY overcooked (couldn't chew through that either)... did not come with guac or salsa or sour cream.. was about $9  Direct quote from my friend: "It tastes like sh*t"
2. Deluxe nachos came with cheese, guac and salsa I believe. Guac was freakin RUNNY. Chips were stale.
3. Cheese quesadilla with corn tortilla was just sad. Cheese had no flavor, the tortilla was only 4 inches in diameter, salsa was blah... I guess you get what you pay for.
4. Plain nachos- STALE

STAY AWAY!!   YELP other places close by!
author: sophia l.

description: Falafel Burrito.  Beans, sour cream, cucumber, salsa, (rice?), and of course falafel.  A little on the dry side, definitely on the carb-heavy side, but a tasty alternative to the traditional burrito.  I would have preferred the falafel be made fresh rather than heated in the microwave, but this got the life flowing back through me after a long and crazy day.
author: Alana K.

description: This place is apparently the origin of the Mission-style burrito. That being said I still wasn't too into their food. It was definitely better than most taquerias in the area, but it wasn't like I was making a big fanfare or anything...
author: Jennifer P.

description: This is one of the major Mission-style burrito taquerias in the City, but it's not my favorite of the bunch.  It's still solid, though.  You will get a solid burrito and an authentic Mission experience.  I am happy to go back, but generally won't go out of my way.
author: Scott E.

description: Totally overated!!!!   Food was just OK, very very very bland and very OVERPRICED for the tasteless food they serve!!!  I should have went to 24th, but wanted to try something different.   Last time I'll ever come here
author: Senia F.

description: Great Mexican food  we love this place, if you like all carne  asada burritos. My favorite
author: Ron O.

description:
I know this place was feature on Man Vs. Food and all, but sorry, this place is not very authentic to me. It's kind of all hype in my opinion.

First of all, I don't like places will runny burritos and they put lettuce in theirs. It's like eating a wrapped salad. I like a burrito chock full of stuff so I normally ask for the works but I don't know of any other taqueria that adds lettuce in theirs. It makes it all runny and mushy and that alone will make my stomach turn.

Plus, I'll always stand by places that have legit chips and this place has those stale, store bought ones. Meh. They can do better. Especially being in such a prime location. 

While they have a big menu, I didn't think they had much selection. I remember the last time I went in there they didn't have something I was craving for. Granted, I may have been intoxicated but I made sure to read every line of that menu only to be disappointed.

Prices are okay and the location is convenient when you're hungry after a night out but I think they need to step it up in their cuisine. If you've been to enough taquerias--and if you're in the mission there are plenty of them--you'll notice the difference in quality. I'll take pizza over this place any night, drunk or sober.
author: Kathryn B.

description: Not bad burritos, I liked them but my wife did not care for them. They could use more seasoning for their meat and rice.
author: Ian M.

description:
Worst mexican food I've had in sf. Period.

I was mildly drunk and starving when I went here and it was still bad. When I'm drunk I devour everything in sight. Not this. This was utter sh*t.

SWEET! The dude from Man Vs. Food went here and ate a colossal burrito! I guess that's their selling point, but honestly, with all of the incredible Mexican food in the Mission (arguably the best in the state) why on earth would you go here.

The chicken was coated in BBQ sauce, which turned out to be pretty gross. Don't get me wrong, I sometimes LOVE BBQ sauce in my burrito (I'm looking at you, Freebirds) but this was just BAD. It was uncharred chicken (despite being cooked on a grille) smothered in a foul tasting BBQ sauce. NASTY.

I'd describe the rest of the ingredients in my burrito as "lettuce and tomato", because that's what it was. They SLOPPED lettuce on and sliced tomatos (yes, not pico de galo, SLICED TOMATO). REALLY? Sliced tomatos? I've never had that in my burrito before. It was like they started making a burrito and half way through they were like "f*ck it, let's make a sandwich."

Never going here again!!!!!!!!
author: Gabe P.

description:
Hi Edward,

I am updating my review because I don't seem to have an option to reply directly to your response.

Thank you for your response. I have to say that your staff was embellishing the situation when they were telling you there was a high turnover and the restaurant was packed. The restaurant was far from packed, at best, half of the tables were occupied, and while there may have been people drinking at the nearby bars, there was absolutely no 'off the hook partying' anywhere in your business.

To be clear, we only walked down the street for a couple of stores. We did not enter any other store, and the last place she used her phone was at our table in your restaurant. I remember that clearly. So to answer your question, it is impossible that she left her phone at another store on Valencia. Your restaurant was the only business we entered that night.

Again a discrepancy in the story that your staff is telling you. The waitress herself did offer the use of her phone, but the manager only came out onto the scene, he did not address us directly, and I do not remember him offering his phone to us. I did appreciate the waitress offering her phone for our use.

Of course we are not the first people to lose a phone in SF. I don't think that issue is under debate. We did not demand to call the police. We stated that if they return the phone right then, we would not pursue criminal charges, but if we return home, use the location tracking on the phone, and find that the phone is indeed located in the restaurant, or in possession by the waitress, we would pursue criminal charges.

With regard to your accusations of racism, I feel that you are projecting onto me when you find my review racist. Spiteful? That's up to your judgment, but I never mentioned race in my review, nor did I make any judgments based on race, and I certainly don't consider my statements racist in any sense. I take particular offense in your statement that I said: "It sounds like you are saying that all "Hispanics" are poor and steal.", because I most surely did not say anything of that sort.

An iPhone is an expensive piece of hardware, and would be tempting for anyone of any economic status, race, or gender. As an aside, there are actually many people who are financially well off who still commit theft, so I don't think I am implying that people steal because they are poor.

I was going to abstain from responding and just move on, but I felt that your accusation of racism warranted a response. I am not racist, and I feel strongly offended when I am accused of being racist. I have experienced discrimination based on race before and I certainly do not intend on putting someone else through that same experience.

Lastly, I was not impressed by your food before losing the phone. Perhaps you will not believe me, but I would not have been kind in my review to your business even if we did not lose a phone there.

I wish you the best with your business, but I will not be a future customer. This is not an underhanded request for special treatment, just how I feel. There are plenty of taquerias in the area that I feel are better value for my money.
author: Innie K.

description:
I've read a number of reviews of La Cumbre that diss the grilled chicken, or some dish that the reviewer didn't particularly like.  This misses the point.  You're there for the burritos, or the plates.

I stopped in two days ago for the lengua plate, and loved it.  I live in New York nowadays, and don't get any variety of Mexican food that really satisfies.  I get my fix when I come back to SF, and this meal at La Cumbre was more than satisfaction.  When I lived in the Duboce Triangle, this place was a standby - it's good to see that they're still doing well.  The plate was well-flavored, hearty and possibly most importantly, full.

I notice that several reviewers have cited some Andrew Zimmern Food Network episode.  Note to them:  the place existed a long time before some producer came up and asked if they could film there.  It's going strong, just as it has been since the early 1970s, and it's well worth a visit if you happen to be in the Mission.  It's just a block away from the BART stop, by the way.
author: Darren S.

description:
Let's be frank: This place is gross. They use cheez whiz on their nachos. When i told them that that was not real cheese, they kept trying to tell me it was: "It's 100% cheese." What the hell? I had to physically point out the shredded cheese that they use in their burritos to show them what real cheese is. 

Cheez whiz is ghetto. I am never going back here again, ever.
author: Caitanya M.

description:
Unfortunately I have not had a good experience here ever since I saw the Man Vs. Food episode that made me notice this place. 

-The service is rude, inattentive, and unhappy. Specifically the blondish woman that's usually at the cash register.
-There are mice. Yes I saw one scurry about the floor and hop into a hole. Also if you walk towards the bathroom you can see a small hole in the bottom left corner next to the bathroom door that is clearly a rodent hole. 
-The food is just alright. The carne asada burrito was nothing special at all, hardly the flagship Mission-style burrito" as it was touted on Man Vs. Food. 

Go to Taqueria Pancho VIlla, cleaner and better food.
author: Egan B.

description:
Had friends in town and they wanted to come here (they caught the MVF episode that featured La Cumbre). 

We were all standing around in trying to decide what we wanted to order. The lady making the plates started giving us samples of the meats. +1 star! The meats were all amazing, the carne melted in your mouth like butter! +1 star for the meat. 

We were a little loud (had a few drinks earlier) and we were contemplating margaritas, the owner? manager?, Ed came over and offered to make us a batch or 2. He was so friendly and personable. We had a great chat and he let my visitors sign his guitar on the wall. +1 star for Ed! He was awesome! 

Before we left, the staff were already clearing our table. All of the staff were friendly. +1 star for the hospitality and +1 star for the cleanliness! 

Bottom line, the plates were huge, the food was great, the prices were right, and all 4 of us left feeling like it was an overall great experience! 

I will definitely be back!
author: Jenna D.

description:
I love burritos but haven't had it here before.  I ordered two tacos and my buddy Calvin order two.  I had a stomach intestine (it wasn't even on the menu) and al pastor.  The al pastor was kinda fried and crunchy and very delicious, stomach intestine was cooked perfectly and very tender but can use a bit more flavor.  Calvin had two lengua tacos that was absolutely tender and flavorful.  With 2 Medelos, we were set.

Will checkout the burrito next time.
author: Kevin L.

description:
La Cumbre has been pumping out reliably delicious steak burritos since....forever.

woohoo, as good as it gets. the end.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
I grew up 3 blocks away from La Cumbre so I may be a little biased but this is simply the best burrito in San Francisco, (read: the best burrito in the universe).

I don't live on the west coast anymore but every time I visit I stop in and get crazy nostalgic over a carne asada burrito. I even bought their t-shirt and I am not a guy who buys shirts.

La Cumbre IS the mission. The artwork, the tiling, even the giant menu which has been the same since at least the 80's (with new prices taped over the old ones).

What's the expression? Often imitated, never duplicated. Viva La Cumbre!
author: Konstantin G.

description:
I rate a taqueria by its salsas. That's where Pancho Villa rates low on my list, Cancun (the one on Valencia/Mission) rates highest.
La Cumbre is in between and has awesome salsas including the spicy salsa verde and pico de gallo.

I usually get the veggie burrito, am usually sober when I get it ;-) and it's pretty great. Only complaint? Some days they seem to close way too early.
author: What's in a nam e.

description: Falafel burrito!! With the spicy sauces and salsas, I am in burrito heaven! There are so many different things to order! I fell in love with the falafel burrito, so I haven't had the chance to try anything else yet. I really like how you order your burrito and can choose what goes in it while it is being made in front of you. They have really good strawberry margaritas too! And they are cheap!
author: Kylie S.

description:
I can be watching these food channels for like hours and hours and become mesmerized. So I saw this restaurant " Taqueria La Cumbre" on Man vs Food and yes, it was in the Top Eats . I go there after my friend nagggs me about his craving for Mexican Food -- plus I didn't mind anyway. It was one of the Top Eats and it was just a 15 min commute away from my home in San Francisco. As you know, I went there expecting it to be a totally EPIC Mexican food experience. I ordered a super Quesadilla ( a lot of food, I know) and my friend ordered some fish tacos.

1. My super Quesadilla was  bleh. The cheese was not even melted all the way!!!!! So turned off, haha.   The meat was decently marinated, but the ingredients were just not that fresh. Overall I was not pleased. 

2. My friend's fish taco was just not pleasant at all. They microwaved a piece of fried fish they got from somewhere and throw it in a tortilla and threw some sour cream on it. The fish was not fresh and was soggy. Ew. 

The staff were a bit slow and though they saw me waiting, they continued chatting about something for a 3-5 minutes before addressing me. The restaurant is spacious and decently clean ( dont sit near the bathroom) and the food prices are the same anywhere for Mexican food. 

As I walk down the street, after my meal, disappointed and feeling deceived  , I see many more nicer looking Taquerias and even some with more people. Don't think I will be making my way out to this restaurant again. Darn Man vs Food!

I have had much better Mexican Food elsewhere in San Francisco.
author: Alice T.

description:
Aftering watching some MVF, I think my expectations for this place was a bit too high. 

A good note for this place is that it's spacious, allowing you to get some seating while you eat. There's a large variety on the menu but their food is pricey, especially the tacos. 

Having been away from SF for weeks, I was craving some good SF tacos. I ordered one carnitas and one beef soft shelled tacos. The steak was good but the carnitas was kind of dry compared to La Taqueria. Another thing that was disappointing was the fact that there were beans and no onions. The beans just dulled down the flavors of the steak and pork, however they did smother the tacos with a lot of meat. They're about $3 a taco, which is pricey. You get a lot though, but I'd prefer La Taqueria any day.
author: robin w.

description: The Tacos were very good and also the Quesadillas. They had a good salsa bar and the service was great. I wanted to try a shrimp cocktail however the person who prepares the cocktails was not in. It was clean and had plenty of seating. I love that they cook out front and you can see all the choices. the grilled items looked fresh. I would come back for this reason. Guacamole sauce was very good.
author: JC L.

description:
Matt's co-worker, who was around 16th St., called Matt at his office to see if Matt wanted anything from a Taqueria. Matt wanted a Grilled Steak Super-Burrito, but the only question was, "Where did he get it from at the busy midday lunch hours?"

Co-worker bought the Super Burritos from La Cumbre Taqueria. Matt has been to La Cumbre only once many years ago, and wasn't too pleased with their Burrito or Horchata. La Cumbre is quite possibly one of the worst taqueria in the city. 

Matt's Grilled Steak Super-Burrito was small and bland. The Guacamole-paste was inserted into the "silver-bullet" instead of a real avocado. Matt or any of us should never complain about free food, but Matt, who's a hardcore burrito-eater, would rather cough up the money and get a BETTER burrito elsewhere. Out of a hundred taquerias in the Mission District, he chose the worst one.
author: Matt G.

description:
Maybe I ate too much burritos/tacos but I still think La Cumbre is just like any other Mexican restaurant in the Mission.

I have to admit they do cut the meat fresh so I guess thats a plus.

I still dont think this is one of the BEST burrito places as stated by Travel channel and Maxim. But its definitely worth a try.

Also, parking suckssssssssss!
author: Carol Y.

description: Had the beef burrito and a beer. I think it was like ~$13.50. Burrito was sized nicely, it was big and filling and tasted great. If im in the area again I might just try something else.
author: David W.

description: This is where the burritos are best, the prices are low, the vegetables super fresh & the atmosphere authentic. If you are hungry and in the area I can only recommend this Cal-Mex place!
author: Veronica O.

description: I'm not sure why there are so many mediocre reviews. Granted, I've been there exactly once in my life but it was a very, very good burrito. Perhaps I lucked out but it was a great experience.
author: Tony G.

description: Stopped in here to grab a few burritos for the wife and I before heading back to helLA.  Friend(s) insisted.  Apparently this place was on the Food Network.  Loved the salsa bar and their tortillas.  Chicken was cooked perfectly.  Mission apparently has the best burritos on the West Coast?
author: Mot Y.

description:
I've eaten here a few times with a variety of people. Making good food isn't enough after midnight on Valencia, and being open late doesn't slow down business here. They're very quick even when the line gets long. Their lines are run very efficiently with two full burrito-making stations. 

Be aware that they run out of grilled chicken. Regardless you'll see everything being grilled in front of you, so you might change your order if you notice the freshest things on the grill. 

More tables and chairs/stools would really, really help. A couple more table could fit on the floor, I'd guess. Either way, be prepared to order your food to go. Even then you'll be happy you ate here.
author: Mike H.

description:
Don't know what the haters are talking about, but if you're trying to to be a restaurant critic after you've eaten at a place drunk off your ass, please don't.  This place is an SF institution, and for good reason: fresh everything, authentic as hell, and hands down best tacos in the Mission.  

There.
author: Doug W.

description:
Went here with a bunch of friends after watching Adam from Man v. Food get served a 2 lb. burrito that looked amazing. I had very high expectations and to be honest, they were not met. 
Was the burrito good? Yes. 
Would I go back in the near future? Not likely. I ordered the Super Burrito for a hefty $8.25 with half pollo asada and half carne asada. The meat was decent, but the overall taste didn't have that WOW factor that I was looking for in a great burrito.
author: Thomas A.

description:
Damn you Adam Richman!!! 

1 star for being on tv and that's about it........

I saw this place on Man v Food so I thought OMG! It was on tv so it must be good, WRONG!

First thing I noticed was the high prices on the menu but I quickly overlooked that, big mistake. $8.50 for a super burrito, seriously?!? I ordered a carne asada super burrito and I didn't enjoy it at all. I can get a bigger burrito at any random taqueria in San Jose. The carne asada didn't have any flavor and was really chewy. I tried chewing the meat but I had to eventually end up swallowing it whole. They did do me a favor by barely putting any meat in the burrito so I didn't have to force myself to swallow til I gagged. Beans were really bland, same with the rice. I'm no expert with Mexican food but I never had a burrito with lettuce in it(correct me if I'm wrong please) and all the lettuce did was make the burrito that much more bleh! 

I did enjoy the pico de gallo at the salsa bar but I didn't like how I had to load up my burrito with it to try to get some flavor in my mouth.

The only way to describe this place would be "yucky yucky yucky!!!" Yeah I said yucky, it is what it is Taqueria La Cumbre :P
author: Harry T.

description:
Was going to smoke some hukka but wants some food first. ran into this spot randomly.  I remember seeing it on TV. so i was looking forward to something yummy.  Got a super burrito with steak.

Good size burrito was cool they grilled the skin a little longer then normal so its crunchy.  The steak itself in the burrito perfect

How ever not much meat.  so personally not worth the 850 it cost for one.  no one has beaten la tapia in ssf yet.
author: Justin I.

description: AMAZING BURRITO. If you are looking for a quality burrito with quality ingredients and quality service this is your place. (I personally would do a make over of the place itself, but the food is amazing) Boy do they know how to wrap a burrito. Tops Chipotle, which is saying a lot in my opinion!!! Good luck to La Cumbre, they won't need it.
author: Leslie S.

description: I was on my way somewhere else for lunch, but my cab driver mentioned this place was on the TV and he'd been dropping off tourists there all summer.  I immediately asked him to stop!  I didn't read any reviews before ordering, just went ahead and ordered one beef taco and one chicken taco.  Hmm...the flavoring of the meat was just ok to me.  I liked the salsa and all of its flavors.  I thought it was all ok overall. The place was quite smokey too...might be a health risk, hmmm...eh...not sure I would jump out of a cab for it again...
author: Maile N.

description: The food looked exceptionally good.  The flavor was very authentic.  The staff was friendly.  But, that's the end of the good news.  The place is filthy and would not pass health code in NC.  The carne asada, although flavorful, was extremely tough.  However, it was not greasy at all.  The parking meters out front on Valencia only allow 30 minutes maximum.  That's 29 minutes longer than anyone should stay.  The pig stye restroom was scary!  If you want to go there, get your hepatitis shots first
author: Tim M.

description:
Gawd-Dawg, I haven't written a review in forever, I was happy with that, but now television has made me write one again. 

I'm giving La Cumbre 4 stars, that's what it deserves, but I wish I could give it 6 just to make up for the confused food network driven louts are pulling this long established, and generally excellent, taqueria's rating down because they are upset that after going there they didn't feel like they'd just stepped out of their own private television show.

Better meat than most taquerias, generally fairly high quality components.  

They also have both melted jack or 'nacho cheese' of the orange fake variety.  You can ask for both on the same nachos.  Don't be upset, the orange goo is just as 'authentic' as any other cheese, given that San Francisco taqueria food is a hybrid.  This is what I will suggest to the So Cal critics - though at least most appear to have been to a taqueria before, unlike the TV gang.   Orange cheesefood is also very tasty at the right time.

Unfortunately, the salsa bar is less than stellar.  While they have a good selection, the salsas are generally oily in consistency and not particularly flavorful.  The green as always is the best of them. Also, one should appreciate the extra onions and carrots mixed in with the pickled peppers

It's a taqueria, like a dive bar it has rules. You must know what to order.  You mustn't stand around confused and unsure what to order from the person working the burrito line.  Your attempts to impress your friends with your bad high school/vacation Spanish will get an eye roll and hold up the line - you deserve worse.  Try to get your food when the place is busy, it's fresher.  Don't whine that it's not as clean looking as Chipotle.  Most of all, one is at La Cumbre to eat a burrito - do not feel slighted if it's not the same experience you once had a Gary Danko. 

Why would one even view a show called "Man vs. Food", let alone take recommendations for local restaurants from a national cable show?.  Even the title (never mind that host) is a good indication that the whole show is absolutely wrongheaded about food.  If you are fighting with it you are doing it wrong.
author: Gustie L.

description:
This place is good drunk food.  I have never been here while sober.  You have had their burritos and they were very good.  And they have a bathroom, yay! I always get a burrito with no beans and extra sour cream.  So yummy.  I also love that they use veggies, lettuce and tomato, I like some salad in my burritos.

So if you happen to be stumbling down Valencia smelling hot dogs and pizza, but are hungrier than that, go to La Cumbre.  They don't make fun of your drunk ass, and you'll probably know someone there.
author: Meara G.

description:
Considering this place is like a block and a half away  from Pancho Villa, it was hard not to compare the two.  For the record, I like Pancho Villa better.

I got the Super Nachos at La Cumbre with chicken.  Ingredients were fresh, and the chicken was tasty and tender, but there was a ton of cheese, with random huge hunks.  Lots of guacamole but way too much sour cream, a sore spot with me because i specifically said no sour cream...she must not have heard me correctly.

The place is not as clean as I would like, got a nice whiff of urine as I walked through the door, but that's not all their fault.  

Good selection of salsas, and chips were fresh, but I don't think I'll be back again very soon.
author: Grace L.

description:
While stumbling from one bar to another, my friend mentioned that he was hungry, so I suggested we check out La Cumbre. 

I ordered the regular vegetarian burrito with black beans, rice, hot salsa and guacamole. The salsa was pretty good, but the rest of it was a little bland, even in my drunken state. Maybe I should have added more salsa or some fajitas? 

I guess the menu was too gigantic for my inebriated brain to process. I'll update my review when I've visisted this place in a sober state. My apologies until then, TLC.
author: Brandi W.

description: I don't know why this taqueria was ever on man vs food. When I ordered a burrito I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw the guy putting the meat in my burrito, using what looks like the cup you use to measure NyQuil!! He chopped the steak up put the pieces in the NyQuil cup thing and then put it in my burrito! And then what seemed like 3 cups of rice and some cheese and the salsa. I was already thinking in my head WTF is that??!! For the price I paid for this rice burrito I was shocked and extremely disappointed! I bit the burrito and pretty much had a mouth full of tortilla and rice with no meat yet! Never again will I go to this place and you shouldn't either unless you want your meat measured in a NyQuil cup
author: Roger P.

description:
I'm from the East  L.A. area and we have a lot of burritos places here. Honestly a majority are just your basic-average tasting burritos with the exception of some extraordinarily great burritos. So last year i kept hearing about this place called La Cumbre in SanFran. Last summer i went to visit some family in South San Fransico and I had to try it. 

So i finally get there and the service was awful! i ordered i Al Pastor burrito (as i do everywhere else). The lady had an attitude and rushed me even though it wasn't that busy. I finally got my burrito and bit into it and it tasted like an asada burrito. I asked the lady if  she put Al pastor and she gave me that "HOW DARE YOU" look. So i guess that was their Al pastor, it just had no flavor..So that was it? this famous burrito ive heard so much about? it was awful!
As i said before there are a lot of little places in East LA that sell burritos and this burrito would probably be even below average.
Not worth the the trip! The only people i can picture going here more than once is Fanboys and people who have never had a good burrito before.

Oh and it is pretty expensive for what it is. I think they charge you more based on their fame (unworthy of that fame).
author: Jonathan P.

description:
La Cumbre boasts being the creator of the Mission style burrito.  Not sure if it is true but they have good food none the less!

Everything tastes fresh and the service is great.  You can definitely tell they have been doing this for awhile!

Great food in the heart of the Mission!
author: Reggie A.

description:
A- Ok is right. After coming from eating pizza, my friend and I peered inside, only to discover that this was the one and only Taqueria La Cumbre. You know...Man V. Food? Right. Well, turns out this place wasn't all it's cut out to be.

Don't get me wrong. The food definitely hit the spot. Everything you could ask for in late night eats. But I just don't think it compares to other burritos I've had. And from personal experience, I just have higher standards, having spent time in SoCal, that is, where Mexican food there spoiled me to death. 

The  shrimp burrito was HUGE. Just as big as my forearm. It was the Super choice. The tortilla was pretty soft, compared to tortillas slightly more toasted. And there seemed to be so many ingredients in this burrito that it felt like I was digging for buried treasure, searching for those pieces of shrimp. They're not jumbo, that's for sure. And what's the deal with the carrots and unnecessary huge chunks of veggies? Hmm...

Despite the Saturday night fun and the hoard of hipsters all throughout the Mission, La Cumbre was still busy. Service was smooth though. The place is real spacious and has that authentic Mission district vibe. There's plenty of places to sit, so you don't have to wait for people to finish eating. It's just the level of cleanliness you have to worry about. 

If I was back here, I would surely try other menu items. But for Mexican food, burritos are my true go-to food. Fact of the matter is, all that's in a burrito and how it's made tells you a lot. And I think La Cumbre still has some explainin' to do. Nonetheless, it was decent.
author: Will S.

description: Quick and good. I applaud their trap at keeping churros by the register. I fall for the ploy about half the time.
author: Heather R.

description:
Nachos cheese????  fo real??

I wanted some fun, packed nachos.  The lady was setting it up all right... beans, meat blah blah.  Then it happened.  She asked if I wanted "cheddar or white cheese"  The moment I chose cheddar I deeply regretted it.  She walked over to a metal thing plugged into the wall, grabbed a ladle, and started ladling on spoonfulls of thick, cheap, disgusting nacho cheese.  I had two choices: Either ask them to make me a new one with white cheese, or vomit all over them while paying for my food.  I chose the second option.  


Just kidding.  I chose the first.


Yeck!

Then the food was fine.  :/
author: J L.

description: They make fantastic burritos - juicy, cheap, hits the spot.  Doesn't get much better than this!
author: Kristen S.

description:
The best!!!
You must have the Habanero sauce, ONLY AVBL ON FRI AND SAT!!!!
author: Michael S.

description: Went there tonight and the food was great and manager Ed was very accommodating and friendly. We got seconds to go.
author: John D.

description:
Damn good carne asada (steak) burritos.

Stopped in on a weeknight. Usual mission hipster contingent sitting at one of the larger tables. The line wasn't that long, but they do take their time putting the orders together. Not necessarily a bad thing.

I ordered a steak super burrito without guac. It was really good. The steak was fresh off the grill, the lettuce etc included was very fresh. I ate inside the rest because I was planning to chill with a margarita, but apparently they are no longer available even though they are on the wall menu and there is no notification the items are no longer available. I ordered a beer instead and had to go back to the counter to have them use a bottle opener (and ask the woman at the counter twice as she kept indicating to twist it but it wasn't a twist top and the woman who rang me up didn't open the bottle).

Also, the ladies behind the counter don't seem to be into idle chit chat or even that much of pleasantries. Get your food and get going appears to be the rule of the day. As long as they continue to make quality burritos like this, that's perfectly fine with me.
author: Patrice W.

description:
Considering I work in the Mission, I have plenty of choices for a fat and juicy buritto.  

La Cumbre delivers (both SF & San Mateo!) It rocks my palate when the Mexi craving attacks & unlike the grossly overrated Pancho Villa, it doesn't cost $10 for a damn burrito.  

Just my $0.02 for your viewing pleasure
author: Athena S.

description:
I came from Oakland after seeing this place on Man vs. Food. I was very pleased.
I ordered the chicken deluxe burrito with a spinach tortilla and fresh avocado slices instead or their guacamole. I loved it!!!  It was full of flavor and the avocado with the fresh chicken and cheese.... Mmmmm mmm good . 
My bf got the super steak and prawn burrito. His took a bit longer since they had to cook the steak and prawns When he ate it he was in heaven! He ate the whole thing!!! 
The cons of la cumbre are the chips and the guacamole. Chips where stale and guacamole definitely came from a package.
author: Steph S.

description:
My expectations for this place were way to high after seeing it on Man v. Food, so that's why it only gets a 3 Star. 

The food was good (loved that you could mix different meats in your burrito), everything was fresh, and the burrito was a good size for the price. A touch expensive for my tastes ($8+, but that's the price you pay for eating organic) but worth the experience. 

The decor needs a makeover, and they didn't have gift cards to buy. Otherwise, go check it out. The owner is SUPER NICE! So that is a big plus.
author: Riley B.

description: So we saw this place on man vs food and thought it must be good right? It was a normal size burrito not really what I would call a super burrito. Then as we we were walking back to the car we noticed how bad of an area it was in. Like skid row bad. The food was decent but nothing to feature on TV that's for sure.
author: Sara C.

description:
Watching La Cumbre tonight on Man vs. Food reminds me of the good old days. I remember coming here and enjoying the carne asada burrito. It was juicy but also seared just right. I thought it was a good burrito. 

Nowadays I'm a El Farolito man, but watching the episode on TV makes me want to pop in for a visit.
author: Dom L.

description:
4.5 stars!

I usually find myself at La Cumbre after a long night of barhopping in the Mission.  I mean, theres no better way to sober up than to stuff your face with a super Carne Asada burrito... and I will gladly stand in the line that wraps around the restaurant to do so.  

The mini tacos are pretty bomb too!

There's a seemingly endless amount of types of meat you can have in your meal (I don't think I've read all the way to the bottom of the menu).  The meats are cooked fresh right in front of you by some dude who looks like he's been doing it forever and the burritos/tacos are put together as you pick everything you want in it.  To wash it all down, they've got beers and Mexican Cokes...AWESOME!! (and some other liquids, too)

The only reason this review isn't 5 stars is because every time I go here, they are out of Al Pastor... one day, Tim, one day....
author: Tim L.

description:
"Cheap huge burritos" is the college student's cry. But the normal burritos were merely normal. It's not bad for $6, but I'm not going to run here when I want a lot of cheap food. The halibut was different and actually really nice, but its $10 charge is a bit painful and not worth it.

All in a all, an OK place for a lot of cheap food. But that's about it.
author: Elben S.

description:
I was fairly unimpressed with this place. After a night at the bars, we headed here for some tasty eats.

Complaints:
-The line. I understand the post-last call rush, but seriously, waiting in line for 20 minutes to get some food? 
-Smoke everywhere! Was something burning? Were we being poisoned?
-Prices. I can get bigger portions of taqueria food in Marin for cheaper. This is the MISSION and I don't care to pay $7 for a burrito when I can get a better one for $5 elsewhere.
-Taste. My burrito was good. But not fantastic. And I was even drunk.

Was going to be two stars, but I tacked one on because I reheated leftovers and it tasted better sober and day-old than it did drunk and fresh. That says SOMETHING, although I'm not sure WHAT.
author: Natalye R.

description:
I saw this place featured on Food Network's "Best Places to Chow Down" special. I think I left the house immediately after the show aired! Since then, it's become one of my regular spots.

I've had their carne asada super burrito and their enchilada plate. The burrito had a perfect combination/balance of ingredients - not too much or too little of anything. The enchilada plate came with two chicken enchiladas topped with cheese, a side of rice and beans, and alittle lettuce and tomato (I put them on top of my enchiladas because that's how my mom taught me). It's such a delicious combination - the savory flavor of the mole with the crispness of the lettuce, the coolness of the sour cream and the warm fluffiness of the rice...aww, man. I was in heaven.

I have yet to try their tacos, but that's next on my list. What stands out about this place is that they grill the meat right there and chop it up. So literally, as you're ordering your burrito, they are chopping up the steak right in front of you. My husband had their prawn burrito, and being the greedy bastard that I am, I took a bite of his and got burrito envy.

Come to Taqueria La Cumbre - because their burritos make others burritos jealous!
author: Mariela D.

description: I was a huge fan on this place 4 years ago. Not so much anymore unfortunately. The birria taco was too greasy to be fun, and they forgot the beans from my food completely. Lunch companions had equally "meh" experiences for the fish burrito and chicken tacos, so this is a duly deserved two stars exactly.
author: Mikko J.

description: Best burrito of your life. Slightly over priced, get over it.
author: Button L.

description: My favorite spot in the Mission for Mexican food. The steak is my favorite it's always super quick to get your food.
author: Mafia M.

description:
I've been coming here for almost twenty five years now, and even once had the airport shuttle bus drop me off at La Cumbre instead of my apartment on the way back in from out of town.

Their flavors, quality and prices have remained surprisingly consistent all those years too.  Hopefully both it and I will stick around for another 25.
author: Carter S.

description:
I hadn't been to La Cumbre in many years, although I dine all around it, regularly. 
It was 2am, and it was right there. Now I remember why it'd been so long.
First, I had the vegetable burrito. It was bitter and tasted like bad hippy food, from the 70's, old school. I tried to doctor it up with their, good tasting, salsa.
That didn't cut it enough. Oh yeah, it was supposed to be a super
but didn't have any super ingredients. 
I had only taken a few bites, so, in a bold moment,
I asked if I could exchange it for a super veg. They
did give me one, but I felt bad vibes comin my way. 
The super veg was totally bland and nondescript.
To top it all off, I'm lying in bed with a stomach ache, which began shortly after eating.
author: Gee K.

description: Super nachos so super good!!! OMG for the salsa bar!!!  Do NOT get too excited for the $3 margaritas, it's straight up processed sugar!  Instead dig on other yummy calories.. I will come back.
author: Sue K.

description: Got the grilled chicken plate. Flavorful, juicy, but $11 is kind of expensive for what it was.
author: Lilian K.

description: Not the best Mexican food that I've ever had but it's decent. This is definitely  authentic but they doesn't automatically make it top notch. Just like there's a difference in quality between a great burger place and a decent burger place, there's a difference between great authentic Mexican food and decent authentic Mexican food - I'd say this place is decent authentic Mexican food.
author: Caleb C.

description:
This is a good three stars, really if half stars were allowed it would be 3.5. 

Why: 
We came for a late lunch and there was no line, no waiting and we could sit where ever we wanted
Soccer was on the TV
The mom and pop behind the glass were friendly and fast
They cooked my veggies fresh right in front of me
My veggie burrito was huge with decent flavor
The green and red sauces on the salsa bar were awesome

Why not:
The chips were stale
The hot salsa could have been hotter
and the beans could have had a little more flavor

I met friends here one of whom has been coming to this same place for over 20 years and out of 4 of us who all ordered something different there were no complaints. That has to say something about the place! 

Try it for a casual lunch you'll be happy you did!
author: Tuesday C.

description:
Looking at the the August 2009 Maxim, they ranked this place as having the bitchin'est burrito, a football size mission burrito ($6).

When I finally went there today, their super burrito was the size of a regular burrito at the price of $9. After biting into it, there were less meat and other stuff compared to other burritos in the area, just fillers. 

WOULD NOT WASTE MY MONEY COMING HERE. 
There are much better priced and tasting taqueria in the Mission.
author: M C.

description:
Mission style burritos sounds yummy and with a myriads  of options of meat to choose from, sounds even better. Well Not Really!

I saw Adam Richman enjoying a Taqueria La Cumbre Super Burrito on Man vs Food so I thought it must be worth a shot but I was totally disappointed. The meat was bland and absolutely tasteless. The pico de gallo was kind of my savior for the few bites I ate but I had to eventually trash the burrito. Lets not even talk about the texture of the tortilla.
author: En J.

description:
There was a moment - -a split second, really -- where i looked through the sneezeguard at the container of watery, pale green liquid, and thought to myself: "there's no way in hell that's the guacamole; it must be be a tomatillo salsa of some sort."  Nope, I was wrong, and that's the moment that I realized I was in for one hell of an awful burrito experience in the greatest burrito-eating city in the world.  Things quickly went downhill from there, including a strawberry agua fresca that looked and tasted more or less like Kool-Aid.  

Pass.  So many other choices out there...
author: Laurence W.

description:
This place was really good.  My girl and I were strolling around the mission and stopped in.

I'm generally not a huge mexican fan but this was the bomb.  Everything in the burrito tasted pretty fresh.  The portion was huge.  Definatlely a cool little place to grab a corona and a burrito.
author: David S.

description:
This place has the prime location because it is surrounded by some of the most popular bars in the mission. My friends and I were walking out of Delirium when we decided that we absolutely have to get food since we were in the mission. Luckily, Taqueria La Cumbre is open till at least 3am on weekends. At about 2am, when all of the bars close, a huge line starts forming around this place. It took us about 20 min to even get our order in. 

The food was not bad, but it was not amazing. I got the suiza, which was tasty at the time (after a few drinks) but the leftovers the next day were quite bad. I'll probably give this place another try in the future but not that late at night.
author: Kate G.

description: 5 stars for amazing food! I've been coming here for 20 years and it's still the best. Tacos, quesadillas and especially burritos are amazing! The best!!
author: Ben G.

description:
Hello Late Night drunken taco fix!

When I am drunk, I love mexican food. Like massive obsession. Thank god we were cruising by this place because my friends and I totally made a pit stop for some late night snacking.

I ended up getting a vegetarian burrito from here. It was pretty good, however nothing really exceptional. It was more than enough food for me and I ended up saving half of it for another time, which I totally ate the next morning when I was hungover (still dont know how I was hungover when I didnt drink that much). 

They do serve beer and margaritas here so if you want to take the party elsewhere, you could probably go here. 

There were times when I was sitting there that I felt like I was in the Will and Grace episode where Karen and all of her rich friends go to this taco place, and they all use different identities because they don't want people knowing they go here. There were people there seriously chowing down like the women in the episode was, which was pretty funny. I really wanted someone to come up and ask me for my name. I would have used Karen's.
author: Diana R.

description:
Overall score: I'll give this place a 2.5 stars

Food: The quality of the food here is pretty good, but then there are some things that they serve that are not quite right. For example, I love how they grill the chicken and leave it whole and chop the chicken in front of you when it's time to serve. On the other side, they serve nachos that were purchased from some commercial vendor. Their roja sauce for enchiladas is so gross, but then their beef is awesome. Uggh, it's so weird. 

Price: It's on the pricier side for a meal that was mediocre.

Cleanliness: This place is located in the Mission district, which is probably not the nicest part of town. When we were ordering, we got a really strong smell of weed inside of the restaurant (it definitely came from outside). The tables are sort of gross and uncomfortable.

Overall: Probably will not go there again....it was too much of a hassle to find parking and then the food was also extremely mediocre.
author: LAIKA K.

description:
This place is pretty bomb. I pretty much never leave with an empty stomach. Their super burrito's are always good no matter what meat you choose. Next time I plan to try the seafood burrito. 

Overall I would have to say that you should definitely give this place a shot.
author: Marcus V.

description: Dont tecommend it. Should have noticed the red flag when we saw it was empty. Food was dry and bland. carne asada rubbery. filthy bathrooms. Will not be returning.
author: Patty S.

description: This place is seriously AMAZING! My first time here I got the supreme chicken burrito  and some chips and fresh salsa and it did NOT disappoint! Ridiculously delicious and flavorful and the service could not have been more friendly! The owner even came over and talked with me and asked me how my food was! I also won a free cookie! LOVED IT!
author: Aditi G.

description:
I came here because, according to Man v. Food, this is the home of the Mission-Style super burrito. I just got a simple burrito with chicken and some hot pico de gallo, as I wanted to get the real taste of how their chicken is cooked and seasoned.

While I appreciate the grill/stove near the serving area (to really show that the food is prepared right there), the burrito did not really impress me that much. It was good, yes, but I feel like I could get just as good a burrito at other Mexican places -- even if I added more to the burrito, such as rice or beans. The chips that I also received were a bit on the stale side...not good.
author: Aaron W.

description: Such a pleasant surprise. Seen this advertised on The Food Network Channel. We ordered a shrimp and chicken burrito, chicken mole plate and a chili verde pork burrito (that we have to eat later for dinner). Only wish they would have had 2 pieces of chicken instead of one yet, VERY TASTY ! We will be back. Great tasty salsa bar and good chips. Workers were very pleasant. Place was very clean and music was cool! Bravo ! U hit the spot !
author: C U.

description:
Just like everyone else I saw this on TV and happen to be in the neighborhood so I figured I would give it a shot.  After all the reviews are are from trustworthy people on Yelp, not so much on TV.  This placed su*&ed from start to finish the Carne Asada or "steak as they call it was cold and bland.  The size of the burrito was fine , but for the quality it was way overpriced and who the hell puts American cheese on a burrito.  The chicken was but and had BBQ sauce so I tried to order some pulled pork and they didn't get the joke.  Overall save your money and go anywhere else, but this place.  

Bland, overpriced, not very warm and overall another tourist trap.
author: Bob J.

description: will not be returning here.. came here with my sister from texas, ordered 2 super burritos w/ no lettuce and no salsa.. and noticed the server take some meat to give to another customer as samples?!! that left our burritos with little meat left..  i wanted to talk to the mgr.. but isnt it obvoius ? .. a paying customer should not have to school the servers.. its common sense.. there are  lots of  taquerias out there.. thanks to yelp !
author: Jewel W.

description:
Good burritos!

Definitely an amazing place to go after a long night of stumbling between 16th and 20th and mission in and out of the bars.

The burritos are great however, I must say Man V. Food definitely gave them a little too much credit. The prices aren't the best, and the product, well.. in my humble opinion there are better burritos out there, and for much cheaper.

For vegans and vegetarians, the super burrito is outta the question, and to the meat eaters it's gonna run your bill up to about 8- 8.50.

I don't know about you, but I'd rather not pay an arm an a leg for an "a-ok" product. 

All in all, this place is A-ok.
author: Jena R.

description:
I used to love this place...what happened to this place?  Was drinking in the mission last night and popped in here early on for a quick bite.  Had my usual favorite that I've always ordered over the years, a carne asada burrito and a bottle of Dos Equis XX.  The beer went with the burrito very well and was a total rarity since I'm a cocktail or wine guy and drink beer only once or twice a year.

Anyway, the carne asada in the burrito was okay although chopped a little small and was kinda dry and tough.  I can live with that, but the way it was rolled was so that the ingredients inside made it a half and half burrito.  Either you took a bite that was all meat or you took a bite that was all rice, beans, and lettuce (not big on lettuce).  I asked for it a little hot, but there was no evidence of hot sauce and it was the blandest burrito I've had in years.

The best part of the whole meal was their chips and also two really good salsas that I got at their free salsa bar.  One of them really impressed me.  So savory with a hint of sweetness before the spices hit.  It really surprised me.  As for the rest of the experience, I used to really love this place so I don't know what happened, but it will be some time before I am back again.  Way too many good burrito places to go in the bay area.  

My feeling is similar to that of Jen S's review.  I thought the food on this visit was probably only two stars, but I'll also give them one extra for the chips and salsa bar.  This place had been great for me over the years so perhaps they were having an off day.  Besides, it's a good place for a quick bite before barhopping in the Mission.  Three stars.
author: Roy N.

description: The burritos here are awesome. I think they are superior to La Taqueria or El Farolito. The lines are also shorter, there are tables, and meals come with chips and salsa (several kinds). The grilled chicken is particularly good.
author: Michael L.

description:
THE hands down best vegetarian burrito I have eaten in San Francisco. I can't speak for the other menu items, but this was SOLID GOLD!! Each ingredient was in perfect harmony with each other. Avocado, beans, cheese, was that sour cream I detected?, tomatoes and onions.  The beans tasted like beans, not  like pork, beef, or assorted other meats! All the ingredients were readily discernible; it was warm and filling.Thanks!  Forget the golden goose, Jack should have stolen the glorious hands of whoever makes these burritos.  

 I enjoyed it thoroughly, and as I ate and walked, I thought, "Don't drop it." Silly, really. How could it escape? It did. The last inch and a half thumped onto the dirty 16th Street sidewalk. There was slim to no chance of recovery. Damn!  I was havin' a hard time, living the good life.
author: Em L.

description: Best burrito in the Mission hands down! The owner is also super dedicated to making his customers happy. If you don't like how your burrito (or other item) is prepared just let the staff know and they'll fix it for you! Yummmmmy
author: Erin A.

description: This place is SO overrated.  My parents made me go here because they wanted to try something that was on Man VS Food, they thought it would be very good -- we were wrong.  The carne was probably the worst Ive ever had.. And the place looks dirty.  I would never come here again for food.  I've tried better.
author: Danielle O.

description:
I don't know whose bright idea it was to wait until the last day I was in town to try and take me to Ike's.  Obviously the line was about three hours long, so we ventured else where and ended up here at La Cumbre for the sole fact that I was tired of walking, and it catered to our groups good restrictions as best as possible.

When they say, If you move from San Diego to San Francisco, you miss out on the good Mexican food, and damn are they right,, SORRY.

Granted the sizes are pretty decent, and the prices aren't that bad, if you're hung over im sure the grease it a tummy pleaser.  But at times it can be too much, leaving all of us with sore stomachs for the rest of the day.

I think my only complaint was the fact that I'm vegetarian, I ordered the vegetarian burrito, and right before it was made, the lady helping me out touched a huge piece of carne asada, and then proceeded to touch my tortilla, getting bits and pieces of meat allllll over it. EEEP.
author: Madison B.

description: I came in here earlier never been here and I heard about it. I'm going to say it was an ok burrito I've had better. So who cares what Adam Richman thinks lol that's not going to make all people like your food, everyone has an opinion and different taste buds. BTW this place was dead when I went and the owner is hilarious posting comments attacking the customers yikes. My super burrito carne asada was ok. I liked that they had spinach tortilla and the menu keeps changing every two seconds on their flat screen tvs, so I couldn't see they add lettuce which I personally don't like but it was too late she had already put it on. I had to ask her to add salsa when she was wrapping it up which she did. She then heated the whole burrito up to make it warm I'm assuming but my burrito was cold and so was my boyfriends. Well I liked some of their salsas in their bar. I don't know if I would come back since there's so many other taquerias that curb my Mexican cravings in the city but I would if I'm around perhaps. I hope I don't get attacked for my opinion lol I get that "celebrities" come here ok and that you guys were in maxim 5 years ago and on sf paper that's cool! Anyways try it if you haven't make sure you specifically tell them how you want it plus I do like that they are big burritos couldn't finish it all.
author: arlene d.

description:
WHAT. The home of the infamous "mission burrito".

HOW. A side trip to SF landed me here with a little help from a feature segment in a show called Man V Food (thanks, adam). 

TASTE. Hands down, you gotta try their version of the "super burrito". I understand everybody has their own but la cumbre's is can't miss stuff. Weighing at a little over 2 pounds, this infant-sized monster is stuffed with the usual suspects - rice, beans, lettuce, guac, pico de gallo, sour cream plus your own choice of meat (in this case I chose to go for the carnitas in chile verde). Added a bucket load of their home-made fresh salsa and BAM.. the rest was history.

SERVICE. We went on a busy friday lunch; place was packed. Not too happy with the wait but didn't seem to mind it at all. We got good seating right away and the salsa bar was such a thrill 'coz of their wide array of condiment concoctions. We had to park on the street since there's no parking, but then again - this is SF. 

PRICE. Forgot exactly how much I paid for a super burrito and a large horchata (yum) but fersure it wasn't over 10 bucks. Not bad at all. 

Overall, La Cumbre is one must-eat spot in SF's mission area. Don not be surprised to hear that even some people consider it as a pilgrimage. Uh huh, it's that good.
author: JC L.

description:
Goood frikin chicken. Burrito express.

I'm not talking about http://www.yelp.com/biz/goood-frikin-chicken-san-francisco#hrid:1AOIgzWlQ6w5Zhs9Nw72pg or http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-burrito-express-2-san-francisco#hrid:t1IuKOgiGjFd0WIaRxva2Q.

I'm talking about a burrito with very good, very flavorful chicken that was made faster than I could say "grilled chicken, black beans, mild salsa, wheat tortilla."

Now that's what I'm talking about.
author: Jason B.

description: Came because of MVF. Kind of mediocre. Meat was tough, sauces flavorless. Have had better burritos in Staten Island, NY
author: Joe P.

description:
Oh, myyyyy love

My darling

I hunger for your...

Well, actually, I just hunger for you, La Cumbre. I had my inagural La Cumbre burrito last saturday, and today, exactly a week later, not a day has gone by when I havent thought about it. I have the hunger of a large fat man, and this means that I daydream about amazing food (don't judge).  

The food was absolutely the freshest, and I noticed that they cut the meat in front of you (a sentance usually reserved for other times, but is applicable here).  Just walking in, it smells like the best food. I got the small burrito which was more than enough with the fresh chicken and some of the best salsa around.  While I'm harboring the thoughts of a 300 lb dirty fat man, I'm a small 5'4'' girl who was barely able to put down the gargantuous burrito.

Oh, just thinking about it now makes me want to run off to the mission and harbor myself inside La Cumbre...

They are very proud of the fact that Maxim named them the best burrito (I'm proud of you too, La Cumbre!) but I'm more fascinated by the fact that my darling Adam Richman from Man v. Food swung by.  There's no mention of his visit in La Cumbre, but that's ok. We all know what's up. Absolutely hands down the best burrito EVER.
