My darling La Cumbre, you're beautiful. You're beautiful, it's true.
author: Andrea C.

description:
The burritos are decent, and the salsas are above average quality, but I've had two very bad experiences here.

The first time I came in I got a falafel burrito. Its horrible. I really like falafel, but this stuff was microwaved, not fried, and was far too dry. Stay away from this dish.

After coming back and having a number of decent burritos, my girlfirend found a rock in her burrito - by biting down on it.  When we showed the employees the rock (about 1/4 across), the employee threw it away. No apologies, no free meal, just back to business.
author: Miles R.

description:
I moved to San Diego, a place that lots of people claim has 'the best burritos in the world', well... I'm still new here but, so far, I don't believe them. La Cumbre is the best burrito in the world! As all San Franciscans do, I like to consider myself a burrito aficionado and, when I come back to visit now- if there's only time to hit up one Taqueria, it's going to be La Cumbre.

They're Nor Cal style (aka: huge) and unpretentious. Best of all, you can customize it pretty much however you want and the staff won't grumble or yell at you. I mention this because, if you've been dissappointed with La Cumbre before- simply have them grill your burrito and it'll become a completely different  experience for you.
author: Robert M.

description: Like their second store in San Mateo, I just don't get the hype. There's plenty of other good taquerias in the mission so I'd keep walking. I somehow keep forgetting how little i think of la cumbre and keep going back only to remember that it kinda sucks.
author: Misha T.

description: La Cumbre is the original.  The grilled meats are especially top notch.  I have never had anything here but great service.  The Mission is changing, but La Cumbre holds its own.
author: Christopher A.

description:
I used to be King of the Burritos. I would scarf those b*tches down by the handful. There wasn't a burrito I couldn't tackle. There was even a point when I could eat an entire one and still be hungry. 

Alas, my days of being gordo are long gone and I have ushered in a new era of sticking to tacos and less dense options. 

But after some drinks at Kilowatt, my friend and I walked around the corner to La Cumbre and were enticed by the burrito options. It was closing in on 8pm and I was starving. I can usually eat dinner pretty late but only if I have a snack. WIth a snack consisting of only vodka & cranberry juice (side note: was supposed to be gin & tonic), I was starving. It was matter over mind and the only thing that mattered was making the grumblies go away. 

So I ordered one of their monstrous burritos with carne asada, black beans, spicy salsa, guac and cheese. They throw a cow's worth of cheese on, so let them know if you want it ligther than that. Along with some chips and a trip to the salsa bar, I sat down on my stool, ripped open the double layer of aluminum foil, and shoved that thing as far back into my mouth as I could. 

After gagging on 2 inches, I took it out and ate the rest like a famished gentleman. 

It was delicious! I was legitimately stuffed after 3/4 of the burrito, but my manly ego wouldn't let me stop. In my best Homer Simpson meets Jenna Maroney impersonation, I said "Must. Finish. Bur-RI-to." And I did. And I whined about it for the next 16 hours.

We went to the coffee shop next door afterwards but I couldn't even look at the menu without wanting to give birth to my new child. 

Needless the say, the food was really good! Come here for a fair-priced, quickly-made, juicy and delectable burrito.
author: Jared S.

description: Had I reviewed this place after my meal last week, I would have given it 4 stars. I was enticed by a surprising good free sample of the quesadilla suiza. The meal was so delicious and well seasoned it didn't even need salsa. Today's meal was barely edible--did not listen to my order, flavorless burrito, refried beans that tasted like the bathroom smelled. The disappointment was worse than the bad meal.  I thought I had found the elusive promised land of tasty Mexican food in the Mission, but alas, it was just a mirage!
author: Presto G.

description: That's just say i'm a regular, i've been here so many times and its still amazing, Tortas, mission style burrito ( Which they created) and Horchata, any place that sells Horchata can get me in the door but there food here keeps me coming back
author: Sydney P.

description:
Oh La Cumbre. How you have disappointed me.  

How did you manage to get on Man. Vs. Food? who did you pay? how much did you pay?? 

I had the carne asada deluxe burrito...and even with sour cream, guacamole and hot sauce...it was the. absolute. blandest. burrito. i have EVER had. 

sucks. no thanks.
author: Lulu C.

description:
I'm going to keep it short and sweet since I've only been here once.

They have an awesome cheese quesadilla deal along with chips and salsa.... I recall it being under $3. So if money's pretty tight for you, I would highly recommend it.

Service was also fast, and there was plenty of seating which is often a rarity in the Mission.
author: Katie S.

description:
OVERALL:2.4   FOOD:2   SERVICE:2   AMBIANCE:3   VALUE:2.5

Don't you just hate it you're surrounded by people eating food that looks and smells bomb, and then somehow you end up in the ONE place that falls flat?  I mean bad tacos in the Mission....really?

Out of fish, shrimp & pollo asada......waaaaaaaaaat?
Soggy tortillas.
Messed up 3 of 4 orders.
Bland, dry AND gristly meat.

Highlight was definitely the salsa bar, and even that's not enough to lure me back, not even drunk.
author: Amy K.

description: I visited this place after going to Blondies (Martini Bar). I rated it 4 stars mostly for the fact that this place was SPOTLESS. So. Darn. Clean. Other than that, the food was cheap (flour quesadilla, vegetarian super taco, churro) and tasted pretty good. Not the best mexican food I have ever eaten, but I would go there again for some cheap tacos. The churro was a little soggy, but I was craving a churro so bad, so soggy or not it was still delicious.
author: Ashley H.

description:
This restaurant was such a disappointment. I had heard from friends that it was "so good" and then it was featured on man vs. food. So I said, "heck, next time I'm on Valencia I'm eating at la Cumbre." 

Such a let down. The burritos were uninspiring, not like what Adam Richman was eating. Somehow, the burrito was dry, and flavorless even. I added extra salsa from the salsa bar to spice it up. My BF and I both wished we had gone somewhere else, maybe Pancho around the corner. Maybe it was a fluke visit, but it's hard to want to go back when it wasn't great.
author: Lesliegh H.

description:
Terrible, soggy burrito. I'll go back to Pancho Villa around the way for a better tasting burrito. 

Wanted to give them a shot. They were fairly friendly and nice. But, just not good food. 

Salsa's are even worse!
author: Art A.

description:
4.5* Steak Burrito with everything
3.5* Carnitas Taco
3.5* Chicken Taco
author: Aaron L.

description:
You can NOT go wrong with this place. As seen on TV (Man vs. food), we tried this place since we were in the area. MAN o MAN! The burrito gets it in. I somehow managed to finish 92% of that big ass burrito too. I don't know how. I guess it was b/c it was sooo deliciously good. I can't speak on the other dishes they have, but the burrito was very tasty. So my advice would be to just get the burrito. LOL

YOU must try this place if you can. It's not too pricey. Although the line can be long and you might have to wait for seating, it will be worth it. Trust me (:
author: Michelle D.

description:
I grew up off of these burritos! This was the spot that my mom and her sister found when they moved to SF from LA when they were my age.
We use to drive here from Marin just for their burritos.

When I think of an ideal burrito, I think of La Cumbre. They grill their meat right in front of you so you know its freshly made and you can really taste the difference. I always get the carne asada here! (even when I claim I'm a vegetarian!) =)
author: Jacquie S.

description:
Brilliant taqueria food. Very friendly staff, better than expected food, excellent presentation as well. 

This is a great taqueria. Don't come expecting a sit-down restaurant-style experience, or chef-prepared food, this is a taqueria for sure but it excels as such. 

Also, they had a well-stocked salsa bar with good salsas/jalapenos/etc.

p.s. I got the mole poblano special of the day; I don't think burritos in California are any good, so not sure if their burrito is good.
author: Kalyn B.

description:
Taqueria La Cumbre claims to have invented the "Mission-style burrito," which most of the rest of us would recognize as "every burrito you have eaten north of New Mexico since 1995."  I.e., the kind with rice and beans in it, usually the size of a baby's head.  I don't know anything about the veracity of the claim, but given that I live crawling distance from here (although I'm not sure I'd crawl on these particular streets), I figured I ought to come check it out.

The verdict: The Super Burrito I got here was not the biggest I've ever had, nor the best, but it was plenty big and plenty good.  And less than 10 bucks.  Even at 6:00, I was the only customer in the place, and they were friendly, helpful, and lightning-fast.  Definitely good enough to go back with Wifey (who was, once again, "on a business trip," which I figure means "stashing money in a foreign bank account for use when she leaves me.").  Thankfully, you're never lonely when you have a burrito.  Which explains why I didn't eat it...right away.  (BTW, any suggestions on how to get guac stains out of fitted sheets???)

P.S.: Every time I see that some a-hole has posted a picture of their food, I flag it as "not helpful."  Pictures of, say, the front of the restaurant are helpful.  Pictures of the inside of the restaurant, also helpful.  Pictures of your food = self-indulgent.
author: Ben P.

description: I had a great experience when ordering from the catering menu for my party of nearly 40 people. I called in my order and Edward was most helpful. 1st star for: I asked if he thought my order was good for the amount of guests I was going to have and he didn't try to sell me more. 2nd star for: He sent and email as an order confirmation and all I needed to do was call to make a payment. 3rd star for: My order was ready on time and everything I ordered was correct and delicious! 4th star for: My order even came with a plastic tablecloth, serving spoons and a 3-compartment serving dish for the three different salsa's. 5th star: Edward even sent me a happy birthday greeting through text. Over all - good service, good food, nice guy. What more can you ask for?
author: Veronica R.

description: Awesome! A friend took me here for my birthday after seeing it on man vs. Food and we had to try it! So delicious and fresh I had the chicken nachos and tasted the steak burrito! I would defiantly visit here again if I am in the city!
author: Sarah W.

description: I don't see what the fuss is about. The carne asada and chicken were both a little too tough and chewy. More importantly, both times I came I ordered something exciting (al pastor once, mole the other time) and was told they didn't have it--and both times they kind of barked it at me, as if I were an idiot for ordering off their menu. Good salsa bar, but that's the best compliment I can give.
author: Mike B.

description:
I have been here a couple of times when I get a hankering for a burrito and have found it to be pretty good when I go. I like their super delux with lettuce (some places don't put lettcue in their burritos unless it is vegetarian and I think that's weird. But then again, I am weird so really, who knows?)

ANYWAY....

last night, Mister P and I decided to go for Mexican and hit up the Mission, fleeing from our boring and not so flavorful life in Pac Heights and get some excitement.

La Cumbre hits the spot. I like their salsa bar, and the fact that I can eat through about 10 of those small plastic cups of salsa and not be judged, (just mildy laughed at by the employees) is kind of nice.

My burrito was HUGE with lots of carne asada, lots of salsa, lots of rice (no beans) and quite juicy.

So I give it 3 stars for not being the best burrito I have had, but definitely one of the better ones.
author: Kathy K.

description:
I came here for a late lunch yesterday (Sunday) around 2. Wasn't too crowded, very short line. I got a deluxe burrito with al pastor. YUM I love their al pastor! It was around $7. The deluxe burrito has rice, beans, meat, guac, sour cream, cheese, and salsa. I think the only difference between the deluxe and super was that the super has lettuce and tomatoes.
The burrito was big and wrapped PERFECTLY. Bf and I both agreed that it was the best wrapped burrito we've seen :P and it was delicious too. I couldn't finish it so I saved it for dinner too, and it tasted great. Their menu has a lot of variety and I will definitely be back to try other menu items. Oh, I also like that they grill the meat right in front of you :)
author: Christine C.

description:
This burrito tasted amazingly super-fantastically unbelievably hella yummy after a night of drinking.

What a surprise.
author: Dina G.

description: I have been to many authentic mex restruants and this by far is still the best. I have moved from the bay area and come back to visit, This Taqueria the first to open in SF  back in the late 60:s still takes the lead. The food is fresh and many salsa's to choose from. The menu has changed slightly and for the best, it makes for coming back more pleasurable. The famous grilled steak, and BBQ chicken are to die for. I would send all my friends,and co workers. This is truly an authentic mexican Taqueria and you cannot beat these prices.
author: Irma J.

description:
I have been going off some of the different recomendations from yelp for a while now. We decided to go the this place after a friend recalled seeing  it on Man Vs Food. We have done this before and always had a decent meal. But I have to tell you this place was so bad I actually signed up on yelp just to tell people this. We both had the Deluxe Carne Asada burrito I noticed right off the bat that the meat they were cooking was not marinated at all. The cook was just pulling it straight from the fridge on to the grill. Once receiving the Burrito it looked great.  Ready to bite in my first mouthful was full of fat and grissel inedible every bite after that required heavy salsa. 6 bites and zero flavor later, we both threw our burrito's in trash and left.

Maybe at one time this place was great but its definitely not worth going to if this is there style now. Only thing that was good was my walk out the door with my snapple in hand.
author: John C.

description:
I have been going to Le Cumbre since 1978.
It is hands down the best place for a burrito on the west coast. 
I knew the lady on shirt before she pasted away.
If you are in San Francisco, this is a place you go to. The district is run down, as it always has been. do not let that stop you. get the steak burrito.  bubbajess
author: Jesse P.

description:
I just had the most delicious mess here. The sauteed vegetable burrito is the best I've ever experienced. They take some garlic and grill up bell peppers (red, yellow and green), onions, mushrooms, carrots and zucchini. That, combined with black beans and rice, all wrapped up in a nice, giant tortilla make me want to run back for more. 

By the time I was done, my hands were covered in burrito juice, and my boyfriend would not make out with me for the rest of the night. A small price to pay, I tell you!

Minus one star because he said that his grilled chicken burrito tasted like air (a common complaint from him) and we actually considered stopping so he could get a slice of pizza on the way home.
author: carrie c.

description: Wonderful people and wonderful food. Don't complicate things. Just eat here and enjoy it.
author: Candace S.

description:
After our violation scrub down in Japan town , My friends and I were starving so we came here to grab something quick and talk about the experience we went through. My other favorite spots in the mission were either closed or the line was too long so we decided to try this place. 

We go there about 10:30pm. The place was pretty full but there were still places to sit. Since we were at a taqueria I went for the tacos. I had tacos al pastor and luengua-all with no beans. I can have those at home anytime! The tacos al pastor were very good. Not too greasy! At my old age, my stomach can't take spicy grease too well! The luengua was ok. The salsa bar was fresh and had good selection.
author: Elo N.

description:
I came here after the episode of Man v Food and I was very curious to see how great this place would be. I have come to realize that most if not all of the restaurants that are on TV are generally not that good. 

This restaurant is like any other Taqueria in the mission. Nothing spectacular, nothing amazing. I hate to say this but I even think Gordo's is better than this place. I was very disappointed. I had the carne asada burrito and the meat was lukewarm and chewy, the ingredients were fresh but the place is not all that clean. I've been to dive taquerias and even been to local restaurants in Mexico.........this place should not be this dirty to have been on TV.   The price for their burritos are higher than other establishments.  8 dollars for a burrito in the Mission..............is a little too much for below par food.

Pancho Villa is clean, Gordo's is a hole in a wall........but it's clean. El Farolita feels grimy but it's clean. This place..............I just can't put my finger on it. It's just feels dirty. 

I will not be coming back here because there are far better restaurants out there.
author: jason g.

description:
So I finally hit up this place after the club. I honestly don't see what the hype was over, their food here is just OK and overpriced. Adam from Man Vs. Food should have gone to El Farolito for a really good burrito. 

OK sorry La Cumbre that might have been a little harsh, but considering its the Mission district, the burritos here will satisfy your cravings, whether it be late night grub or a quick lunch. The inside has an old feel to it, but I completely forgot its one of the first taquerias established in the area. So its nice to be eating in a vintage setting, high ceilings and all. 

I approve of this place just because its open late, but so far its not my top option in the Mission. It's worth a try though! Props to them for having a salsa bar as well. The area outside of the taqueria is a bit iffy, but hey look at where you're at if you're here. Not bad, but not worth the hype.
author: Loren John B.

description:
Two tacos came out to a whooping $7.50.

Ok.  What do a trumpet, a rifle, a Mexican flag, a low-cut top, and two belts of ammo have in common?  They are all found adorning the woman on the tables at La Cumbre.

If that isn't reason enough for a visit, then the food might be.  A quick sampling of the al pastor will definitely have me coming back any time I hit the Casanova Lounge.  I tried the pollo asado too, which holds its own.  Just writing about this makes me hungry for a couple of tacos.  Well, that and maybe also the fact that I'm a fatty.

While the tacos are solid, the stale chips and questionable green paste labeled "guacamole" should be omitted from your meal; even if free.  Furthermore, the $3/taco price point can only be forgiven by the fact that La Cumbre neighbors a bar.

Taco, taco.  Burrito, burrito.
author: Troy M.

description: My boyfriend and I come here whenever we're craving some quick Mexican food. I always get a burrito, I once got the el pastor but it was mostly fat and pineapple pieces. But the carnitas and carne asada are pretty tasty. The salsas also compliment the food.
author: Maria H.

description:
The holy grail of mission burritos. 

Arguably the originator of the mission style burrito that has been made so popular by imitation chains, this is a burrito mecca that I make a must stop whenever I visit San Francisco. 

The burritos here are enormous. I can barely eat half of one. On top of that, they are mega CHEAP.  A burrito, chips, and a drink is considerably less than $10. As to how anyone could eat chips on top of these gargantuan burritos however is beyond me. 

The rice, beans, and meats here are delightful. Its delicious and I don't know what more I need to say.

Stop in and visit a San Francisco legend. You won't regret it.
author: Ryan O.

description:
Great burritos, never changes, I've been going here since I was 6.
Better than El Toro but parkings a little tough so get a friend to jump out and just circle the block.
author: Mike V.

description: Not terrible? Beautiful interior and ambiance. Bustling, friendly, great service. Food sub-par relative to the competition. Carne asada tough, burrito soupy and the shredded pork dried out.
author: Terry G.

description:
My boyfriend and I tried La Cumbre after seeing the episode of Man vs Food featuring the super burrito.  Upon entering La Cumbre, I noticed that the patrons were lacking the local populace, especially since it is located in the heart of the Mission district.  Normally, I look for Hispanic families at the desirable taqueria establishments as an indication of a good local value.  

The service of the staff wasn't particularly friendly and my boyfriend ordered a lime margarita for me but I ended up with a lime Jarritos (lime Mexican soda).  I ordered a pollo super burrito while my boyfriend order a pollo asada super burrito, since they were out of al pastor.  My burrito consisted of fresh ingredients, black beans a plus and the chicken was juicy; however, I had some chewy bits of chicken and the lettuce...  shouldn't have been in the burrito.  It was okay but I've had better.

My boyfriend saw them grilling chicken but for whatever reason, he ended up with a few dry and chewy bits and also didn't like the lettuce on his burrito.  He has had better also.

Overall, we were full but unsatisfied.
author: Tiffany A.

description:
Decided to stop in after missing the Civic Center BART stop. Got the deluxe, with carnitas (I think). Was great. Def one of the better burritos I've had in SF. Only complaint - the dude chopping the meat was loud as shit. My head was pounding before. After, I thought I had an aneurysm. 

UPDATE - I didn't have an aneurysm.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Saw on Man vs. Food. This is the birthplace of the Mission Style Burrito -- ie. what they do at Chipotle. I love Chipotle but place is even fresher and more amazing. If I lived in San Fran I would go here weekly. They have like 10 types of meat/seasoning combos to choose from for the burritos! Mind blowing. If you like Mexican food, you should love this place.
author: Scott B.

description:
Worth the expensive taxi for this delicious lunch. This taqueria is definitely reputable, and they have been around since the 1960s for a reason. That being said...nothing here just really knocked my socks off. I was hoping there would be something there to really blow me away, and while it was all good, there wasn't one particular item or ingredient that was at the top of its class.

Check the place out if you get the chance, but I wouldn't make the trip up to the city just to eat here.
author: Matt D.

description:
Ok, La Cumbre has achieved redemption.

I went twice within a week and was pretty satisfied with both meals.  One was lunch with a friend in the middle of a dreary Tuesday and the other was a Saturday afternoon hangover solution and both super burritos were far better than what I had previously received at this establishment.  On one occasion I got a meat combination of carnitas and carne asada.  I recommend doing the meat combos, delicious.

These are good burritos.  I don't know if they're the best but I'm glad I've now experienced better after the horror show that was the last experience.
author: Steven R.

description: Been here a couple of times and the burritos have never failed me.  I've only had the pollo asada and carne asada burritos and have always been a great pickup on my way to the BART station just down the street.  I'm deducting one star on this review mainly due to the cleanliness of the restaurant.  I'm not sure if it's an unwritten rule at this place but I've been bussing my own table after I eat there but sometimes have to bus it before I can eat since others often leave their mess expecting someone else to clean it.  Other than that, probably in my top 5 burrito spots in SF.
author: Eric M.

description: The burrito at least the regular carne asada one is now the size of a Taco Bell bean burrito. They cut back on the portions so much it's roughly 1/2 the size of what it once was and it's 1/3 more expensive. Other's must agree with me because last Wednesday around 6 pm there could have been no more than 5 people in the place including me yet the sidewalk outside was teeming with people. Honestly it's not worth the hassle if you are driving because it's always been a problem finding parking but the payoff now isn't that big of a deal. It has had it's day and this is coming from someone who's been going here since 1992.
author: .James A.

description:
I stopped in at La Cumbre yesterday, it has long been near the top of my list of taquerias.   I was very, very disappointed.  Are they under a new management perhaps?  The staff were surly, I thought and the burrito that I had was, well, substandard.  It was not well wrapped; the carnitas was not fully cooked and when I asked for a bottle of hot sauce, the woman behind the register --who was obviously annoyed that I would ask--  sucked her teeth and gestured with her chin at the salsa bar.

I will not be going back to La Cumbre on my own,  The only scenario that would bring me back would be that I was with a group and the group pick was La Cumbre.
author: lee d.

description:
I've been twice. Both times my burritos were a 3 on the scale of 1 to 5. That means they were edible, and somewhat tasty but not lick-my-plate delicious as they are at El Farolito. 

I was just there this Sunday and was disappointed when I ordered a 24 oz. fresh-squeezed carrot juice that was on the menu. The cashier looked at me like I was on crack. She said, "No we don't have orange juice." I reminded her that I wanted carrot juice... I mean I had just seen a girl walk down the street holding one and I assumed she got it here, it was right there on the wall. But alas, NO, she said they didn't offer it. Minus 1 point for that.

My chicken burrito was quite tasty but for some reason I thought the meat to rice/bean ratio was off. I like a little more beans and rice in my burrito. Their salsas were good but for some reason the green avocado/tomatillo one tasted like refrigerator that day. I was bummed about that! Overall, they have a nice selections of salsas and garnishes in their salsa bar. Their chips are alright, nothing to write home about.

One interesting thing I noticed on the menu was that they offer a falafel burrito. That's some serious fusion right there. My veggie friend got it and said it was good. I was too freaked out to try it but I give them props for their originality. Both friends I took said they enjoyed their food and were rather shocked when I told them this place was only average compared to the best that the Mission has to offer.

I'd say I would go back, but only if I'm too tired or lazy to walk to El Farolito on 24th and Mission.
author: L. L.

description: I don't know about this place... Of all the Taqueria's in the Mission, I would steer clear of this one. I came here last night with a couple of friends and I wasn't very pleased with the food. I ordered a super burrito and repeated what I wanted three times... They obviously weren't listening because they added things I did not want. Their guacamole had a watery consistency, looked like it had been sitting there for a week and the carnita tasted old. Plus their chips were stale and some had a chemical taste to them. I couldn't finish my meal because I felt like I was eating expired food.. What a waste of money.
author: Rosa L.

description: Even for Mexican food this place is a bit dirty. The burritos are delicious, great tortilla wrapping. I only wish they would clean things up!
author: Jack T.

description:
Major let down. Not to mention that I became violently ill when I got home. Went here last Saturday after we had seen this place on Man vs. Food. I have walked by this place for yrs and managed to not get sucked in.

 Alas, being adventurous and supportive I said, ''Fine, let's go... Live a little.'' Ummmm, live a little, no.... I could not eat mine. All I had was the bean and cheese burrito. Simple, how can you screw this up? Hmmmm, it is doable. I had a bite of my BF's, a carne asada burrito, and that was all it took. Very soon after it was all down hill from there. 

Based on food alone, I will never go back. Place looks dirty, is way over priced and does not deliver. I would never go back.
author: Nicole F.

description:
I enjoy trying Mexican food in different cities. I'm not saying this is always a successful endeavor.... (nachos in London = crap), but needless to say, a friend in the City suggested this place to me. 

The City is a fickle place. Some delights are open into the wee hours. Others are open for a select time. Taqueria La Cumbre is one of those wee hours places. My brother and I decided to try it post-concert and drove on by at about 11:30 PM. 

We were in a sketchy part of town for that time of night. In the daytime, I'm sure the charm would have shown through. In the evening, that charm retreated behind metal shutters. 

The food was decent. It's not the best Mexican food I've ever had, but they grill the meat when you order it. I had the carne asada burrito. It was a decent size, but a little spendy for what I got. Maybe it's because I go to the taco truck and spend a max of $4-5 on a meal. Meh *shrug*. The meat was delicious, but the other innards didn't fare as well. The beans were bland as was the rice. I was hoping I could save it with some salsa.... but alas it just added some moisture to the rice. 

My brother got the chicken burrito. He had the same complaints as I did, but I have to admit that the chicken was darn tasty! His burrito had guacamole and it was fine. 

I'm sure that this won't be my first foray into the City for a late night bite, but give this place a go if you're looking for decent midnight vittles.
author: Rena W.

description:
Yes, I did watch the Man v Food episode, so my expectations were high. So, I decided to check out this so called place that first created the Mission Style Burrito. 

Unfortunately, it was all hype. The husband ordered the Super Burrito al pastor. I ordered the taco al pastor. Meh...I definitely had better, even down the street. The staff was sorta friendly, but disorganized. The probably asked me what I wanted on my taco at least 4 times! The al pastor was under seasoned. The beans were under seasoned. The lettuce made the burrito bland. Overall, I was not impressed. The only upside is that it is open late. But then again, I could go one or two blocks that is also open late and get a better burrito.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Became aware of this taqueria after driving by it often during my commute, and subsequently heard of its greatness through the SF burrito grapevine.  I stopped in recently and had a taco plate.  It was good, fresh tasting and was provided with all the toppings/sides I needed.  I was happy and content (as was my belly).

My girlfriend got a carne asada burrito and I have to admit, I was a little jealous.  I mean, my plate was good but hers was just downright tasty.  I am salivating just typing this.  I have had many a burrito in my time and can pick the best out of a mexican food lineup.  The key is integration of ingredients and freshness.  This 'rito had the mojo and was working on all harmonious cylinders.  Like I said, I was jealous.  Very, very tasty.

The environment was what you can expect at the corner of 16th & Valencia: authentic Mission neighborhood vibe, pure SF.  The hustle and bustle of the staff and customers made it feel good to be there enjoying the food on a saturday afternoon.

The prices are a little high, as some reviewers have referred to the Man vs. Food episode as an impetus for that.  Undoubtedly this is true.  I just hope that the added attention doesn't translate to an ego boost for the staff that leads to a drop in quality and further increase in prices.

Highly recommended.  Stop by if you are in the area, it's just a short walk from Dolores Park.
author: TJ D.

description:
Visited here recently after being away for a few years  -  what happened????

Absolutely the worst burrito I've ever had -  bland, boring, stale rice, canned tasting salsa & barely there "hot" sauce   - basically  tasted like something you'd find in a food court in some mid-western mall.....

Are there new owners??   Or did they just figure out that tourists don't know any better, so why bother???

This place was once one of the best......so sad!!!!!
author: stephanie c.

description: One of the best burritos I've had. 2 lbs of food wrapped in a fresh tortilla and salsa. You're given many choices to customize your burrito so it will come out to your liking.
author: Phillip C.

description: After seeing Man vs Food, I decided I had to try this place. We went on a Tuesday night and there was no wait. The service was very helpful and courteous. I ordered the super burrito, which I enjoyed. It was extremely filling and tasty. The carne asada was juicy and delicious. I love avacado/guacamole, and there was plenty on the burrito. A very good burrito and I'd recommend trying it.
author: Matthew S.

description: Not great but good. This taqueria was hyped up to me as the second coming of Christ in an Burrito.  I was a little underwhelmed with the flavor of the meat, it was sort of ....bland .  To some that's the point to just have the flavor of the meat, barely any seasoning. Personally, I like subtle seasoning not overpowering but enough to know oh yeah there's a little something there.  Guacomole, rice and pinto beans and the tortillas were very good.  I also had a fish taco there which to me would've been better than the half Carne Asada, and Pollo Asada burrito i got.  With that said, i'm definitely open to trying  this spot again.
author: Earl B.

description:
Best burrito in the Mission and SF!! 

My friend took me to La Cumbre after work one night and we both got the carne asada burritos. O-M-G. The beans, the beef, the guac, the salsa, the rice (i'm really picky about the rice) - everything was super fresh, flavorful, and delicious. 

Great for a "I don't want to cook tonight but I want to eat something good" after work meal, or a "I want to quickly catch up with a friend over a meal but not drag it out" place, or weekend lunch/dinner/late dinner/hang over cure.
author: Keiko T.

description:
This was my first 'mission' style burrito in the actual mission neighborhood and to be honest it was a bit of a let down. The al postor had decent flavor but overall the burrito was on the bland side. And for 8 dollars I was expecting a whole lot more.  I will stay on my quest to find the perfect mission style burrito, as la cumbre just was not it. 


Also they had doused the entire restaurant in the taqueria 'cleaner' which is do sting I thought that I would pass out. While I admire there cleanliness, I wish they had a more discrete method of cleaning.
author: David M.

description:
DON'T BOTHER!!!!!!!!!!!!

Were in the mission and BF said, Oh lets go to man vs food place! So off we went and both got a standard carne asada burrito.

I've had good burritos and bad burritos, but this one was plain terrible. The meat was SO TOUGH THAT IT YANKED ONE OF MY FILLINGS OUT OF MY MOUTH!!!!!!

I was eating it and was chewing and the meat was SO damn chewy I heard something crunch! Then I spit it out and looked at it and couldnt realize what it was later until I went home and had a hole in on of my molers! WTF! I thought it was was just something bad in the burrito or the veggies not being washe dout enough but no it was part freakng part of my filling!!! it yanked it out, literally. 

Besides this mishap, the other items were not over the top great and will never come back. Seedy area, well it is the mission!
author: Petri Y.

description:
I've been on a review hiatus and what better way to come back than to write a review about a taqueria.  Not to mention, i'm waiting for my Yelp twin to catch up to me with his reviews.  But, why a taqueria?  Because i love em!  Tacos, burrito, flautas, enchiladas and all that Mexican goodness!  

Anyway,  I came here with Greydon U. to have dinner before an elite event.  I ordered a lengua super burrito.  Yes, i like lengua.  Not many people like it or are willing to try it but y'all are missing out.  Usually lengua is done just one way, but here, they have regular lengua and spicy lengua.  I couldn't pass up the chance to try it spicy.  i asked if it was really spicy because you know how it is sometimes.  They say its spicy but  really its mildly spicy.  So when i asked both the cook and the cashier immediately said YES!  It sure didn't disappoint.  

The lengua was spicy.  The burrito was fulfilling and it had everything i wanted in a good burrito.  I couldn't complain.  The place is actually pretty big, but then again no one was in there when i was there so maybe thats why it looked so spacious.  I will definitely be going back to try their other items.  Om Nom Nom!
author: Aaron G.

description:
The meat was very good. I could just eat the meat alone. Its on display and is cooking right infront of you.

I tried the carne asada and got a Super Burrito and a taco.
Even though every one is saying that the burritos were bland tasting I thought they were very flavorful and juicy. 

The salsa they had was also great! It was a pleasant surprise to find chunks of avocados in the salsa!
author: AJ B.

description: My boyfriend and I have wanted to check this place out ever since we saw it on Man v Food and OMG  it was AWFUL!  We both got carne asada burritos and literally every piece of meat was so chewy and fatty I couldn't swallow it. It wasn't only the meat that was inedible but the entire thing tasted weird...like all of the ingredients had spoiled.  In short this place is nasty and over priced.
author: Amanda B.

description:
A Slow but Steady Decline in the Past Months

I have just had the smallest "super" burrito of my life, and I speak as one who has eaten a truly embarrassing number of these guys. In isolation this wouldn't be a big deal, but at this point I have to acknowledge that this is a trend.

Cumbre was always dependable, solid, with friendly people and generous portions and delicious carne asada-- chewy, but delicious. La Cumbre was, for me, a go-to taqueria. Like up to three times a week sometimes.

Over the past several months the quality of the ingredients and size of the portions has gone down. Burritos have grown smaller, with less of the good stuff and more rice. Avocados have grown less ripe even during peak season. Salsa has gotten runnier and less tasty, and finally tonight the salsa bar didn't even have to-go salsa cups at the bar, you have to ask for them at the counter, at which point they will give you two. Ask for four and they will grudgingly hand over the other two.

The people are still friendly overall, though. Maybe there are enough out-of-towners and walk-ins coming in to make the compromises Cumbre has made in quality and quantity profitable. I tend to doubt it, given the relatively low cost of the ingredients and the wealth of other options out there... Los Coyotes, Pancho Villas, and El Toro are all better options at this point, all within a block of La Cumbre.

I hope Cumbre gets back on track. The place has been around for decades and is a real part of Mission history.
author: David M.

description:
Visiting Taqueria La Cumbre was akin to a pilgrimage to me. As a frequent consumer of such chains as Chipotle, Qdoba and Burrito Beach, to visit the place that started the whole "Mission Burrito" craze was a must on my SF to-do list. 

And boy, did it not disappoint. First of all, the burritos are larger than the chains (so if you thought those burritos were big, these will be downright ginormous to you). As someone who prides himself on his large-capacity stomach, I am a bit embarrassed to say that I had a little trouble finishing the bad boy.

This fact, however, was due to the size, and not at all to the flavor or taste. The owners pride themselves on using the freshest and highest quality ingredients available, and you can certainly taste it. The carne asada was so delicious and tender, but it meshed perfectly with the creamy cheese, the refreshing salsa, and the not-so-overpowering seasoned rice.

Simply put, best burrito I've ever had.
author: Ross H.

description: If your one of the lucky one's that stumbles in before the rush of people that is normal for this eatery than order quickly. It takes them awhile to make your food. You can stand there and watch them make your food and place it in a sketchy microwave to melt the cheese! That's super appetizing. It's not the best Mexican food i've ever tasted but not awful I suppose. A little pricey and the cleanliness of the table and seating is questionable :( Probably won't run back to eat there and certainly won't be missing out either.
author: Monika A.

description: The burritos are nice and thick, the meat is tasty, and the signs are quirky -- a pleasing experience for those who love Mexican food.
author: Guillermo G.

description: I wanted to like this place because of seeing it on man vs food and just by looking at the location and the crackheads on the corner i still convinced myself to order a deluxe burrito. And after that it just went all down hill to their ketchup salsa, and old ass pacifico, to stale chips, extra chewy carne asada forget this place it gets 1 star just for being on tv!
author: Luis S.

description: I was on Valencia St. just after work and wanted a super burrito. When I hit this place up I was put off by the price but everywhere else I looked was charging about the same. I would describe the burrito I got as "flavorless." All of the ingredients were remarkably bland. But the worst part came later: I paid with my debit card and I didn't leave a tip (it was my first time going here and the lady behind the counter seemed kind of mean and... I'm a d-bag, whatever...). So when I checked my debit card statement the place had charged me $10 instead of the eight-something I signed off for. Either an employee wrote in the tip for me or there was a minimum transaction amount that no one bothered to tell me about. Real shady.
author: Phillip T.

description: Yes, the latest rash of disappointing reviews are right on...the super burrito was anything but, except bland and uninspiring. I've been coming on and off for over 20 years but the last time was exactly meh.
author: Henry Y.

description:
Had two soft tacos with carne asada.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either; kinda mediocre I guess.  I asked for spicy, but it really wasn't.  Maybe I got white-boy treatment, but still, not cool.

Their salsas/sauces are pretty good, though (there's a little self-serve salsa bar).  There's a spicy brown sauce that goes down really well with the chips, which are pretty good.  They don't give you a lot of chips, but you can go back and ask for more.

At the very least, the service is quick and you can be in and out in a few minutes.  But you can say that for lots of the little hole-in-the-wall places in the Mission, and probably get tastier food too.
author: Brian T.

description:
I came here for the first time and ordered the fajitas steak burrito. didn't know that they needed to spend extra time cooking the fajitas w/the steak, so the lady behind the counter went ahead and served others behind me (without giving me a heads up that mine was on the grill), so I kept thinking that the next steak burrito was mine... and embarrassment ensued repeatedly. 

wish I took Spanish instead of French in high school. sigh.

chips are sparse but salsa bar is pretty...abundant. bad word choice, but there were salsas I've never tried before. burrito was okay.
author: Serena W.

description:
The food itself is probably only two stars, but the extra one is because of the salsa bar. They have radishes and pickled jalapenos and carrots! And I think their salsas are hot and tasty. I am a sucker for a good salsa bar. The chips are good, too, although several of mine were dragged through salt instead of sprinkled with it. 

The meat and fillings are pretty bland, and the mild sauce has no flavor and no punch at all. 

The service is bad - do they not have to try because of the reputation? And what is the rep anyway? Just that it's the first taqueria in the Mission? Lame. I speak Spanish fluently and attempted to do so, only to be rebuffed. That's fine; maybe they aren't used to white girls speaking Spanish. But the chick made all these assumptions that I did not appreciate - like the mild salsa thing. Well, maybe that's the only assumption, but it bugged. 

The nice thing is that you get a huge portion for little money. Yeah, it's a huge mediocre portion. So there's that.
author: Jen S.

description: La Cumbre used to be THE place for burritos. They wrote the book. But, alas, something changed. I think there was an ownership change and the food just tastes different and not as great as it once was. Even the killer red hot sauce they used to put in ketchup bottles on your table changed. It used to be so great and nearly brought tears to your eyes. I used to get the grilled BBQ Chicken burrito and add the red hot sauce, Incredible. I do not want to trash Le Cumbre. It is legendary, I think they have just become complacent and lost their edge. Great staff, super hard working. So, there is room for improvement and a return to splendour. They just need to freshen up. I know Poncho Villa tok a lot of their customers. Le Cumbre used to be the King but now they have much competition. Some very good taquerias and some that even surpass Le Cumbre. That is just the truth.
author: El R.

description:
Thank you Adam Richmond for helping me rediscover my inner fat guy.

La Cumbre was featured on his Man v Food show, and claims to be the inventor of the Mission style super burrito.  As this was a dull Sunday afternoon in which I hadn't eaten, I drove down to the Mission to give La Cumbre a try.

Overall, the burrito met expectations.  The pollo asada was very fresh, but a little too lightly seasoned for my tastes.  There was a generous heap of rice, which I tend to count as a negative as it's clearly cheap filler.  Finally the prices aren't super--a buck or two more than most other taquerias.

The absolute best part about La Cumbre for me is that Arinell pizza is right next door.  The inner fat guy is proud to admit that he grabbed a fantastic NY-style slice for dessert.

3.4999999 stars.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Hadn't been here in a couple of years, so I decided to stop back in.  I ordered a chili verde chicken burrito, but I think the woman making it misunderstood me, because I ended up with the grilled chicken.  Eh, no matter.  Grilled is good too.

This burrito had a few excellent qualities.  First, the rice, which was excellent, and the refried beans, which were very tasty as well.  Also, the grilled chicken had a really nice grill-flavor.  However, the meat was a bit on the dry side, even for grilled chicken, and a little more fatty than I generally like.  More curious than ever what the chili verde is like & will probably have to try it here at some point.

The other reason for the dry-ness was the lack of tasty salse.  There were three different salsas in the salsa bar when I was there (plus lots of other sides, like jalapenos, corn, radishes, and ranch dressing), so I got some of each.  Sadly, none of them made the cut, which means I ate most of my burrito salsa-less.  This is part of what contributed to the dry-ness.  There was a bright-red tomato-based one that was just bland, a darker, brown-colored one that looked promising but was so hot I couldn't anything for a few minutes after tasting it (which is saying something, given my predilection for teh spicy), and a green avocado-based one that was okay, but sort of bland, and too onion-y for my taste.  So the salsa situation made me sad.

Still, not too many complaints about the burrito itself.  I'll be curious to see whether the chili verde version takes care of the dry-ness issue.
author: Angela B.

description:
I understand that La Cumbre is a hallowed creche of burrito development, but its work has been long ago eclipsed by advances in both burrito components and technique by other Mexican-American restaurants. While simple tricks like steaming tortillas have trickled down to even the likes of Chipotle, La Cumbre still engages in the barbaric practice of grilling them dry post-assembly. The burritos are bland, with an unpleasant texture and oddly homogeneous filling.

Eating here is like watching a Simpsons short from the Tracy Ullman show after a string of Season 6 episodes. You can respect where the stuff you love came from while still being slightly repulsed. At best, La Cumbre is a testament to how far we've come.
author: August K.

description: I admit that the food is great, but the employees make this place not worth the food. I bought a homeless woman who was sitting outside of the restaurant a burrito and she came inside to eat it since it was rainy and cold. After she sat down the employees proceeded to throw her out. It eventually led to the police coming to remove the woman. All she wanted to do was eat her burrito in peace. Doesn't every man on Earth deserve that? Please do not support La Cumbre. Thank you :)
author: Katelyn C.

description:
SERVICE - Three Stars: The staff behind the counter was very prompt, courteous, and helpful. The counter area was clean, considering this is an old-school taqueria. Nothing out of the ordinary for a place that's been around. Loved the fact that they took my AMEX card for a $6 purchase and they didn't snicker at me one bit. I would have paid cash, but spent it all at another food joint that was cash-only.

FOOD - 1 Stars: Maybe this place was built up in my head, having seen Adam Richman visit La Cumbre during his Man vs Food San Francisco episode. Everything on television looked fantastic. Unfortunately, it didn't have any taste. I ordered 1 carnitas taco and 1 al pastor taco. I had their "medium" and their "spicy/hot" salsas. EVERYTHING on my plate was extremely bland. The only bits of flavor were the salt crystals on my tortilla chips. Al pastor usually has tons of flavor. Carnitas usually has hints of spices and salt. The 2 salsas I had were so bland.

ATMOSPHERE - 3 Stars: What you might expect from a neighborhood taqueria that's been around for years. I don't think their goal is to wow their customers, as they definitely have a solid customer base.

Bottom line... everyone has their own preferences on food; especially taquerias. But as it's evident that La Cumbre has been around a long time, it might work for you.
author: Ray C.

description: Great food.  I had the super burritto.  Fresh ingredients. Meat had a great taste to it.  Get the jamaica tea as well.
author: Jesse G.

description: Like many other people here, I went here because I saw it on Man Vs Food and wanted see what the deal was..Mediocre best describes this place..nothing special. The old lady prefers The Little Chihuaha so I imagine that's where we'll continue to go for Mexican food in San Francisco..
author: Morris D.

description:
Oh La Cumbre, how I love you. Been here numerous times but just tonight realized that I haven't written a review so I'll review the service I had tonight. You managed to piss me off and make me deliciously happy in 2 fell swoops. 

First I ordered a Chicken Fajita Burrito (zomfg, must get) and a Corona. Ten minutes later you somehow managed to forget that I had ordered a burrito, but the ladies there were nice enough to immediately start making it when I complained. Cut to while this was happening as I was standing up at the counter, someone came by and cleaned off my table so I lost my chips+salsa and what was left of my beer, I let it slide because I didn't feel like being _that_ asshole customer.

Then you almost immediately managed to make me deliciously happy by giving me a tortilla that wasn't fully cooked, so it was still a bit doughy. You made my night. So. Fucking. Good.
author: Jon U.

description:
Like many people here, I saw this place on Man Vs Food and decided to give La Crumbre a shot. To be honest, this place is only ok. There are many places in the Mission that have much tastier burritos and at better prices.

I wasn't disappointed per say, but I have no desire to return.
author: David D.

description:
Best Burritos your ever going to find !

I went here for lunch and got the Deluxe Chicken Burrito. The thing weighs at least 2 lbs. So just holding it lets you know that your in for some serious burrito.

They cook everything right in front of you at Taqueria La Cumbre. They have a big grill where they grill fresh vegetables and meats. The decor inside the place feels sincerely Mexican from the chandeliers to the archway above the door. You can tell that there is a lot of history here.

The line cooks make the burrito to your taste adding ingredients at your command.

This also feels like a real local favorite in the neighborhood. You can get a good sampling of the people that live here just by observing the customers of this place.

+ Best Burritos I've ever had
+ Great prices
author: Kristopher B.

description: I love this place.  I feel like everything is delicious and the employees are very kind.  I am a vegetarian and they have a lot of options that appeal to me.  They have a bunch of fresh salsas/extras (radishes, cilantro, onion) in their little salsa bar that makes it even better.  Although I feel like all the salsas are pretty hot in general.  Anyway, great food, I love it.
author: Sarah G.

description:
For a Mexican restaurant, this place was on one of the better ones that I have had thus far in San Francisco.  The individual dishes such as burritos and tacos are really good, but only if you select the correct meats.  The type of meats that I personally would recommend at any Mexican restaurant are Al Pastor, Lengua, and Chorizo.  Carne asade is more for like a Chipotle-chain restaurant than an authentic restaurant.

However, when you are out late at night, one of your best conclusions to the night is sharing a plate of hearty nachos.  I would not recommend the nachos at this place for groups because there are frankly some better options in San Francisco for that.  If you go to La Cumbre, make sure you get yourself a burrito or a taco.
author: Min P.

description:
This spot was actually featured on...what else...MAN V. FOOD. I mean, the host really hyped this place up for us, BIG TIME. So when I took my first bite, I was sort of disappointed.

Not to say that this place sucked, because believe me, when you have to have a fully stuffed burrito, this place will make one with the best of them. Just that MAN V. FOOD dude overhyped this place like it was the 2nd coming of Mexican, which I'm sorry to say isn't. Mission is full of hole-in-the-wall restaurants, and this is just one of many.
author: Geric O.

description: Man vs Food was wrong! Drove to San Fran from Ripon for a day trip. Made my husband hunt this place down just because it was on TV. It totally sucked. I even ordered exactly what he ordered. Taco trucks in Modesto are half the price and 10x better! No flavor in the meat, stale chips, and all tortilla. $8.50 is crazy high for this burrito. Stay away.
author: Veronica S.

description:
I was ravenous and the chicken burrito was a perfect answer to my hunger. However! I just want to say that the "super" burrito is a waste of those extra few dollars. The "extra" guacamole was the watery kind and there was seriously three shreds of lettuce.
What I did like was the crispy tortilla wrapper and the fresh, flavorful chicken.
author: Liane G.

description:
OH SO NOT A FAN.

I came here based on personal recommendation from strangers (that I met at Ike's sandwiches).  BLAH, the food is not amazing, the rice is blahhhhhhhhhhhhh.

Not super cheap like the couple said, I guess the portions were big.  Parking is bad...IDK, this place is over hyped.

This is a good place for late night (after club/bar hopping) restaurant, but other than that...my fellow YELPERS, you've got WUI (writing under the influence).
author: Steph L.

description:
Taqueria La Cumbre has the best pollo asado I've ever had.  The thing is they keep the whole breast marinating and don't chop it up until it's time to make your burrito/taco/whatever.  That keeps it very juicy and flavorful, I'm definitely a fan.

The only things I would have liked to be different would be using avocado instead of guacamole and melting the cheese on the tortilla or at least putting it on the hotter ingredients (beans/meat/rice) so that it would melt instead of on top of the lettuce and sour cream.  Still, this was a very tasty burrito.

Also, the chips are very good.  There are too many places where either the burrito or the chips are kinda weak; Taqueria La Cumbre is not one of them.
author: Joseph N.

description: Great place to go and get the all meat super burrito to soak up all those beers consumed at Zeitgeist.
author: Neilson V.

description:
I enjoyed eating here last night, possibly in large part because I was really, really hungry. Per usual. I had a fish taco and a prawns taco and I wasn't poisoned, which is always good. It's not a fancy establishment, but when I'm consuming tacos in a state of near-starvation, I don't want silverware or its ilk anywhere near me.

The wisest decision I made was to get vegetables with the prawns, because they were super damn good. There was zucchini, carrots, peppers and more, all juiced up and flavoring my mouth with fresh-tasting nourishment. I savored the shit out of those veggies, and I suspect they are the reason I'm giving this place such a high rating. I couldn't stop telling my friend how surprised I was by every mouthful, to the point where she had to try some and inevitably concur.

The fish was better than I thought it would be, although everything was soggy by the time I was even halfway through eating. I don't know why I was craving seafood so badly when I'm such a fiend for meat (the redder the better!), but I'm glad I ordered what I did. It was good! Also, I didn't get poisoned! (I'm so ecstatic about this that I feel it bears mentioning more than once. Yeah. I've had some bad experiences.) The end.
author: J P.

description: Sad to say.... Disappointed. Saw this place on Man v. Food and made a trip from 2 hours away with this taqueria on our list as one of our stops. First off, ordered the burrito I saw on TV and it came out nothing like what I saw. Asked the lady and she just kind of shrugged me off. Burrito was okay at best. Those of you that know Super Taqueria around the Bay I can tell you it ranked right there with Super Taq we also got the Super nachos, those were okay at best and a kids burrito that my kid loved. Overall I was disappointed because my expectations were set for a 10/10 but I felt I got a 5/10. If my expectations weren't set so high it may have reached a 7/10. Oh well.
author: Joe R.

description:
Saw this place on Man vs Food and decided to check it out.

We ordered super steak burritos.  The place was empty, but it took super long to get our food.  I was disappointed to see that the burrito was so small.  Couple bites into the burrito, and I noticed that the steak was super hard.  It was also chopped up, but the pieces that were too big for one bite.  We all agreed that the burrito sucked!  On top of that, the place was all smokey because they were grilling something.

SUPER BURRITO IS SUPER SMALL.
STALE PRE-COOKED MEAT.
DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE!!!
author: Danny L.

description: My friend Henry, Chuy and I were in town enjoying San Francisco.  My Friend suggested we eat @ Taquiera La Cumbre.  Glad he did.  The food was excellent.  They made us feel at home.  Comida Buena estilo casa.  Gracias.  I would strongly recommend you eat there.
author: Junior H.

description:
This place is super good. The servers there are really nice, and will make your burrito however you like it with a smile on their face. The decor is pretty enticing too. Big breasted latina with artillery belts strapped to her chest.

The guacamole was kind of weird, it was kind of watery, when I like it more thick. But they had corn at the bar you could help yourself to, which made up for that. Their chips are really delicious I think I ate two things of them.

I ordered their fajita burrito which was pretty good, but it was really greasy. I probably will order something else next time. Something with the oil and the veggies maybe. My friends ordered Super Nachos and they were HUGE! Maybe that's why this place is called La Cumbre because it was a 'summit' of nachos. :)
author: Xavier G.

description: I'm not sure why this place isn't more highly rated. I always get the carne asada burrito and it is DELICIOUS. The steak and cheese is soooooo good. They also have a great selection of flavorful salsas. If you're looking for a good burrito, this is your spot.
author: Jazmine S.

description:
I always get the super quisadilla suiza with chicken.  Always.  I like it - it's like a burrito, minus the rice and beans.  But today, I don't know what hit me.  I was in the grip of a force I could neither understand nor resist.  A voice in my head (possibly the same one that says his name is Mikey and keeps whispering "redrum - redrum") said "Have a taco!  HAVE A TACO!"

So I had two tacos.  Two carnitas tacos.  Two carnitas tacos con queso y aguacate.  Dios mio - those were some tasty tacos.  Get a fork - you're not finishing these with your fingers.

P.S.  Nice BIG cups for the free water!  How awesome is that?
author: Joe C.

description: I'm from L.A. So I know good Mexican food. I came here with huge expectations, total fail. I wanted something different from the burritos we have in LA. I had a carne asada super burrito, it was ok. I like the fact that they grill the meat instead of the griddle, but the beef was chewy. I found ut bizzare that they messure the meat with a salsa cup but whatevs. There spicy salsa is very spicy, its made with habanero but no flavor it needed some salt. The salsa ranchera with avocado was good. Its a ok burrito just dont expect too much. I tries a different burrito place on mission st and this is much better.
author: Ana G.

description: Good huge burrito. I liked it. Would I go back? Yes, probably. Am I still looking for the perfect burrito? Yes.
author: Christine A.

description:
Dry, dry, dry.  
I picked up a burrito at La Cumbre to bring to happy hour at Elixir and it was so dry I almost had to dip it in my beer to help force it down.  But this wasn't fourth of July and I hadn't entered a hot dog eating contest so I ended up with half a burrito uneaten.
author: phil h.

description:
OK, I didn't notice last night because I was drunk but, there was lettuce on my veggie burrito. That's not right. La Cumbre, you know that's not right but, I'll tell you why--- 

Because I've finally shaken my hangover and am ready to venture into the world of solid food by eating the other half of my burrito which was wrapped and put in a  bag while I was in La Cumbre's bathroom puking up 4 hours worth of liquor. 

I unwrap previously stated burrito, take a bite and am grossed out because lettuce doesn't keep. It gets soggy and screws up the whole texture and taste of the burrito. 

I don't want to be too negative so I will also say the service is good and the bathroom was very clean which is ideal when praying to the  gods.
author: R M.

description:
Only reason to eat here is if it's late night.

Otherwise, their burritos are just ok and their salsa doesn't have a very fresh quality to it.
author: Liz B.

description:
This place was decent. I came here after hearing about it on Man v. Food.  I ordered my standard "first time coming to a new taqueria" order: chicken burrito. I rate the burrito as slightly above average... the chicken was kind of bland, but everything else was good. However, I was disappointed in the chips, which didn't have a lot of flavor or substance to them.

If you're in the mission and want good Mexican, I'd recommend Pancho Villa or La Corneta instead.
author: Chad H.

description:
The wonderful, lovely thing about La Cumbre is that it has not changed a bit in twenty years. Everything tastes exactly the same as it did when I was in kindergarten, which is a nice feeling wherever you can find it.

Imagine my surprise upon entering the world of adults and finding that some people do not enjoy steamed tortillas with gooey cheese!? I mean, why not? I know you assholes are drunk most of the time anyway, so how can you be relied upon for credible critique?

Also, though other taquerias may boast a "better" or "more authentic" all-around burrito, I challenge you to find me more tender, fresher pollo asado anywhere in this town. If you can find me better grilled chicken, I will buy you a burrito. Unless you are ugly, in which case do not PM me. Thank you.
author: Megan W.

description:
This review is only for the regular taco with lengua, which is the only thing I've gotten here the various times I've eaten here.  I looked over the reviews on Yelp, and am now a little afraid to try the other items...and it must be admitted that I really feel that taquerias should be rated on the basis of the carnita.  However, the lengua is superb here, and I have not found lengua to match at other tacquerias.

What makes the lengua so great: first, it's tender.  As a friend explained to me, lengua must be made over a long period of time or it will be too hard to chew, and I've had experiences at other taquerias where the lengua just seemed hard to chew.  

Second, you can choose the lengua in a nice tasty salsa sort of sauce that permeates the lengua with this mild spiciness.  It's wonderful drenching the black beans and the tortilla.  It's crucial to get the chips that are free so that you can eat a good amount of the lengua and beans with the chips.  The tortilla gets rather soggy between the beans and the sauce in which the lengua is cooked.  However, near the end, I roll up the few pieces of lengua and small amount of beans and salsa and quickly stuff it into my mouth before it falls apart.  

By the way, if you haven't had lengua before...it's tongue.  It has a slightly gamey taste...sort of like what you might taste in lamb, but less strong (in my opinion).  I love lamb, so lengua works perfectly for my tastebuds.  Consult your tastebud before ordering lengua. 

Very cheap: taco is $2.40 ($2.60 with tax).  I might move up to the super taco with lengua next time.
author: Sooj O.

description: Eddie, you rate me a 1.5?  I've been spending money at your establishment for 10 years.  I order the same thing every time.  I know by watching them make my burrito exactly how much meat goes into my Chili Colorodo.  I AM NOT GETTING MY MONEY'S WORTH ANY MORE!  I rate you a ZERO!
author: Randy F.

description:
Ingredients in a Super Burrito:

-Beans...check
-Rice.....check
-Meat.....check
-Guacamole...check
-Cheese...check
-Sour Cream...check
-Salsa....check
-Lettuce.....ch-wait!  WTF?!?  Lettuce? In a burrito? Dude...No.
author: Jay H.

description:
See Jeff A's review... "la Chodumbre"

Unyummy all around. Been here once when I was STARVING and don't plan to return. The food just was not tasty at all.
author: Jill M.

description:
El Cumbre was not impressive. Though it claims to be the home of the original Mission burrito, you can tell that this place has been featured on perhaps too many Food Network shows. 

This place is just too pricey for what they offer (nothing special) and the local Mission folk have definitely noticed and gone elsewhere. You can find wonderful taquerias all over this area that are cheaper and the food might even be better.
author: Merrill S.

description:
Its sad that La Cumbre has been getting slammed by one star reviews  - and its even more unfortunate that it was on that stupid ass show (I didn't personally see it).  I'm actually a little pissed that they were on that show as their prices are increasing.  This is the ONLY place in SF that I would consider paying $8 for a delish Pollo Deluxe Burrito. Mmmm salivating just thinking about it.  I've always found that the Deluxe burritos are always too big for one meal for me.  So I have discovered a cheaper route - the Deluxe $4 taco.  Sure its still $4 for a taco - but its covered in delicious goodness - cheese guac sourcream salsa. yum.

I've tried the rest and still come back for the best.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Other reviews here seem to be for the al pastor burrito hyped up in Man v. Food. NOT A GOOD CHOICE. 

The burritos here are mediocre at best, and many of the meats are bland and unappealing. The pollo asada, however, is where La Cumbre really shines. 

Their chicken is flavorful, tender, smoky, and has a wonderful char. 

Order the pollo asada quesadilla. It's a lot of food for around 7 bucks and is tasty and filling. I've tried their burritos and taco and was as unimpressed as everyone else who has reviewed this place... but the pollo asada quesadilla keeps me coming back to La Cumbra again and again (despite abrupt service and an unexciting atmosphere) and earns La Cumbre 3.5 stars. I'll round up to 4 stars for being open late.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
looks like i beat the crowds here (if there ever was a crowd) plenty of parking in front.  first stop at the cashier's where i had to specify what i wanted: carnitas burrito (5.75) 

here or to go.? to go
kind of beans?  black beans 
spicy or mild? spicy. 
you think with so much specificity, the burrito would taste great. nope. it was average,  bland, the rice was slightly undercooked. per my experience,  these assembly line, scoop and run taquerias haven't satisfied me. i'll take any taco truck over any of these assembly lines any time.

salsa bar available. no free chips..friendly service. no repeat.
author: Victor G.

description: We tried this place last week. We ordered a steak burrito, and a shrimp quesadilla. Both were very good.
author: Joe M.

description:
Yum - perfect place to stop in on a Saturday afternoon in the Mission in the rain for a couple of carne asada tacos and a horchata.  Carne asada melted in our mouths, as usual.  I always love their selection of salsas and garnishes, but have to question the ranch dressing that they have alongside the rest of the stuff. 

What's up with that?
author: .Hon H.

description: Home of the mission burrito. Super fresh! The carne asada deluxe was awesome. Forget about splitting this with your friends. Get the giant and eat it. Very Delicious!
author: Marat P.

description:
Ohmygod. Best burritos...Big...lots of fillings..affordable.  The chicken is even bbq'd flavoring. SO good.  The strawberry juice is extremely sweet, but really good.  Plus it was my g-pa's favorite mexican food place so I always get a warm fuzzy feeling when eating there.  Just look at their logo..Badass chick! 
Definately go there.
Since I was wearing their shirt way before I had even eaten there, I am definately going to pick up another one..for the memories of my rad grandpa..and because it is rad in itself. yup. true story.
author: Sonya D.

description:
I first became enamored with La Cumbre in San Mateo so one day i decided to check out the original San Francisco store. It is still just as good. The burritos are packed with meat, rice, and the assorted fixins and the quesadillas are cheap and gooey with cheese! Today when I needed a quick snack, I got a corn quesadilla plus free chips for less than $2! What a marvelous deal!

You can talk in English or in Spanish to the folks who work here and they're polite, pleasant, and have a smile on their faces.

I recommend this place to anyone looking for a reasonably priced, delicious Mexican meal.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Nothing more disappointing than soggy tortilla chips 5 minutes into my meal. 

Also...Thank You, La Cumbre for using processed cheese in my nachos. 




NEVER AGAIN. 
I want my $4.79 back.
author: MJ T.

description: More often than not I wouldn't write a review, but on this one I just have to put the warning out there.  My wife and I had lunch this afternoon of Sat.  But the person taking our order was so slow and the person at the register.  I felt like she was just so bored.  No hello, thank you, or enjoy your meal.  I ordered grilled stake and my wife ordered a beef burrito.  The meat was tough and tasteless, so was the rice and beans, how can you mess that up?  I gave them I gave them 1 star because the salsa wasn't too bad.  The Taqueria on mission street is much better and tastier.
author: Francis W.

description: For some reason I went back.  I got a burrito this time.  It was worse than words could describe.  I hated myself in the morning for eating that garbage.
author: Christine M.

description: Worst taqueria in the area. Stay away. Dry chicken, dry carnitas. No redeeming qualities.
author: Blond E.

description: Stoned and inspired by a recent episode of Man vs. Food, a few of my friends and I decided Taqueria La Cumbre was the perfect solution to our evening munchies. Man, we were right! The asada super burrito kicked my appetite in the nuts, their salsa bar had all the right toppings for my side of tortillas. Just don't forget, the red baskets do not belong in the trash.
author: Mike S.

description:
Usually I crave burritos. Not from La Cumbre. I have been here twice now, both times after 10:30pm en route to catching the 22. So, kudos must be offered for being open late night. 

But, here is my -.02~
* white flour tortillas taste like they were thawed from frozen and have a been on the shelf too long aroma
* rice has crunchy dried out bits
* cheese might even be white shredded American, it melts like glue
* prices are not cheap for what you get
* chips made the bag greasy

and here is my +.02
* size is ok, enough to save for another snack
* staff is very friendly and quick and substituted without a problem

I really didn't like the looks of the fried food at the buffet line either, it had been fried hours ago. 

There are a lot of really great burrito places in the Mission. You will prolly only find yourself here more than twice if you are drunk or it is late.
author: Miel H.

description: Seriously the worst burrito I ever had, even by taco bell standards. Granted it was late after a night of drinking but I ordered a carne asada burrito and what I got was
author: Tony P.

description: This place was the best but I lost my taste buds from doing to much nitrous (never again) or the meat has lost its taste dramatically. My guess its little of both. I still would recommend though.
author: Ken M.

description:
I know why it's taken me 12 years to find this place. La Cumbre has been open since 1967 and still retains the same nondescript signage that is lost amongst the bolder new business signs. I've walked by this place many times and never would have given this dive a chance based on looks.

I've tried many burritos in the same area at different locations but found out today that it was my mistake in looking for style over sustenance.

If it weren't for the recent episode of MAN vs. FOOD on the FOOD Network I would have never given this place a chance. Thank goodness for my channel surfing habits.

The burritos we had were perfect. I had the regular grilled chicken with black beans and spicy salsa...pretty basic but a purist approach in getting the flavors of the meat.

This was the best chicken burrito I've had in the 12 years I've been in SF. I'm going to have to sacrifice my current Burrito supplier for La Cumbre.

Excellent.

Oh yeah the pricing... 2 regular burritos and 2 bottled waters with chips and guacamole... $15. Pretty good.
author: Peter M.

description: The burritos here are amazing!!  I have been here twice now and each time I left full and happy!!  I got a super burrito with steak and it was perfect (i got the steak fresh off the grill) and my lady got the pork again which was just as good as last time.  I saw some negative reviews of this place and i dont get it when i was there everything was good, no complaints from me!!
author: Ben S.

description: Place is gross! Food is awful... very dissappointed too.
author: Di G.

description: Adam Richman host of Man vs Food is a great actor. The burrito was nasty, cold and flavorless.  The chicken was drenched in bbq sauce.
author: Linda W.

description:
I had a pollo en chile rojo super burrito here, yesterday (sans lettuce, for better reheat-ability.)  The chicken was super tender and flavorful, and I really enjoyed the burrito.  My roommate (who is absolutely amazing but will probably never read this) got the carne asada taco combination plate. Te quac was far too liquidy.. it slid off the chips we tried to use to consume it.  Also, the rice was a little too firm, but maybe that's just my personal preference.  This isn't cheap for mexican food - my super burrito was $8 and her taco plate was around $10.  But it was yummy and pretty clean.

Oh one thing I liked very much was that the wrapped my burrito with ample aluminum foil so that packing up the second half of it to go was a breeze.
author: Katharine H.

description:
While drunkenly stumbling threw the Mish on a bar hoping excursion, with a great friend of mine, we tumbled into this little gold mine. 

We split a chicken burrito it was fantastic, and ginormous! Got to say if your drunk and in the mood for some food, This place is ten times better then Sparky's. Hell, I'd even eat here sober!
author: Ariona E.

description: Whenever I'm in SF or San Mateo, I hit up La Cumbre for the best burritos ever.  I grew up on these burros and there's nothing better. I've had a ton of other burros from all over and nothing compares to the original.  I don't understand the poor reviews.  Perhaps people were too drunk (based on their descriptions of drinking, late at night, etc) to taste the goodness that is the La Cumbre experience.  Viva La Cumbre!
author: Patrick B.

description: I should have read the yelpers reviews instead of relying on the Man vs. Food episode.  Walked all the way from my hotel in the Fisherman's wharf area for the burritos and was disappointed. Small burritos and pricey... hate to say it AND i never thought I would say this, but Chipotle does it better. Bigger burritos and for the price.... better value. Save the walk and give it a pass.
author: Jacquie L.

description:
What a disappointment!  I ate a TOTALLY flavorless burrito.  I got the super carnitas buritto.  Where the heck is the sour cream or guacamole??!!! I can't taste it at all!
