I ended up heaping on salsa to give it something, but it was just plain bad.  I am a burrito lover and I will be happy with most burritos, but I was actually shocked at how bad this was.  I want my 9 bucks back!  

PS. I also really didn't like how the burrito maker only put like 4 little pieces of small diced onion after I asked for onions.
author: Cat R.

description: I've been eating here since high school and love this place. when folks come back in town this is always one of the stops. the burritos are awesome, get the thick green salsa and enjoy.
author: Matt R.

description: Preetttyy good? Was not too impress and only because it came out on man v food . I believe they hyped it up too much. However I will say it was pretty good .. I had the Carne Asada burrito.
author: Debbie D D.

description:
Question:  It's 1:00 AM, I have $3 left in my wallet after spending all my money at the bars in the Valencia and 16th vicinity and I'm hungry, what do I do?

Answer:  Head over to Taqueria La Cumbre.  The meat tacos are filling and under $3 and for vegetarians, the bean tacos are under $2.
author: Josh K.

description:
Wow, how many of us came here after Man v Food aired it?

This was my first trip to the Mission District, and I stopped by just to check this place out. Everyone has said good things about the burritos, so of course, I went for a burrito. 

Having the attention span of a fly, I took one look at the HUGE menus on the wall and simply blanked out for a second. Then I spotted the burrito list and decided to focus on that. 

I went for the deluxe burrito with chicken. May I first say that I was happy to see that the burrito stayed wrapped for the entire meal. Second, I was sad because I couldn't finish it (I got full!). Third, I see what some people were saying about the small portions of meat. I could've done with a little more chicken, but to be honest, I liked it so much that I would have been fine with a veggie burrito. It filled me up without that "bowling ball in your stomach" feeling, which was good because I went for a stroll afterwards. 

So far, this was one of the best burritos I've had since I moved to Cali, but we'll see if that remains the case once I've sampled a few more taquerias. ;)
author: Angel W.

description:
The most amazing quesadilla and burritos. All that needs to be said. Run there now or after a late night of drinking in the Mission. 

THE END.
author: Arin N.

description: The best burritos in the mission! Fast clean and oh so bomb! Their salsa bar is also top notch with cilantro for dayyyys!
author: Ashley O.

description:
Really flavorful and fresh tasting.  I normally do not order burritos, but here I get the chicken fajita burrito and it is delicious with plenty of veggies.  Downsides: Their salsas area a little bland (I find myself just using plenty of lime); It is actually a little expensive for the area (but satisfying).

Food: 3/5
Service: 3/5
Ambiance: 1/5
author: M R.

description: I appreciate this taqueria for two things, one: they use olive oil and two, I've never been to a taqueria that puts so much love and carefulness while marinating and grilling the meat. The outcome and taste is exquisite! Every bite is heaven.. Try this place for flavor and quality, the prices are fair and you will not be disappointed!
author: Carlos C.

description: The regular burrito at La Cumbre is small, but it sure does pack a punch. I just finished eating a charbroiled chicken burrito and I must say despite the small size of it, it tasted really good. I thought the burrito was going to be on the drier side because there was no cream or guac in it, but I was mistaken. I won't say this is my favorite place in SF, but just because they fry their own chips or at least it tastes like it. I will give them the benefit of the 4 stars. In terms of other great burritos around the area, I have one secret spot that I will share with you, but I need to go there sometime soon and take a picture of my experience before I can post a review about them.
author: Michael J.

description: Tasty food but I got a stomach ache after eating there. I can't confidently blame la cumbra so I'll give it another try in future
author: Ori N.

description: I recently dined at Taqueria La Cumbre per the suggestion of Theodore O. Actually, we dined together. I ordered the lean pork plate with rice, beans and corn tortillas. I skipped an "adult" beverage in favor of a strawberry agua fresca. While I found these food and drink choices very enjoyable, I must resist giving this taqueria additional stars until I sample more items on their extensive menu. Kudos to the male member of the staff who firmly escorted the homeless man from the restaurant after he harassed us for food!
author: Camille K.

description: Wow this place is so over rated by the media, the food was "garbage" that's all needs to be said. Do yourself a favor and go to La Corneta or somewhere else YUK..... I'm pissed I fell into the rumors this place was good.
author: Alexander D.

description: My friends and I came here after a night of barhopping, anticipating some great Mexican food. But unfortunately, this place was pretty bad. I ordered a regular grilled chicken burrito, and what I got after paying almost 6 bucks was undercooked rice and dry and tough chicken in this really skinny burrito. I was hella hungry so I still downed it, but it was not pleasant. Definitely overpriced compared to other taquerias in the Mission. 1 star for the food, and an additional star for being one of a few places open late on that block of Valencia. Next time I'm out in that area of the Mission, I'll try that pizza place next door instead.
author: Amanda K.

description: I love this place I've been going to this spot since I was just a little one... Great food nice ppl but sometimes I come out smelling like I was the one grilling.
author: Josué P.

description:
I love how Steph C. just took it away with the first description being the chick fight before the food itself.

Yes, there was a chick fight there which lasted like 10 mins after the verbal escalation of another 10 mins.  You can imagine how long this wait in line is now during the after hours (2am)

But yes, the chick fight was brutal, two girls were going at it on the floor with one chick using her stilletos to hit the other girl.  When the cops busted in and took them out, the first girl had a small cut or something on her eye and the other girl's entire forehead was buldging and swelling like crazy.  And of course, there was the interim rent a cop that came from the grill behind the counter who manned the door and gated off the restaurant.  

As for the food.....my burrito was kind of dry and come on, if i'm drunk and I'm not too excited bout my burrito, it's just not doing it.  Maybe it just needed more guac or something, but I'm going to say no to my burrito.  

The nachos were good and you could tell since we got the super nachos which were stacked up and by the end, there was barely any left.  And everyone knows that when drunk people order nachos, theres always leftover since our eyes are bigger than our stomach.  Nope, we killed this nacho.
author: Vincent K.

description:
I like the picture of the broiled chicken with the bikini tan-lines that says something like "our chicken may not look great, but it tastes the best."

Anthropomorphizing the food I'm about to eat is always a win, and reminds me of that classic "Cluckin Chicken" commercial from SNL in the 90's: http://www.hulu.com/watch/2317/saturday-night-live-cluckin-chicken (Whee, look at me!  I'm getting quartered and split!)

Anyway, La Cumbre DOES have very good chicken.  Overall the chicken burritos are solid, big and filling but nothing fantastic.  Crispy, freshly made chips and good salsa also add to the quality.

They tell me the tacos are great, I will try them and get back to you.
author: Kevin H.

description: I was bar hopping with my buddy the other night until we walked past this place. I realized that I had seen it many times on the Food Network and Travel Channel, so we decided we had to go in and try it out. I ordered the regular burrito, which was pretty good but at the same time reminded me of Chipotle. I later realized how many other items they have on their menu, so next time I'm there I'll be sure to order something different. I didn't think I got the full experience, but it was still good nonetheless. Quick service and chill atmosphere.
author: Anthony L.

description:
There are many taquerias in this neighborhood who do al pastor better...

I should've went with the chicken...
author: Nathan W.

description: Went back for their carne asada burrito: AMAZING! Very delicious, with options for the spicy (yes!) and spicy-phobic. Comes with chips and a salsa bar. Beware of the salsa verde, she is a spicy little devil!
author: David P.

description:
Definately FAIL.

I recently moved to SF from the east bay and have been trying to find a good taqueria...so...
I too decided to try this place out after seeing it on man vs. food... only to be greatly dissapointed. My husband ordered the super burrito.. but their was nothing super about it, and we've definately had bigger at other taquerias. 
I ordered the taco salad, which super sucked. The grilled chicken they used tasted like it was slathered in bbq sauce which made it taste not mexican at all. 

This place pretty much just sucked, and i will definately not be back. 
The search for a great sf taqueria continues. .*sigh*
author: Viv D.

description: Favorite!! They have the BEST al pastor and burrito I have ever had. You can either take your time and eat in, or have it to go! Their service is speedy, but never rushing.
author: Kiley W.

description:
I read some of your reviews of La Cumbre.  Apparently, many of you who gave this place 5 stars were drunk when you stopped by this place.  Figures.  I am sure when you're drunk, hung over, or when you get the munchies at 3 am, this place is the cat's meow.

When I came here for lunch earlier today, sober and a little tired, I didn't feel like I got 5-star food.  It's no La Taqueria, let me tell ya, although the decor is surprisingly similar.

I have a lot of, umm, eccentricities, and one of them is that I don't like wrapped foods: you know, burritos, chicken wraps and whatnot.  I feel that eating something wrapped is akin to injecting yourself with food.  Food should be enjoyed, not wrapped in a giant tortilla for your convenience.  

But I digress.  Anyway, I try to order a platter whenever possible.  This time I had a combination platter: carne asada, pollo asada, re-fried beans, rice, lettuce, tomato and cucumbers.  This, with some tortillas, guacamole and sour cream, set me back $11.  The chicken was good, but the steak was a bit overcooked.  I really liked that they cooked it in front of you.  It was definitely fresh, but not that great.  Their version of guacamole was this weird looking liquid . . . it really looked more like an avocado agua fresca.  I had no intention of trying it.  Corn tortillas were small and excessively greasy.

They said that La Cumbre was the original San Francisco taqueria, and I believe it.  Although "La Cumbre" means "The Summit," "original" hardly means "best."  I'd rather pay a couple bucks more and go to La Taqueria.
author: Yan G.

description:
This place is a classic of sorts.  La Cumbre is nothing at all fancy, just a row of steam tables brimming with chile verde, rojo, chicken, steak, etc.  Many people claim this to be the standard Mission burrito, with the carne asada holding the gold standard, but I'm of another opinion.  Mostly I think it's just your average, cheap Mexi-cali filler.

So what would make someone come here, when there's so many other great Mission taquerias around, besides the "must have food, before I pass out" instinct that typicaly overtakes one near the corner of 16th and Valencia?  Why of course it's the Cumbre!  . . . which is what exactly?  As the guy behind the counter explained, it's something like the Peak, of a mountain.  And taking one glance at the lusty bosom of the gun-toting revolutionary that is La Cumbre's menu mascot, yes I begin to see it, two reasons to come back, very metaphoical reasons if you will.  But that's it, nada mas.
author: Todd E.

description:
One of the worst burritos I've had in the city, and that includes some that were made by my gringo self at home in the middle of the night while I was drunk.

The steak is just plain bad.  Poorly butchered, overcooked, and not very flavorful, it's hard to recover from.  Adding ridiculous things that have no place in a burrito (gargantuan slices of tomato?!?  what looks like an entire head of lettuce?) is not a good way to recover.

I only give it two stars because I HAVE had worse mexican food.  It was in Eugene, Oregon, but still.  At least La Cumbre isn't the absolute worst.  Probably just the worst taqueria in a neighborhood full of amazing mexican food.  If it weren't for drunk people who didn't know the mission, I imagine this place would be long closed and forgotten.
author: Adrian L.

description:
This place is delicious. I don't know if its the fact that I'm usually only here at 3 in the morning when I'm starving from alcohol induced hunger, or if its the perfectly proportioned steak to sour cream to guacamole ratio. Or maybe its the chips and salsa escorting my burrito.

The price is awesome, all that deliciousness, and they are open like all hours of the night which is really all I'm asking cause when I'm inebriated, the last thing I want to stop me is your crappy hours. 

Not to mention there is always somewhere to sit. I think we have sat at the same table basically every time I've been here.
author: Sarah S.

description:
At best this taqueria is a 2.5.

Like every other reviewer, I also was attracted to this Taqueria after seeing it on an episode of Man V. Food.  Dont believe the hype, this joint is mediocre at best.  We ordered the Carne Asada Super Burrito and regular nachos with cheese and jalapenos.  The nachos were pretty good, but you cant really fail at putting cheese and jalapenos on top of chips.  Actually, the cheese was cold- not even warm, so that could be considered a FAIL.  The meat was cooked in front of you, but it tasted rubbery.  The only good thing is that the service was pretty quick and that it didnt taste as greasy as other burrito spots.

There are definately more places that are better like EL FAROLITO, LA GUADALAJARA, LA VICTORIA's (san jose)... Better bang for your buck!  

Will not be in a rush to go here again.
author: roe n.

description:
This place is delicious and inexpensive Mexican Food.  The Nachos and Quesadilla are my top recommendations and the quantity of food for the price is really good here (Pancho Villa has less food per $, but their burritos are better)

If you are looking for an amazing quesadilla or nachos, this is the place to go.  Their quesadillas are some of the biggest you will find in the Mission and they are stuffed with Guacamole and Sour Cream - Mmmmmm.  I usually like the Chicken quesadilla but the pork or Carne asada also works.

The Carne Asada Nachos are the best in the Mission.  A secret is if they ask if you want white or orange cheese get both.  The white cheese is standard the orange cheese is that cheap nacho cheese you get at the ballparks that is frickin' amazing yet questionable.  Well, the combo makes for an inspiring and delicious plate of nachos.  My roomate and I used to get this pair of food almost every sunday for football games.  Since then we've grown slightly more health conscious (it wasn't just La Cumbre that was our downfall) and have cut back a little.

The burritos, tacos, etc. are pretty good here but not the best, but the nachos and quesadillas, are where it's at.
author: Bryce G.

description: Cheap tasty eats after bar hopping in the Mission! After visiting Casanova and Elbo Room, my friends and I get here early (12am) to avoid the crowds that come in after the bars close down. I usually order the beef taco. They've got the most excellent salsa. Beef was super tasty too, not dry at all. They're hella cheap too, about 3 bucks a taco. I usually order 2-3 w/ a nice cold horchata, depending on how drunk I am. Look for the quirky ads they put up by the windows, makes for something fun to read while you're drunk!
author: Thomas L.

description:
I'm hungry for a mission burrito. Cancun perhaps? No, the person I'm with has sore feet from standing in pointy, high-heeled shoes all night, and that's too far of a walk. So I will give La Cumbre a shot. Afterall, how bad could a burrito be? Especially after a night of drinking...

Well, apparently really bad. Tough meat, dry beans, watery rice, too much lettuce, avocado paste. Why God? Why would you let someone do this to a burrito?
author: Texture D.

description:
Adelita, the restaurant's mascot, is absolutely beautiful. I can't say the same about the food.

While tasty, their chicken torta leaves a lot to be desired. I went in there hoping to get full from a nice $5 torta only to leave with a stomach half full. For the $8 I spent, I could have exploded at other places (of course, the reference to Taqueria Can-Cun).

Try it out. If you don't like it, don't come back. At least look at the beautiful pictures on the wall.
author: Haz O.

description:
After a visit to Burritophile, I have successfully ascertained that this is where I got my burrito on last night after the tequila had taken full control of my body.  Not wanting my mexican invaders to turn the lights off and make this another lost evening, I fought fire with fire.  Actually, I probably would have just gone and got an Arinell's slice to ogle my gangly filthy pizza boyfriend, but it was after closing time.  Bummer.

Anyway, my burrito kind of rocked.  I mean, I would never come here sober because in my mind I have it filed away under "Cheesy Mission Mexican".  However,  even the lettuce, tomato, and questionable guacamole did not deter my enjoyment of my long thick tube.  It was over $8 which is pretty lame, but I think it was girthier than your average piece.  And god, do I love the girth.  

Soooooo....yeah.  I guess if you're drunk in the mission and not in the mood for any Colombian specialties, this will do!
author: Coco D.

description: A super burrito more lackluster than Pancho Villa's so-so offerings less than a block away. My puerco chili verde super burrito from La Cumbre wasn't temperature hot enough, lacked the heat of good salsa, and had bland ingredients thrown together less than lovingly. The chips that came with it were an afterthought and few in number. If I'm going to pay over $8 for a burrito I'll go to Pancho's instead... or better yet I'll walk the four blocks to Can Cun and get the best burrito I've had in SF for $6 and some change.
author: Dirty D.

description: We got overcharged for our food (beyond the fact that it was overpriced to begin with). I just spit out a dime i found in my burrito (th reason im writing this). The rice was hard because it was undercooked--who knows what else could have happened to it.  The place was packed with annoying drunk hipster yuppies pouring out of the bar--enough said.
author: Aaron B.

description:
What a crazy night I had here! I went in to get a bite before going to partake of all the bars on this street.

I was waiting in line when the girl in front of me kept giving these scatterbrained orders to the lady preparing her tacos. The girl then proceeded to stand there and let her eyes roll to the back of her head so that you could only see the whites of her eyes. That one move told me everything I needed to know about her. (crack head) 

I ordered my taco. Let's see... what kind of taco to get? I look on the board and there's a quick blurb as to how they had the best chicken ever. Ok Chicken taco it is!

As I was paying for the taco I hear two girls in the restaurant scream bloody murder. They jump up and down and all I can see is spilled beer and these girls huddled in a corner. The workers are all laughing. I ask my cousin what happened and she says, "You didn't see the rat?" 

Me: Rat?

Cousin: Yeah it just walked out the door all slowly (cousin mimics something fat slowly waddling out the door)

Me: Ok...

Hahahah this did not stop me from eating my taco at the establishment. I just wanted to eat it a little faster. My taco was brimming with ingredients. Pico de gallo, chicken, and black beans. It was so packed I had to get a fork to eat it. The chicken had a nice bbq flavor to it. Good deal for the price but nothing spectacular about the taste really. And ok... maybe the rat soured my experience a little.

That was a colorful start to my night out drinking in the Mission.
author: kimy l.

description:
Hmmm...rethinking my 4 stars with all of the other mediocre reviews. I will preface my experience at La Cumbre with the fact that I was totally loaded and we literally ordered 5 rounds of beers, were totally obnoxious and I asked an ambulance driver if I could send a message over the dispatch (he said no). However, the carnitas were so so so good. Maybe It's because I was drunk, but I am telling you, some of the best ever--flavorful, not too fatty and just that right amount of crisp. 

Just one warning: do NOT order a churro! It was the stalest, grossest churro ever. When a bunch of drunkards turn down a churro, you know that something's wrong...
author: Nicole S.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 96

The burrito definitely does the job but I still haven't found the Mission equivalent for Ocean Taqueria. Everything with the burrito is A OK fuh sho.

The new (or new to me) cashier is cool. He's reminds me of a stand up comedian you would see at the Holiday Inn Bar or something.

Well, working in the mission will definitely give me the chance to get to know some great places to dine....
author: Kristina C.

description:
Among others' opinions here on this website, La Cumbre is a taqueria that I grew up with in SF and loved ever since 1980.

The carne asada burrito has always been the best around town.  You must get the 'ranchera' sauce (roasted green chile salsa) and fresh avocados to go with it.

For the adventurous types, try the Lengua (beef tongue) tacos...always my dad's favorite when he comes into town...
author: Michael C.

description: The next time a Southern Californian tells you about how "real Mexican food tastes" where they're from, tell 'em they can suck it.  I had Mexican food in San Diego, Los Angeles, and all throughout Orange County and I can say that this is very easily the best Mexican food that I've had anywhere (in fairness: I've never been south of the border).  I highly recommend the quesadillas, the burritos, okay, just about everything.
author: Jason T.

description:
Love the carne asada tacos.  I agree with others, the quesadillas are good too.  The burritos are kind of pricey, and more food than I can manage in a single sitting.

This is a great bargain choice amongst all the chi-chi places littering Valencia.
author: SF G.

description: I had a taco here at 3:30 in the morning, after I went dancing and drank a lot. I have passed by a million times. The al pastor taco deluxe was a perfect size and a fair price. It isn't as soul-shaking as, say El Metate, but you can't beat it for convenience. I saw a very interesting fist fight develop between 2 hipster patrons, which originated (somehow) from one of the meats not being available (I also suspect cocaine was involved).
author: Andrew K.

description:
I give this place 3.5 stars only because I think the prices are a bit high.  A veggie burrito will run about $5.00, which I guess may be standard, but  c'mon, beans, cheese, and rice should not cost $5.

I only ever get their veggie burrito or veggie tacos, so I can't speak to the meat dishes, but their veggie burritos and tacos are fantastic.  My roomates rave about beef (not sure what kind) enchiladas here.

They're open late which is a plus, and the staff is nice.
author: D. M.

description:
Well, I decided to check this place out because I heard this was the birthplace of the SF Mission style burrito.  This place is overrated.  There are a few positive points about this place that I can start out with.  The ingredients are fresh.  The meat is seemingly grilled to order (BBQ pork and grilled chicken are both great).  And as mentioned over and over, the portions are LARGE, so if you're a light eater, you can split a super burrito, super nachos, or super anything.  However, the less than stellar reviews are spot on.

I'd give this place 2 stars had I not known this place could be where the Mission style burrito was invented.  The rice and beans are terribly bland.  Not only that, they dominate the burrito, so it's hard to taste all the other things in the burrito.  The guacamole is fairly watery and not very tasty.  So do you want a huge burrito that isn't particularly tastey?  The only positive spin I can put on this is since this place is open late, it might be good after drinking if you're around the area.  The only other suggestion I can give is to just get a meat filled burrito and skip the beans and rice.

service is ok
where the food is prepped looks very clean
parking can be hard to find, but not too bad.  meter fed
author: John D.

description: Come here when you're drunk and want to try La Cumbre's rubber asada. I eat meat, but there's something unethical about cooking it this poorly.
author: Huey K.

description:
Good food, open late, quick friendly service is a plus for a place that, at 1am, is dealing with a good deal of drunks.  Had a taco, which was piled high with meat, veggies, and guacamole.  Chips included were good too, and a nice selection of salsas and such were offered too.

Overall, decent place, nice late night stop too.
author: Eric M.

description:
unfortunately this place is not that tasty - carne asada is dry, the carnitas are crap, etc...I can go on and on...and on.... but...it strangely has the best quality tasting chicken compared to the other taquerias in and around 16th & Valencia. It was a shocking discovery....

my advice....If you just desire a regular chicken taco (w/beans & salsa) I would recommend this spot over the other ones...avoid the other crapola on their menu....
author: Tony R.

description:
La Cumbre is the wind beneath my wings! I don't think there is any better burrito than the big juicy meaty ones here!  

I love how they pack the burritos full of fresh hot off the grill meat!  And you could even order all meat ones, which are a favorite of my roommate, Albert.  But I like to get the regular supremes, because the guacamole and the black beans are so fresh and complement the meat really well.   The grease makes it taste so good too!  

FYI: The burritos taste exponentially better post-bar or club!  I guess that's true for all food though... 

All I need is a huge chicken burrito from La Cumbre, an ice cold cerveza, some good friends, a Laker game on Tv, and I'm set!
author: James C.

description: If it weren't because this place was featured in Man vs. Food, I probably would not have stopped by.  I ordered the Carne Asada Burrito which was tasty but nothing spectacular.  Maybe I was expecting too much from a place featured on TV.
author: Ha T.

description:
La Cumbre is a little gritty. Not exactly the cleanest place on the block, but they stay open really late on most weekends for the drinking crowd even though it doesn't say it anywhere. In fact, I think their sign says they close at like 11 or something on Saturdays. I've been there way past 3AM more than once.

The food's... ok. My usual arbitrary burrito metric is Pastor. Most places do it a little differently, but it's usually an indicator of how everything else fares as well. Al Pastor here is often just the right amount of oil and reasonably tender. Nothing too special.

Geek stats: plenty of open wifi to snarf, only one outlet that I've found; have to get the right table
Occasionally they have Jolt in the fridge too.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Rating varies as follows: 
food consumed while intoxicated: 3 stars
food consumed while sober: 2 stars

The one thing La Cumbre has going for it is that it's never full, so if you find yourself out on the weekend and all of the top restaurants in the area are maxed out, you're guaranteed a spot here.  The food isn't all that great, but if you're hungry like the wolf and are facing an hour wait for Puerto Allegre, Little Star, or Luna Park, you shall be fed just a short distance away.  Totally tolerable when ravenous - especially if a lot of alcohol has already made it into your system.
author: Marie S.

description: Wow, nearly the worst food experience ever. Ordered a carne asada burrito, tortilla was too old/chewy so took it apart to attempt to eat what was inside. The tiny bits of meat were dry and had no flavor. They "measure" the amount of meat put inside by using a tiny salsa container cup (the kind you fill to take salsa home with you). One tiny cup of meat is used to put in the entire burrito, leaving the rest of it filled with rice and beans. Pretty disappointing as the tiny amount of meat didn't even have any flavor. I had to throw the whole thing away and feel very ripped off.
author: Steven A.

description:
Great spot. 
Ridiculously large portions. My gf ordered the chicken soup and it had half a chicken in it. They also had a Tiger Prawns burrito?! Whoa.
Amazing food. Classic taqueria vibe. They had a mexican flag-colored miller lite guitar on the wall for god's sakes. Just cool.
There is a ton of mexican in the mission, but this is high on the list.
author: Andy B.

description: Look no further for your authentic Mission style burrito joint.  Forget Chipotle, screw Qdoba and those other chains...La Cumbre has ruined me on burritos and in a good way!  I first visited this joint in 1999, when I visited San Francisco for the first time.  at the time, I wouldn't necessarily call myself a big Mexican food fan, but I became one in the years following.  I was amazed by the freshness of their food.  They make everything right in front of you, and you can pretty much customize your own burritos, tacos, salads...I've always opted for the vegetarian style with rice, beans, guac, salsa, cheese and sour cream.  It never lets me down.  My cousin has lived in the Bay area for almost 40 years, and this was the first place he ever had a burrito and he's disappointed if he goes someplace else.  I think that speaks volumes (since he has to drive in from far away now to get there!).  I also get disappointed if I can't make it to La Cumbre when I'm in town.  And just know - NYC "mission style burritos" pale WAY in comparison to this place.  This is the real deal holy-feel!
author: Taryn C.

description: I am yet again truly baffled by some of these reviews. La Cumbre exemplifies a fantastic Mission Taqueria. From the fantastic salsa bar, to the well seasoned grilled meats in the burritos, this place is great!  Something I have realized about Taquera's in S.F, is that they may do great burritos, and o.k tacos, but that's about it. If you want good enchiladas for example, FORGET IT..Nowhere makes a solid Guajillo chilli sauce. You have to go to So Cal or the Central Valley  for that..Strange, but very true...
author: Tim E.

description: this place was closed at 1130 they need to update the time on here.
author: Christopher W.

description:
I have only been to La Cumbre twice and both times have been after a night of drinking in the Mission. I'm giving it 3 stars because it's reliable, tasty, and gets the job done. It's been donned our '2 AM burrito' spot. 

Last night I had the deluxe carnitas burrito which came with: guac, sour cream, rice, beans and a side of chips. The carnitas were flavorful. Pretty much your standard taqueria fare. Their salsa bar is great idea since you can grab as much salsa, pickled jalapenos, and canned corn (yes! canned corn) as you'd like. 

If you don't finish your food - there's foil you can grab to wrap it up.
author: Cecilia L.

description: I love Mexican food. It's one of my favorite cheat foods. This place was underwhelming at best. Ordered an all meat carne asada burrito with guacamole. The meat lacked flavor and $10 for a burrito? Forget it, I rather go somewhere else. Also, red salsa is suppose to taste smoky and mildly spicy. Instead it was really sweet. I don't get it.
author: Jenny J.

description: Atmosphere is divey, and vegetarian options are limited. That said, for someone looking for a meat-filled Mexican burrito, it's hard to do better than La Cumbre.  Their burritos have flavor like no other.
author: Joaquin E.

description: Pretty average Mexican food, among many other Mexican options in the Mission.  The burrito I had was huge, but not particularly extraordinary.  Not bad, but nothing special.
author: Tamara N.

description: Oh, La Cumbre, I really wish I liked you more. I always hear great things about this place, and so this weekend, I finally went. What a letdown. I'm not saying the food wasn't good. It just wasn't Great. The meat was somewhat lacking in flavor and tenderness, and the tortillas weren't even that warm. Saddest part, the salsa. I love salsa. I really do. But this salsa was not good. The chunks of jalapeno were too big, there was no zest or kick to it. It just tasted like I was eating tomatoes and jalapenos plain. What a bummer. Adam Richman failed to mention that, didn't he?
author: Taryn S.

description: Love this place! Burritos are fairly priced, good sized, and you get chips with your burrito. Plus the self-serve "extras" bar is pretty stacked. Lots of seating and relatively clean. I'll definitely be back, but this place can't beat El Farolito down the street (taste-wise)!
author: Brad Y.

description: This place is great. Came here not too long ago and this place can definitely pack a punch. I recommend the grilled asada or chicken because they are constantly making it and you know its the freshest off the menu. I will definitely swing back through there for another adventure.
author: Richard G.

description:
Hurry Hurry help her, help a fellow Yelper. grilled pollo plates,      carna asada dates. limon flavored Jarritos, steak stuffed tacos. 16th and Valencia,  


 La Cumbre  is a old school taqueria that grills your meat right in front of you. I've been going here since the early 90's when I used to hang out with this Christian after school recreation center. God bless to Mike Ditaranto and Phil, without them I probably wouldn't have had such a fun childhood. La Cumbre just makes me reminisce of when it was dangerous to walk around 16th street. And the only people that went to THE MISSION were locals.
author: John L.

description: The general rule so far has been that each Mexican restaurant in the Mission does one thing good and everything else mediocre. This place has awesome nachos. I'm not sure what it is about them, but they are great.
author: Alfredo A.

description: Steak burrito was the best in years. Great flavor. Like the old original La Cumbre. Tortilla was a little off - too dry.  I'd been maybe 3-5 years ago, and it has improved. I'm going back!
author: Josh F.

description:
Very bland, do not believe the HYPE! There are other places that have BIGGER AND BETTER BURRITOS!


RATING: GARBAGE!
author: Jammy J.

description: Really tasty chicken tacos, but when they ask what type of beans, just skip the beans. All it does is dilutes the taste of the chicken, and the chicken is good enough to stand on its own. Everyone on staff is incredibly friendly too. I was trying to decide what to get and they kept giving me free samples. Awesome people.
author: Dan I.

description:
What a pleasant surprise this place turned out to be.  We stopped in here not expecting much.  The atmosphere is old and a bit run down and out of date.  Nothing fancy here.  But they made one of the best burritos I have had at a decent price.  I had a prawns and fish burrito and it was made exactly how I asked it to be made and even better.  They filled it with lightly cooked fresh vegetables in addition to normal burrito fare and actually used good prawns with flavor.  In a word, excellente'!

The menu also has plenty of vegetarian option for you veggie lovers and vegans.

Don't come here for the atmosphere come here for the eats.
author: Scott A.

description:
This place is pretty awesome!!  Great food, good service and clean bathrooms. I am a major burrito critic but this place uses lean beef and the salsa is very tasty!

For desert, try the churros, they are even better when they are hot and fresh!
author: Sandra W.

description: The chicken fajita burrito was amazing!  Also, got a chorizo con huevos breakfast burrito and it was off the chain!!  The place is excellent, decently priced.  2 burritos, 2 drinks for less than $20, not a bad deal for San Francisco dining!  Plus my son loved the tortilla chips and refried beans as dip.  Very authentic and friendly.  And amazingly close to the BART so i don't have to drive and fight for parking....  Kid friendly too!
author: jesse m.

description:
Saw it on Man vs. Food, headed over there with my BF & brother.  We have a few fave burrito spots and were hoping to add Cumbre to the list. No way! It's not gross but certainly not great! We were hungry and smoked yet the burritos were not good.
We all got carne asada burritos.
I'm sure Caucasian people will like it.
As a Latina, no.
author: Chris C.

description:
Open after the bars let out. A menu the size of a high-school football scoreboard and very reasonable prices. The folks who run the place are friendly and quick, once you get through the long line.

After last call, just tell the cabbie 16th and Valencia!

(There's also a decent pizza joint next door that also stays open after hours.)
author: Mike p.

description: I used to like this place and their burritos but the past two visits, I'm starting to see a negative pattern develop. In the past, I've disregarded the overall unfriendliness of their staff and how they took my order and STILL tipped. Wish I got that money BACK. During my 2nd to last visit, the staff person slammed my food atop the counter for no apparent reason. Was difficult to fathom what this idiot was thinking but my hunger superceded everything and I just regrettably ignored that display of emotion. Over my order? WTF?! The last visit will be my final one and for this reason--charging me for a carne asada burrito when I clearly ordered a VEGGIE. And then the audacity to do so with the same attitude I tried several times to overlook. There definitely won't be a visit anytime soon, most likely EVER. And you know what's sad? I'd probably get better customer service from a Taco Bell than this place.
author: Chris C.

description:
La Cumbre has been there for me since college and wow, those carne asade burritos cannot be equaled anywhere!  And they opened one in San Mateo and I thought it wouldn't be the same but it is well worth the visit too!  

Great food and a cool place, easy to get to from BART as a bonus.

Just talking about it makes me want to go there now!
author: Etienne E.

description: Great burritos. I really enjoy mixing their meats (such as chick and carne asada). My first time there they walked up to my friends and me and gave us all samples of their meats. Pretty much sold me on the spot.
author: Jay P.

description: Just stopped in the other night, I was kinda sick of the other spots around this area. I had a deluxe veggie with avocado. It was totally huge and hit the spot. The rice was moist  and did not have any weird peas or carrots in it.the burrito was just the right mix of beans, salsa and avocado all served up on a whole wheat tortilla. It smelled good in there, with a clean busy vibe. I would def hit it up again.  Oh, and the green salsa is tasty.
author: Tamrin H.

description: Cool spot if you're looking for some Mexican flavor. I had a super burrito with carna asada which everyone raves about and have to admit it was pretty damn good. Plus it was very filling (huge portions), it felt like I was holding a brick. The only bad thing was it was a little pricey in my opinion $8 for a burrito when most taquerias in the neighborhood sells them for a lot less. But I heard the Mexican sandwiches are their specialty (tortas). I'm coming back for that. Fo sure! I'll let u know how it goes on the flip side.
author: T L.

description:
As a resident of the 16th/Valencia block I have had burritos everywhere: Pancho Villa, El Toro, Mariachi's, Los Coyotes, even all the way up to Buen Sabor on 18th- but I'll say: I don't understand why people keep saying the meat is bland.  La Cumbre's meat is flavorful and moist, and not all greasy. It tastes like it is grilled on a backdoor bbq. 

I think the burritos are great, tacos too! Sure they may cost 50 cents more than pancho villa, but I think it's worth it. Also, I am a fan of "fake" cheese they use on nachos, regular shredded cheese gets all hard and gross after like 3 minutes.

Overall, it's the only spot I go to for mexican food north of 20th street because it's awesome.
author: the k.

description: Good stuff, but not the life changing carnitas I was promised...  Perhaps it was just because I ate less than a hour before, or maybe it was due to the copious amount of beer that was consumed before...  I'll be back to try it again.. sober lol
author: Bryan N.

description:
I was unaware there is new management!  But now I know....anyway, I used to come here all the time when I was in the mission --- mostly because it's very conveniently located and was decent.  This is the kind of place that needs a cons/pros list because I really like their burritos, but I'm a little on the edge about other qualities...

CONS
-the ambiance is bleh, even for a taqueria spot...I think it's the lighting that bothers me.  though i do enjoy some of their murals/art and the high ceiling
-i'm not sure if I should write this or not considering the location but I will because it's a fact...there are normally homeless people outside and sometimes inside
-kind of overall not the cleanest spot in terms of tables are left dirty, trash left around etc
-late at night, of course, it's full of crazy ass loud people coming out of bars...but that's not to say i'm not one of them...hehe

PROS
-open late!
-FAST. the other night we were looking for a quick meal...the two choices as they are near each other was Pancho Villa and La Cumbre - we decided La Cumbre because Pancho Villa takes foreeeevverrr sometimes...and La Cumbre serves you in like 1 minute
-large menu selection
-yummy burritos.  I think these are one of my favorite burritos in SF - has all the right ingredients and is yummy; their tacos are good as well...though I like Cancun's tacos better
-fairly priced
-in the center of the mission
-decent salsa bar that includes limes!

This is one of my most frequented taquerias in the Mission --- though I come here to eat burritos rather than tacos.  I feel like there used to be a burrito card where you could collect hole punches of burritos you ate..and I wanted one!  But I don't know if that's actually real or if I just dreamed of it.   Hmm...
author: Liz C.

description: Overpriced, less-than-mediocre food slowly served at peak afternoon hour by disorganized, unpleasant staff.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Good solid Mexican food. Saw the Man vs food and had to try.... But it wasn't anything special....... Big let down coming all the way from Outer Richmond. 

Great place if you are close.

P.S. Beware of the Mexican trio band lurking around. Looking for tips
author: Ray C.

description: With all the options nearby , I can't see why you would go here. I got a pollo asada plate.  Beans were super salty. Tomatoes and lettuce were pale, no flavor.  Cucumbers were dry and flavorless.  Chicken breast I would wager was pounded out, airplane food-like.  If this was $6.00 , maybe. They charge $11.50 for this.  Sorry, but that was crap.
author: Jamie C.

description: La Cumbre--home of the worst chicken burrito I've ever had in the Mission District. I took the leftovers for work the next day, but ended up trashing it and going to Taco Bell instead.
author: Teddy B.

description: I loved this place like 10 years ago, but sad to say it is just not the same. The ingredients (especially cheese) seem very cheap. There are better places right around the corner
author: John C.

description:
When I roll into La Cumbre sticky with $2 Tecate, I always feel the need to drunk dial my father, as I know he'd appreciate my treading in his exact alcohol-soaked, Mexican food-craving footsteps.

No, he's not a drunk, he just lived in the Mission in the 70s (ok, so maybe that means he was a drunk back then).

That aside, last night around 12:30 I got the most epic burrito craving while on the dance floor at Delirium, so I screamed to my friends and made for La Cumbre as quickly as I could. One chicken, black bean, rice, and cheese burrito (and hailed taxi) later, I was in a bliss I knew I inherited from my father. The burrito was so big that I couldn't even finish it on the long ride home to Russian Hill, so I climbed in bed with my prize and a bottle of Smart Water, and passed out in a state of ecstasy about ten minutes later.
author: Carla C.

description: On our last day in San Fran we had to try this place thanks to my husband seeing them on Man Vs. Food show. What a dissapointment for both of us! How could a burrito be messed up?? Don't get it. We shared a chicken and steak burrito with no sour cream, the rice and beans were ok, the veggies were fresh, the meat was chewy cheap, after several attempts to break it down I gave up and took it out of my mouth, it was gross. Why would anyone serve this to paying customers??? No refills? That sucks! I am so glad we actually had the best burrito ever at El Farolito up the street...now THAT is a dam good quality burrito! Ha ha at least I beat my husband on a good  find.
author: BV M.

description:
The carne asada burrito is rockin.  That's all I have to say about that.  However, this place gets crazy late at night.  My girlfriend and I were trying to get a burrito late one night and the sheer chaos was really not worth it.  The girl in front of me started screaming at one point.  Not just speaking loudly, but screaming as if stung by bees.  The guy behind my girlfriend collapsed, grabbing hold of her for support.  None of this is the fault of La Cumbre.  Or is it...?  
Anyway, stop in for lunch, get the carne asada burrito, and you will be happy.  Or at least you will have a good burrito.  Your happiness is your business, I suppose.
author: Richard N.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE - best burritos in San Francisco! although my friend said to check out taqueria cancun but I haven't been there yet so...BEST BURRITOS. This place has been around forever and it's always been yummy.
author: Lani B.

description: I went to this place just because Man v. Food went here and raved about the huge burritos. Yeah. They're big but the flavor is average at best. The place was crowded but I noticed very quickly that there wasn't a single Mexican in the restaurant. No Mexicans in a Mexican food joint is never a good sign. I got the carne asada burrito and the meat was somewhat tough to the point I have to spit a few pieces out because they couldn't be chewed. All-in-all, I give this one three stars.
author: Gregg H.

description: Did I really just pay $13 for a deluxe steak and prawn burrito? Damn.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Awesome beef steak burritos. I have yet to date tastes better burritos than this! Yum yum
author: Lana H.

description:
I must confess I'm a little nostalgic when it comes to La Cumbre.  My brother brought me here in 1988.  It was first visit to California and San Francisco.  The Mission wasn't hip back then.  This is when they closed the Wells Fargo ATM on 16th at 7 p.m. because some poor soul got beaten to death while passerbys did nothing.

Before La Cumbre I was a burrito virgin.  Big brother instructed me to order carne asada with whole pinto beans and hot sauce.  Nothing like the taste of your first burrito. The hot sauce brought tears to my eyes.  Keep in mind I grew up Massachusetts where El Torito is considered authentic.

Then brother took me to Zeigeist.  That's a whole other story.  

La Cumbre has fallen a bit in quality over the years.  It looks a little tired.  The carne asada isn't as good as it used to be.  I can't help but crack a big grin every time I walk by the place.
author: Liz P.

description:
I'm feeling inspired by e.e. cummings this morning.

somewhere i (wish I had) never travelled,sadly beyond
any experience,your burritos have their tastelessness:
your most frail gesture is an oversteamed, sopping wet tortilla
which i cannot touch because it melts in my hands

my slightest look easily will unclose it
though i try to keep it closed with my fingers,
it opened the one time I went there layer by layer as Autumn opens
(touching clumsily, bumblingly) her first dead leaf

Unmelted cheese, crunchy rice, odd and virtually indistinguishable mishmash of sour cream and guac, gave me refried beans when I asked for black, served the jackass who cut in front of me in line before me. Boo, La Cumbre. BOO.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
I've ended up here on more than one occasion, usually after stumbling around in the mission after last call.  I've always gotten the regular tacos and never been dissapointed.  The carne asada, carnitas, and al pastor are all very flavorful and tender.  The tacos are extremely messy, especially al pastor with refried beans but lets just say I'm neither sick nor overly hung over this morning (only slightly) so it definitely agreed with me and did the job.

Oh yeah, there is only one bathroom in there with no lock and when I went the soap container was empty, but they did have paper towels.
author: Theron L.

description:
I'm in a burrito coma and please pull to plug!  Are all burritos created equal?  Nope.  I was craving Pancho's for the 4th day in a row, and when my boss wanted to eat, he said "no, not pancho's again" and we then went to Cumbre.  

I expect my mexican restaurantes to be run down and this one fit the bill  My carne asada burrito was just average, no better or less than what I expected.
author: patrick o.

description: Love this place somehow no matter where I go in the mission I end up at this place often by accident they are the best great salsas too
author: Nirea S.

description: The best thing about this place is the chicken. So maybe just get a chicken taco to let it shine through. The burritos are OK but not delectable. And the salsa bar is kind of sketchy looking. Also, don't plan to eat there, because the lighting is about the most depressing I've ever seen in a restaurant.
author: Marco L.

description:
They have the best carne asada tacos anywhere in San Francisco! Also, I love that they have the salsa bar open and it includes items not always found at  taqueria's llike corn. 
Their service is always fantastic, meaning they listen when i order and pay attention to me. The food prices are really reasonable, my friend gets vegetarian nachos for around $5 when other places you pay close to ten.
I take everyone who visits me from out of state here. It is very "local", and my favorite taco place in  SF by far.

Delicioso.
author: Sara L.

description:
Guacamole Sauce, not chunky goodness.

Falafel Burrito. Righteous!

Open after the nearby bars(delirium, killowatt, etc) let out.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
Great place to stumble into after dancing/boozing at Elbo Room or any of the other go-to Mission spots in the area. Which is exactly what I did last Saturday night. 

Unfortunately, I made a mistake. I agreed to split a burrito with another dude in our group. I will never live this down. What can I say? The burritos look big when you're buzzed. Needless to say, it wasn't enough and I ended up noshing some of of Carla C.'s, but hers was guac-less and sour-cream-less so it really didn't satisfy my inner savage beast. Anyway, don't do what I did. Get your own burrito. 

Also, I don't understand why, but this place is smoky like a mofo. Apparently their efforts are more focused on making delicious burritos than on installing proper ventilation. In fact, maybe the smokiness is exactly why their burritos are so delicious. If it's not too cold, just go outside and banter with hobos while they're making your food inside.
author: N C.

description: the carnitas had NO FLAVOR and overall it was a waste of money. Next time walk your in their walk down Valencia to the corner of 18th and go eat there. This place is no bueno.
author: Natasha L.

description:
Too bad the sfgate critic praised this burrito joint, because we came to check it out, in our quest to find more good burrito places after enjoying El Castillito at Church and Mission.  I had a pollo chile verde taco (which was very generous but more expensive than El Castillito at 3.55 versus 2-something), he had the burrito al pastor, both deluxe.  Mine was bland, his was too small and just not enjoyable.  Beans boring, rice boring, salsa boring.  A very one-dimensional eating experience.  What was "spicy" (as in, oh wow, you want the mild salsa, well you know the chile verde is spicy - are you sure you want it?) was only mild.  

Would not come here again.  Only thing neat about this place was that it's across from Bombay Ice Creamery.
author: C L.

description: Have not had such a great service in a very long time. We came all the way from Orange County and we had a great time there. The staff were there to serve us every time we turned around haha. The margaritas were delicious and at a great price. I would definitely come back next time we are in san francisco
author: Eva S.

description: When I'm in San Francisco and craving a burrito I head over to La Cumbre located in the Inner Mission for the spot. Pollo/Carne asda SUPER BURRITO, Tecate..chips and salsa hits the spot. This place is always crowded so prepare for a short wait. 7 bucks should cover it...can't go wrong!
author: Stan C.

description: Another Man v food review. Defenitely don't come out of your way for the super burrito. Not impressed.
author: lenpup y.

description: Great food, I don't know about the negative reviews about the cleanliness of the joint, but it was a great meal.
author: Thomas C.

description: Good burrito but a few dollars overpriced compared to the surrounding taquerias. I enjoyed the Delux Carne Assada burrito. It was quite tasty and had a good amount of cheese and filling but was on the small side. The burrito alone put my bill just shy of $9 which to me is a few bucks overpriced compared to its size. After i finished it I was still ready for more as I have a beastly appetite. Cooks and Cashier were friendly and even provided me a free sample of their grilled chicken, which was great.
author: Trev D.

description:
My first visit here was in 1991.  The place hasn't changed much.  The room, the chairs and tables, the menu, and even what the folks behind the counter wear hasn't budged.  
Not that there's anything wrong with that.  

In fact, I have a friend in New York who is a chef who still tries to figure out how he's going to get a burrito from La Cumbre to his house on the East Coast via mail and intact.  We've thought about Fed Ex, Fed Ex with some dry ice, overnighting during the winter, not having it made with sour cream, etc.    Any suggestions are welcome.

The only thing that has changed about this place is that the prices have gone up.  Initially, getting the burrito super deluxe was a $5 proposition out the door.  I think we're clocked in at around $7.50 or so now.  I'm not complaining.  It's still a great deal.  After all, a Burrito Super Deluxe from TLC could easily be two meals.
author: Nelson W.

description: My love affair with La Cumbre started en utero, it was my moms favorite place to eat when she was pregnant with me back in the late 70's.  My sister and I ventured to the Mission District a few months ago in search of La Cumbre and i must say i had the carnitas burrito deluxe and it was bomb!  It was bomb after going to the dentist and having half a face that was still numb.  The carnitas was lean and juicy with no hard crusted out parts and no super fatty pieces.  The Agua Frescas was still the best around too super refreshing.  La Cumbre is still and will always be my favorite place to grab a burrito whenever I am in the city!
author: Megan M.

description:
Here's the way it usually works: 
1. I fly from East to West. 
(With connections this can take over 9 hours. And these days many airlines have stopped, well, umm, feeding you? So I arrive hungry)
2. If I fly into SFO, I ask my kind friend who has picked me up to take me directly to La Cumbre. 
3. I gorge. 

Iffin you SFers dont know a good thing when youve got it, check this: we make do with Chipotle back in Washington DC (one of the wee small problems with making the Nations Capitol your home - there are NO TACQUERIAS!) 
La Cumbre is scrumpdeelish--ee-o-sis, esp when washed down with a strawberry soda. Almost like being back in Mexico, only now Im less broke. 

Rejoice and exhort the virtues that you have such a fine food source in your midst. And its cheap too!
author: Sean G.

description: The sautéed vegetable burrito is my favorite vegetarian burrito in the Mission.
author: Jonathan R.

description: I was looking forward ever since Man vs Food. I finally went  and was not impressed. The super burrito was so-so at best. I've had much better burritos at the trucks on the side of the road at about half the price. not even a refill on the drink. Never again!! Sorry Adam.
author: Michael M.

description:
TLC is a place that I avoided for almost 2 years after moving to the Mission area.  I'm not sure what triggered my decision to finally try it but it probably had something to do with alcohol.  As most have stated, it's not the nicest looking spot and you don't get that 'wow, I'll bet the kitchen is spotless' vibe.  The 'guac' they had in a little tray looked more like baby food.

That said, there are 2 things I have discovered this place has going for it.

1.  Pretty good salsa bar...before it gets mangled by a days use though.

2.  The chicken fajita burrito.  This thing is really, really good.  I have not tried anything else on their menu nor do I intend to.  I can get a better 'standard' burrito at a number of other places, but the way they do this monster up is seriously tasty.  The chicken is shredded and there are peppers and carrots and I don't know what else but it's GOOD.  I've had this 5 or 6 times now with no ill after effects.

Definitely not the best taqueria in the Mission  (a strong statement to make given my limited trial of their offerings, as correctly noted in a comment) but they certainly do this particular burrito very well.
author: Ross A.

description:
Sorry Yan!

This is my new favorite "16th Street" Buritto.  The grilled meats are killer and they are grilled fresh....

Also.

They have some hot Latina woman as a 'mascott.'

What isn't to love.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Seriously, drunk people. Why this place? Why don't you just go around the corner to Panchita's if it's late at night? Or, just get a bacon-wrapped hot dog. 

This place has two things going for it: the pollo asado, and... the pollo asado.

Well, I guess their tortillas aren't terrible. I've never had a stale, hard tortilla here, which is more than I can say for some other taco and burrito joints.

Seriously, though. Take a walk. Go to any of the 15 better taquerias in a 5-block radius that stay open late at night.
author: Angelo B.

description:
Not bad, but not that great.  Given the five hundred other taquerias in the area, I'd check one of those out before heading back.  Carnitas was a high point, it was the soft kind with no crispy bits -- to be clear, I like all kinds of carnitas, so I viewed this as a particular genre.

Chicken quesadilla was ok, nice that it was not greasy as they use a hot press to melt the cheese, but didn't have a ton of flavor.  Plus I ordered a corn quesadilla but they gave me flour.

The restaurant was freezing cold, minimal to no heating and the front door wide open, so that was a bit of a minus.

My friend had a carne asada burrito and said the beef wasn't too flavorful, he didn't think they marinated it like some other places do.  And we agreed that the chicken is better at La Taqueria.
author: Walter K.

description: Saw this place advertised on the food network so I thought we should try it.  Love going to frisco and decided to skip eating at fishermans grotto and get some Mexican food.  Total mistake!  This place was dirty, food expensive, salsa variety's had no flavor, tables were wobbly...I could go on and on???  They did serve a lot of food but it was a lot of untasty food.  Very disappointed, Adam, from Man versus Food!
author: Michael R.

description: My step dad took me here when I was little and I've been addicted ever since. I turned my friend, elite yelper Theodore O., onto this place. If you want a burrito thicker than your forearm, go to La Cumbre, ¡¡ahora!!
author: Peter F.

description:
the one thing about this place?  authentic....thats right authentic.  thats why you go here.

if you want fresh go down the street and go to pancho villa or el toro BOTH owned by the same owner.

THIS PLACE?  this started as a GREAT PLACE and even though its been visited by that chubby guy on the travel network...it isn't the place it used to be.  they used to make a HUGE BURRITO but NOT WHEN I GO...it seems to be as small as a burrito where i went to high school SHC...lol.  i'll go here if i want it to be a bit salty and have spices other places don't have.
author: Bing D.

description:
This is a favorite for late night eaters and drunk people, alike. La Cumbre is open until 2 AM!

Personally, I like the cheese quesadillas. The carne asada burritos are okay, as well.

The chips here are good, as they are served warm. However, the salsa is average.

Churros are served, which is always a plus.
author: A B.

description:
In the 80s La Cumbre was legendary. My family would travel en masse from the Excelsior to wait in a line that stretched outside onto Valencia just for the carnitas. Family members from LA would beg to get a La Cumbre burrito within hours of arriving at SFO.

Well, the 80s are over and the legend's been shot to hell. After a recent reopening, I gave La Cumbre more than a few chances for loyalty's and memory's sake. Keeping it simple with rice, beans and cheese (I can't speak for the meat)  is a good move because the guacamole is pathetic, the tomatoes are large and mushy, and the cream, well I've got sick (as in projectile vomit sickness) twice from eating there now.

Warning for travellers: Watch the cream for contamination and if you have an extra dollar, please for the love of burritos just say no to their guacamole and pay extra for avocado instead. Trust me on this one.
author: bianca francesca o.

description: I went here after seeing it featured on Man vs Food. After seeing the host's reactions, I was expecting the best burrito of my life. Well, he played it up for TV, but not much, cause the chicken burrito was tasty! The ambiance is nothing to write home about. It's quite ordinary and unassuming, so next time I may ask for an order on the run, but there will be a next time, for sure.
author: Julia S.

description: This place is the BALLS.  My old boss used to say this.   And now I do....it means it is the best.   For quesadillas.....it rocks....I love it....ate it twice in 24 hrs....fuckkkk ya La Cumbre you rock it like that...
author: Rob C.

description: I was drawn because I heard this was the original Taqueria in the Mission, not to mention they have a giant guitar on their wall.  This place offers big portions and all you can eat salsa bar, that also has corn and 4 different types of salsa.  Their burrito's are pretty big, and totally reasonable for under $7.00.  I had their tacos once, and it tasted just like the burrito so not much of a difference. All in all, a good place to get a burrito if El Farrito, and Cancun taqueria is close.
author: J Y.

description: This place is overpriced and bullshit! 12 dollars for 3 tacos and a mandarina jarritos is insane! Paying so much money for mediocre as mexican slop is a travesty! The service was terrible and the bitch that rang us up- honey you have the personality of a wet mop! I am never going there again! I am sticking to the mexican mission dogs that they sell on the streets...now that is amazing!!
author: Yolanda O.

description:
I love me some burritos. But I do not love me some burritos from this place. I'm hardly ever let down by burritos (even the microwave ones you get at Costco), but I was let down by La Cumbre.

With so many excellent choices in the Mission, its hard to justify coming here with their overpriced and bland burritos. Hell even the salsa had me wondering 'where's the flavor?' Hell even the hot sauce had no flavor.

This place is like the scene in Oliver Twist where he asks for more gruel/porridge. Except the flavorless gruel is now the burritos and I'm definitely not asking for more. 

NEXT!!
author: Rocky K.

description:
I have been going to La Cumbre since 1980, when the very friendly and sweet mother of the family that owns the taqueria used to be the cashier.
The burritos were by far the best I have ever had in my entire life . They were to die for!!!!
No more. After the death of the mother and the family moved to San Mateo  County, the quality of the meat became abysmal and they  no longer offer the delicious special meat sauce that I used to so look forward to when I went there.
I still go about once a month, not because of the food , Just out of nostalgia.
author: Chris S.

description: After seeing this on the TV show, Man vs. Food, I had to go check it out.  I got a super burrito with chicken. I have never tasted chicken like that in a burrito! My husband got the sauteed veggies, which were cooked fresh at the time of order--this also was done for the chicken.  You may wait a bit for it, but it's worth it!
author: Liz F.

description: I was really excited to eat here because of man v. food. it wasn't that good and i definitely wasn't impressed. i think chipotle tastes much better than this place
author: Desiree L.

description: el pastor super wet burrito. there is nothing better.
author: Alex G.

description:
La Cumbre is in my top 5 favorite taquerias!  
My only wish is that they would have avocados as opposed to just guacamole Veggie Tacos are still the best in town!
author: Heather S.

description:
One cup of way-too-sweet horchata and one overpriced quesadilla with dubious steak later, I found myself being called over to the register and informed that they had charged me for my friend's meatless quesadilla and I still owed them two dollars.  I paid, all the while wishing I was over at Taqueria Cancun where the meat is flavorful, the horchata is just right, and the counter guys know how to take an order.

A pox on all who speak ill of Cancun!
author: Frankie D.

description:
As a regular for over 2 months while I worked a few doors down, I had my fair share of chicken tacos.  For the most part, I walked away happy, but every once in awhile, an apathetic worker would put together a mediocre taco.  

I definitely liked that they used meat that remained intact longer and would cut it on the spot instead of a vat o' meat, all diced and mismashed up together. 

And the chips.  Most of the time good, but on several occasions I got some that were questionable and inedible.  

I'm so glad Papalote is just down the street from me now!
author: April B.

description:
Good fur drunk late nite eats, but watch out for the over charging latenite I'm a 2 time loser.
I've recently learned that this type of over charging is the norm it's referred to as the "white boy special" I seem to fit a certain profile that prohibits me from paying the menu price.
author: t h.

description:
La Cumbre in Valencia Street in the Mission is a great taco/burito joint that is authentic, no frills Mexican.

Being a recent immagrant from Sonoma County, and it's Mecian taco trucks, and local Mexican run restaurants, La Cumbre is a God send! If only we had anything like it in the Sunset...

If your in the mood for a quick taco, burrito, be it fish, polo, el pastor, or the fantastic carne asada, stop by La Cumbre. You won't be disapointed.

Plus, the great Mexican hottie painting on the wall, and the family history of the spot is a welcome adition.
author: Enoch K.

description:
My husband heard about this place and wanted to check it out so the entire family went there for dinner last night.  We were quite pleased: my husband had the pollo chile verde, our son ordered a carne asada burrito, our daughter had the grilled shrimp (huge and juicy) tostada salad and I went for the chile colorado plate. Portions were very large, salsa bar was amazing and fresh, and everyone enjoyed their meal. Although I have to say the meat in the chile colorado was very tender and the sauce very deliciously spicy, it can't compare to what my mom used to cook. But honestly, I don't think ANY Mexican place can ever compare to my mother's cooking.  So, call me spoiled, but we all enjoyed our meal, and the staff was very friendly, especially when my husband tried to order in Spanish (then he asked me to help him) and the kids threw out their orders in Spanish, also. 
We also enjoyed the layout and decor (made me think of when I was a little girl) and the Mission is always a cool place to check out the local art. 
So there!
author: Elma R.

description: This is by far my fav burrito in the the bay area.  I started going to the san mateo location as a kid and found this location 8 years ago and have been going ever since.  Clean and fresh tasting food everytime.
author: matt w.

description:
This is the best all-around burrito place at the 16th and Valencia intersection. I purposefully don't go here all the time so that when I return, the burritos are that much better. They have the best food, but more importantly they have the nicest people. Check out their other location by the San Mateo train station. 
Its hard to say whi I think they make the best burritos, and it is all so relative, but it must be because they have the best ingredients. 
Their salsa is very good too.
author: Andrew B.

description:
after seeing la cumbre on man vs. food, we've been meaning to check it out...

i wish i hadnt....we both got a super burrito, him the carnitas, me the carne asada.....i can sum up our la cumbre experience in one word. fail.

very bland and dry...the salsas were no good...and $8 for a burrito? ridiculous...i think the only good thing about la cumbre is that their burritos are a lil' healthier and less greasy than other taquerias

we're sticking to our favorite place, la altena
author: Alice K.

description: The food is good, the salsas were good, and the place is relatively comfortable.  I only wish the people behind the counter spoke some English, even if we are in "little Mexico".  I ordered with difficulty...my partner finally gave up and went two doors down to a a great Philly steak joynt.   We won't be back.
author: Doug A.

description: I like this place ok. Decent food at average SF prices and you never have to wait for too long to get your food. It's much like other taqueria joints in the mission for the most part. What sets this place apart (for better of worse) is that the food is less greasy. Their veggies include carrots, which is a bit weird. Carrots in your fajitas? I was hungry for Mexican food and had about an hour to enjoy my meal with a fun book to read. After scoping out many reliable taquerias in the mission, I decided on this place, because I knew that the food was reliable and I wouldn't be feel bad for hogging a table while I finished my meal and read a chapter or two. I ended up ordering a shrimp quesedilla, which had way too much liquid in it.  I don't want to bite into a dripping quesedilla. It also had carrots inside. CARROTS!!!!!! Yuck! Next time, I'll stick to my usual fish tacos or burritos.
author: Su K.

description: The burritos were tasty, yet I can't agree with Maxim magazine's vote for the best burrito in America. This may be the birthplace of the burrito, but it's certainly not the best place for them. And what's with having magaritas on the menu when you don't actually serve them? La Cumbre vs. Chipotle? Chipotle wins!
author: Beans L.

description: So i was told by many people that this is one of the best burrito places in SF.  Now i love burritos as i eat mexican food twice a day at least. When i think of a Taqueria i think authentic mexican food and great salsa bar. I ate there today 10/10/12 at 2pm and was less than impressed. I by no means thought that this was going to be the worst burrito i have ever had but it was. There was no flavor in the chicken and the spicy salsa was not spicy at all. The cheese that went into my burrito was not melted and tasted like it was not covered in the fridge when they stored. You know when you dont cover something and it actually absorbs all the flavors of the food sitting in the fridge. Thats what it tasted like. The chips weren't bad but there really wasn't anything special about them and they weren't even warm.  My girlfriend got one steak and one carnitas tacos and they were also terrible. This place just needs to go back to the basics. I am white and i can make better mexican food then them.
author: Brennan F.

description:
For the amount of press it gets, I expected better.  Of course, I've never seen "Man V Food" NOT like a restaurant, so it may not be the best guide...  

Maybe I should have been hungrier, but I stopped in to try one of their  "super burritos" early one day.  It looked good, but it was kind of bland, and I was amazed at how quickly the whole burrito disintegrated.  I think I probably got 3 bites before the whole thing fell apart.  As the two-star definition says, "Meh.  I've experienced better."
author: Brent C.

description: Carne asada is awesome!  I love drowning the burritos with their hot sauce because it is so good.  I do not need any frills and thrills so I could care less that the place is outdated and tacky as hell.  As long as the food stays consistent I'm a believer.
author: Chanthi L.

description: This place is all hype. Not good! Burritos suck, service is bad. Food doesnt taste like anything. Bad experience, I cant believe I came from Oakland for this
author: Chris M.

description: How the mighty have fallen. My carne asada today was really tough.
author: Scott R. D.

description:
Being a professional burracist (burrito-racist), you may think of a huge bias when eating what I call a "log of baby food".
Well, my room mate loves burritos and for his birthday I treated him to La Cumbre after overhearing here and there that they have some of the best "logs of baby foods" in town.
Let's begin from the price: according to him they were slightly overpriced, but the portion was good.
He had his reference meal, a super-burrito with carnitas and he thought it was OK.
I went gourmet, of course, and had a chicken fajita burrito.
I have to admit, it was good, but wet...dripping wet.
I still don't get the concept behind a burrito but it was good and two or three bites were actually great.
The combo of sauteed peppers, pattypan squash and chicken bursted in my mouth with great pleasure...
Other times it was just a "log of baby food".
Bottomline, it actually was one of the best burritos I've ever had, but I had 5 in all my life....not sure if I reach the appropriate significance.

Man they're stingy with the chips! I counted 12 for each of us.

Ah, forgot, I smell like carne asada like a little BBQd Arbre Magique, thanks to the friendly smokiness of the premises.

If you go to the bathroom, don't forget to squeeze the pollita.
author: Dario B.

description:
yeah...not so great here.  my expectations are bit shot and a return visit not planned in the near future.  i mean, you got carne asada on the menu...keep that vaca on the grill.  they get 2 stars for the green sauce.   but then again, any mexican restaurant w/ a decent green sauce gets 2 stars from me!

viva la taqueria down the block on mission!
author: Lady K.

description: Overrated.   El Farlito's quesadilla seuza still remains supreme for nor cal.  I do like la cumbre option for meat and salso only.  A true so cal mexican burrito.
author: Fatty A.

description: The carne asada is flavor-less!!! THIS PLACE SUCKS el farolitos or la taqueria is a better burrito!
author: Josie M.

description: I ordered a beef fajita burrito.  What a gringo move.  It was tasteless & didn't come with guac as I requested. However,  I am giving this place 4 stars because everyone else loved their carnita burritos (which I sampled) and the place was clean with cool artwork.
author: Phillip M.

description:
What can I say about La Cumbre, their nachos were a good sized portion, great to share with another but the chicken was overcooked for my taste. 

I gave it another shot and on my second visit I decided to order something without meat or chicken. I got their veggie burrito which was by far a lot better than their nachos!! Pricing was not bad either as I paid approximately $10 for a burrito and Corona. In conclusion, I would most definitely go back to La Cumbre!
author: Jamie S.

description: Super disappointed! Saw this place on Man vs. Food...and was in the area so I thought my gf and I should try...I can def. say I've had way better burritos! My gf got the deluxe pollo asada; she said it was 'just ok'. I had the deluxe carne asada...the meat was tough and was cut in large ass pieces...I could not bite through 'em and the salsa looked like it had been sitting there all week! At least I can say I've tried La Cumbre, but I don't think I'll be going back any time soon!
author: Jen D.

description: Tasty beef tacos at 1am on a Thursday.  I didn't get sick and I didn't get hungover.  Can't really ask for more!
author: Audrey T.

description: After over 30 years of this being one of my favorite places, I give up.  Meals used to be made with care and pride; last night was such a crap experience (tough, gristley carne asada; I'd ordered carnitas) that I will not be back.  $7 for an inedible burrito, and not even what I'd ordered, accompanied by an attitude at the counter while ordering that I can't put a name to but was certainly less than welcoming or positive.  They've lost a good customer.  For $7 I expect to be able to eat my burrito.  Bummer.
author: RunJane R.

description: Only tried the veggie burrito and nachos- pretty good stuff. Salsa was a bit on the bland side and not spicy even though I asked for hot. all in all, i'd eat there again.
author: Karli K.

description:
La Cumbre is like the junkie that mainlines heroin and shoots speed into their eyeballs...fantastic highs necessarily followed by crushing lows. This place is like your really smart friend who didn't have too much direction and ended up going to Junior College, only to drop out after the first year because they found that getting high was way more fulfilling than showing up to class. 

During peak hours, when they are cooking the meat fresh, La Cumbre can have some of the most top notch carne asada in the city. Also, their re-fried beans really put every other bean in close proximity to shame.
