Kidney, black, pinto, green, string, and any other goddamn  bean look like chumps when compared to La Cumbres' re-fried warriors. 

This place, although having potential, makes some really ridiculous errors. First, they load their burritos with lettuce and sliced tomato. Like the shit you find in a sandwich. Second, they have the goddamn word 'prawn' listed in about seven of their entrees, yet every time I ask about the prawn they can't seem to to find it. "Check in the fridge" I tell them. "No prawn today!" they scream. The most vile sin they commit though is  their version of 'baja-style fish taco'. Now I've eaten fish tacos in baja mexico, goddammit, and I've also eaten them at Rubio's, which isn't saying too much, but I have never in my life ordered a baja fish taco and been served fish that has been sitting in a heating troph. What the hell part of baja is this taco representing? The soggy part? I can't believe that they serve floppy fish here. It tasted like canned mackerel jerky, which has various properties useful for capturing otters, but has no place in a taco.
author: Dave G.

description: I am vegetarian and I love their Super Deluxe veggie burritos. Love the salsa bar, always fresh and so tasty. I get them all the time and will get them any time I'm hungry in the citay  :)
author: Jezebel U.

description: The problem is that they steam instead of grilling. If you want a good burrito, you must grill. Every time I come here I am wasted and I always leave wishing I'd gone to Arinell's instead. But, you know, it's edible, it's nicer to sit in than that tired old bag Pancho Villa and they take plastic.
author: Maria D.

description:
Taqueria la cumbre is san francisco's first mission taqueria.    Though it's been around for many years, burritos and e tacos here are average when it comes to taste, quality and authenticity

I tried the bbq chicken burrito.  Though it was huge,  taste wise it was below most places I visited.    The meat portions are minimal.    All you taste is beans, rice and salsa.    

For $8   I would expect more.
author: JERRY B.

description: There is something really inedible about their food.  I bit into something fucking nasty and couldn't identify it for the life of me.  I ate three bites and threw it in the garbage.  Gross and cheap describes most of the fix ups I've been on but not a burrito.  Taquerias should be cheap and tasty and yes I know they pay their workers nothing and they slave away all day for their customers.  I can't argue that but where do you draw the line between ignoring bad food because you feel bad for the place and telling people to avoid a sucky meal.
author: Angelina J.

description: My fish taco tasted like either the fish or the oil the fish was cooked had gone very, very bad.  But I was brave/stupid/starving so I ate it.  Then I spent several hours worrying about when I was going to start throwing up.  It never happened, so I appreciate that.  That was some rank tasting food though.
author: Katie S.

description: i saw this place on Man vs. Food, and i came with great expectations... but seriously, no matter where you go, super burritos will always taste the same unless put crack cocaine inside. The super burrito here is no different than the place near my house, it was even a little watery.
author: Jeffrey B.

description: It seems like the reviews here are pretty mixed but I really dig this place. They have HUGE burritos with good equal portions of everything. The carne asada here is very good.  I have heard from other people that their food was cold and the service was slow. Based on my experiences,  I really like the food (not the best, but very good) but the service can be pretty apathetic. This should be a stop on any  burrito lovers tour.
author: Nick H.

description:
It's great that this place is open late, but the food is just barely OK.

The mushy salsa has no heat to it at all and the flavors are indistinguishable from each other.  

The al pastor burrito is similarly boring.  Chips, well, not even worth it.

Of course, if you're starving, and it's the middle of the night this place jumps from 2 to 3 stars.
author: jorge c.

description: Man oh man, well i had just gotten a tattoo in the area and I was starving after. My friend suggested La Cumbre also because she remembered it was on Man vs. Food. I ordered a quesadilla and was tempted to get streak but realized the place was know for its chicken so i tried it out. Must I say it was DELICIOUS! The place is good. I wanna go back but since i don't live in SF it would be a waays to get there, but worth it. Only reason i didn't give this place a 5 was because the lady who was making me and my 2 friends food was totally rude to my latina friend. But maybe she was just having a bad day.
author: Jasmin J.

description: This place may only get mediocre reviews on yelp but let me tell you this place is solid four star burrito joint. It's always the same. I have come here time after time for the charbroiled chicken burrito and always leave happy. It's not super fancy but I feel everything is fresh and enjoyable. Come check this place out its better than a lot of other mediocre burrito places in the mission!
author: Jason P.

description: There are a lot of surprisingly eh reviews here.  I would never order anything here but a grilled steak or a grilled chicken burrito (and that tends to be my sensibility on the burrito front anyway).  I don't order them super (unless I'm splitting), and I always order black beans (though I'm fine with refried here too).  In those incarnations, I find La Cumbre to be quite a good lunch.  Add to that a Bohemia (if your day permits it), and it's the best lunch.  Truck it over to Delores Park on a sunny day, and it becomes a great lunch.  Five stars even.  Four stars here because the rest of the food is a bit eh.  But the burritos are great.
author: Laurel B.

description: The atmosphere inside the place was bad. It was really dirty and disgusting. I noticed you had to pay for the bathroom. But other then that the burrito was delicious. The price didnt seem fair to me. I like Pancho Villa better, I believe they make better burritos there. This place is alright though.
author: Claudia M.

description: I have been coming to this little burrito shop since before I could talk, and its the best little burrito place ever.. the only other burrito shop that comes close to this one is its companion in San Mateo right on Bst.. Both La Cumbre locations are the bomb.. definetely worth the drive from where ever you live or work :)
author: Cherie S.

description: The horchata is a little too sweet but they do roll the most perfect burritos.  They are giant but still fit in your hand, two layers of foil, perfect.  It's so satisfactory to regard, especially right before you unpeel everything and make a giant mess.
author: Laura Y.

description: Are you kidding me?? Over $10 for a mediocre burrito and a (non alcoholic) beverage! How does this place stay in business? Oh, yeah, drunk people.
author: Drue C.

description: If you are a fan of lettuce in your burrito, this is your spot. Unfortunately, nothing here really lived up to expectations (especially since this place has been around since the 60s). The carne asada burrito was edible, but the steak itself was chewy. The carnitas tacos were shameful, as they were lukewarm and showed no signs of crispiness but lots of greasiness...
author: Nicolas H.

description: The people here didn't lie but Adam Richman did. The carne asada is unbearably chewy.
author: steve g.

description: the place looked old and not that clean. i tried a super burrito and to pay 8.50 i gotta say it wasnt that great. the meat was a bit hard to chew. and the taste wasnt that great. im  a mexican raised person so i might be picky but to be honest even a taco truck burrito has better taste. the salsas on the salsa bar were to plain and to top it off the chips were stale and old. i have no idea how it was picked by the tv show man vs food. its ok if theres no where else to go but if there is i would check out other places to compare. btw i love your food gladys macias.
author: Miguel R.

description: My last visit was very underwhelming. It wasn't bad, it just wasn't as good as I remember this place being. I was in need of lunch and immediately thought of this place.  It always does the job because it's cheap and fast.  Once you eat here, you can rest assure that you won't be hungry the rest of the day.
author: Roger H.

description: Let me preface this by saying I'm a transplant from Boston.  In Boston, you're likely either a fan of Ana's Taqueria, or Boca Grande.  I am firmly in the Ana's camp.  As a member of the Ana's camp, I love my burrito's tortilla STEAMED.  La Cumbre is not the place for you if you are one of those grilled burrito freaks.  Although not as speedy as the Ana's burrito assembly line, service was as expected.  A choice of mild or hot salsa was a nice surprise.    The hot salsa did not disappoint.  Fun divey decor wins over Ana's.  My plate was even shaped like a hot pepper.  If I had any complaints, its I would have actually preferred an even steamier tortilla. yum.
author: Parker W.

description: Burritos are big, and the price is right.  If you can't find something delicioso here, maybe you don't like mexican food.
author: Stephen M.

description:
let just say i wasted and watching Man Vs Food last night. went down to La Cumbre with friends in the middle of the night. and got some bomb ass carne asada burrito!!


this is the birth place of the mission style Burrito Bitches!! 

Pretty Awesome Place , for late night snack and drunkies like me ^_^
author: Smart C.

description: I had the munchees so I decided to come to this place on a Saturday after I heard about it on Man vs. Food. The Man Vs. Food guy made it seem like this is the best burrito he has ever had in his life and it's the original "mission" style burrito. I walked in and it smelled like fire inside but it wasn't as bad as Naan and Curry fire. I decided to try the burrito which I thought was pretty good. However I didn't think it was great so I don't know what the Man Vs. Food guy was on. Maybe he lost his taste buds with all the crap he was eating? :) I would take El Farolito over this place any day of the week. You at least see Latinos at El Farolito where in this place everyone was not Latino and that was a little odd for me.
author: Nir B.

description:
Okay- I'm from Mexico, lived in a Texas/Mexico bordertown my whole life, the BF saw this on Food Network, so we *had* to go on our trip to SF. The food was okay, VERY much just O-K. The only thing that sets it apart is the seasoning of the meat... something most people wouldn't even notice. It has good flavor, but there's no WOW factor. Also, there were no Mexicans actually eating at the place (all tourists and hipsters), possibly a sign that there's more authentic and delicious food elsewhere. Especially for the price, the food is only slightly better than fast food burrito places.

To make it worth going- visit La Cumbre around 5, then walk up and down the street in Mission district. That's really the only thing that made it fun... otherwise I wouldn't recommend and trip *just* to go.
author: vienna c.

description: This is the kind of place that puts beans in a taco. Not how I roll, usually. But, when you are drunk and you have $2.44 burning in your pocket that doesn't want to be spent on a pizza slice, you can get such a taco here. Not a bad deal, but not a outstanding taco, either. Middle of the road.
author: Tom H.

description:
Yes, I am a fan! However, there's a new manager (young guy with a mustache) who is ruining the place and its reputation. When he first came on board he had this new ridiculous method of paying first and ordering at the cash register when all the customers have been doing the opposite. It was confusing and frustrating so he finally changed it back. The guy just stands there and do's nothing else but "hawk" over the workers (WTF!). There's no need to watch them, except to impose ridiculous regulations that will drive your customers away (e.g., smaller portions, or ratio of goodies vs. fillers). In my opinion this place is as authentic as you will find in San Francisco, but this guy needs to go. 
Another reason why I rate it so low, given my infatuation with the food, on WEEKDAYS  I have been denied service 20 minutes before they close on more than one occasion. They close earlier on weekdays. Not sure exactly what the schedule on weekdays is, sometimes 9:30 other nights 10 and other nights 9 and they won't serve you after 9:11, 9:40, or 8:40 respectively. WTF! Just stick to one schedule and put your customers first, close when you say you're going to close.
author: M R.

description: It was pretty good.  Definitely some good homemade food in here.  It's better than Chipotle but probably a little unhealthier.  I went here on a trip to San Fran with  friend.  She really wanted to go because of Man versus Food.  I mean, it' definitely good.  If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd rather go to this place than get a burrito from Chipotle.  Good stuff.  Not the best burritos ever, but it's good and deserves 4 stars at least.
author: Spicy S.

description: My first experience with a Mission taqueria. I was so hoping it would remind me of  my burrito experiences when I lived in San Diego. Even when drunk it failed to even come close! I dunno how you can make a pinto bean burrito taste wrong, but it did. It wasn't horrible, but it definately wasn't great. One down, 72,645 other Mission taquerias left to try.
author: Cindy R.

description: The most bland and boring Mexican food I have ever had.  The salsa had no flavor or spice.  The rice was dry and bland.  The beans had no flavor.  The vegetables were not fresh.  The grilled chicken is the only thing that passed for food in the whole place.  I highly recommend never going here for any reason.  If you want real Mexican food, go to Taqueria El Farolito on 24th and Mission.
author: Michelle H.

description: This is the best and only decent taqueria in the Mission. Yuppies done fucked up all the other ones.
author: Stan B.

description:
the food is okay & so is the atmosphere. or maybe this is just in comparison to other really delicious mexican joints ALL OVER THE MISSION and ALL OVER EVERYWHERE IN CALIFORNIA. i'm not opposed to mediocre mexican food, really, i just don't understand why you'd ever get stuck eating it if you're in san francisco, of all places.

i did have an excellent girl talk sesh here a while back, which kind of means i saved a little spot for it in my heart. a little, teeny, three stars space for it.
author: Irene S.

description:
I have been eating La Cumbre burritos since I had teeth, over 30 years.  This was the burrito of my youth, my first love in the world of taquerias.  I am happy to say that my love has not wavered. 

What must be said however is that I don't go here for anything but the carne asada burrito.  The steak here is second to none.  I see a lot of bad reviews on La Cumbre, and they are from people eating chicken tortas and other nonsense mistake orders.  They should just call this place Carne Asada's, because that's the only thing you should order here.  Everything else is mediocre.  But the carne asada burrito is so damn good, I just can't get enough.  The reason is this is the only place I've ever seen that flame barbecues their steak, in true carne asada fashion.  All other taquerias use their big flat grills, and they can't capture the flame-cooked deliciousness of La Cumbre steak.  I highly recommend ordering just steak, cheese, and maybe a little rice and beans, but I often just go meat and cheese or meat and rice.  Don't even drown it out with salsa or pico de gallo.   Just enjoy the asada in all its glory.
author: Dan B.

description:
la taqueria was closed this past monday (shame on you) so we ended up here.

very solid carnitas (although not crispy at all as some places do their carnitas). huge burrito. nicely proportioned.
author: MJ R.

description: I came from Sacramento to San Francisco  for a concert on 3/30/2012 It was for MSI and Prior to my trip with my girlfriend I was looking for local restaurants in San Francisco  that were close to the Regency Ballroom. I found La Cumbre on " Man vs. Food" and I was excited.highly anticipating  a great burrito. , I was disappointed The burrito was expensive and i expected a super burrito as was said on  the show but found one that was anything but super for the price. The ingredients were bland, and I believe the beans and lettuce  were past due as me and my girlfriend both got sick the following night and day after eating the burrito. If you go there just cause  " Man vs Food " was on there don't expect much.
author: Luis L.

description: More of a wet burrito establishment. Pretty good; large portions.
author: Scott F.

description: As I was watching them cut up the carne asada for my burrito, I thought, "That carne asada doesn't look particularly tender or flavorful."  Sure enough, it was dry, bland, and chewy.  I was not impressed.  There are so many other burritos in the Mission that deserve your love than this place.
author: David L.

description: When I lived in SF, La Cumbre was my neighborhood taqueria, which means (in a neighborhood packed with tacquerias) that it was the one I chose more often than not, especially if I wanted a burrito. I always remembered La Cumbre's meats (esp. the grilled steak) as being really, really tasty, and eating at Chipotle here in NYC I always get sad when I compare. This August I literally was in SF for an hour and I had lunch at La Cumbre, and maybe it was the nostalgia, but it was better than ever.
author: Charles G.

description: This place is FLIPPIN tasty!!!!! Even tho a Mexican hater introduced it to me. The smoke from the grill is so Mexico.
author: Michael G.

description: Yes, I saw this on Man Vs. Food and decided to do the test against my husbands favorite, El Farolito. We ordered regular carne asada burritos with refried beans, rice and meat from both restaurants. The carne at La Cumbre was a bit dry. The beans were yummy but it did not stand up to El Farolito. My husband is a regular at the 24th St (between Alabama St & Harrison St) where he only orders boiled chicken and rice. I would say the carna asada burrito with green sauce is the best at El Farolito. Don't forget the chips for 50cents too!
author: Kim C.

description: I have finally figured out another reason to try to clone myself: so that I can spend most of my day eating at La Cumbre.  I saw it profiled on the Food Network and went in, asking about the giant burrito featured on that show. It wasn't in my gustatory range, so I got something smaller, a super burrito with chicken, guacamole, rice, sour cream, and cheese and lettuce.  Mmmmm....delicious!  The atmosphere is pleasant, not anything extravagant, but overall a good taqueria experience.  Good for the whole family. I especially liked their salad bar with radishes and salsa.  Extra spicy!
author: Steven T.

description: I think this Burrito is dope.  One fo the best in the Mission and it is mainly becasue of the great Carne Asada.  I have been to all and this ranks number one for its Carne Asada.  It is fresh and cut right in front of you.  Big fan of it.  Also the Green Guacamole Salsa in the salsa bar is awesome and the other sauces are all great and quite spicy which I like.  Try it out and see what you think about their burrito and salsa bar.  In my opinion they are both very very good.
author: Harry E.

description: When I lived in San Mateo, this wasn't one of my favorite Taquerias. When I asked for nachos once there they gave me the real nacho cheese kinda stuff like you would get at a baseball game or something. I went yesterday though to this one and I was starving, I had just been at work for eight hours and felt my stomach start to yell at me. After the argument my bf and I had we found ourselves at la cumbre. I ordered Nachos again because  it was really what I wanted and I prayed it would be better this time. And let me tell you, it hit the spot. Oh man did it ever. The nachos came with REAL cheese and the plate was huge. Well I would expect it to be huge for $7.75. It was a success!
author: Tiffany D.

description: I don't know what it is, but I prefer the veggie burritos here to those at Pancho Villa, maybe it's the tortilla?!  I can't quite place why yet!  On the downside, I don't think they have an open salsa bar. 0_o
author: Michael C.

description: Born and raised in San Francisco, I am proud to say that La Cumbre has set the standard for my burrito taste buds! I always order a deluxe burrito with pollo asado (grilled chicken -it's the best!) Back in the 80's this was the spot, and in the 90's the kind of died out. This is my boyhood taqueria and I love it to death! When I have a craving for a burrito I come here, all the other taqueria's I just order a quesdilla because I'm faithful to this place. =)
author: Robert Q.

description: I love the meat at this taqueria, in particular the carne asada and the pollo asada.  They are grilled over a fire, and taste great!  My favorite is a regular carne asada burrito with black beans.  I could seriously eat one 5 times a week.  They aren't the best burrito I have every had (that would be at the El Farlito in the outer mission), but the are the best in the area.  Flavorful, no bullshit, yum!
author: C H.

description: This place isn't bad....the quesadillas are pretty good and so are the tacos. Not the best though...the chicken is good but it is a little bland. Overall, the food isn't that bad...just not great.
author: Gina R.

description: This place is bananas. My only complaint could be that it isnt as open as frequently as I would like. I could eat there at 10 am til 4 am everyday. The super burrito is the best. I also love that they give chips on the side.
author: Lola r.

description: After seeing this on TV I had the urge to go.  I checked Yelp and I saw it had some bad reviews.  Even though all of this I still went.  It was bad.  Don't even know why the TV show Man VS Food went there.  The food was bad and was overall bland!  Was not worth the money.  No wonder why there was no people in there.
author: Willy G.

description: My favorite mexican place in the city. The super burrito is so good! Parking in he mission sucks though and you always have to watch your bag, but well worth the burritos!
author: may s.

description: I heard a lot of hype about this place and wanted to try it out for myself.  My impression was that placed has been hyped to much. Its good not great. I had a carne asada burrito and the meat was really good. They gave me the option of having mild or spicy slasa.  Even though I usually have very little tolerance for heat. I went with the spicy. No kick. I was really disapointed din that.
author: John M.

description: I used to think I liked my Mexican food a bit less spicy than the average person, but then I had truly tasteless veggis tacos from La Cumbre that made me really wish I'd just gone to Pancho Villa. Their guacamole is not vegan (and doesn't look particularly appetizing to begin with) so that didn't help. Plus when I went they were "out of Margaritas" despite the multiple snazzy flavors listed up on the board. What the hell? It was early in the evening. Only redeeming quality: corn in the salsa bar.
author: Sharon T.

description:
these guys get bonus points for 1. being the original SF burrito joint and 2. being open past last call and 3. allowing me to eat here dressed as conan the barbarian

they know kids in the mission like to party and they set their hours accordingly.  the burrito was very good and tasted very fresh.  

no mystery meat here: at one end of the line you see a guy throwing chicken and carne asada onto an open-fire grill, then you see him cut the meat up and put it into a container from which the girls that wrap the burritos extract the delicious meats and insert them into delicious tacos/burritos/tortas.
author: Alex K.

description: I just ate here and was very disappointed in their carne asada burrito. The meat was flavorless and chewy. I could barely distinguish the meat from the other ingrediants in the burrito. La Taqueria on Mission St is better.
author: Lia R.

description: my brother took me to this place after the club because he said it was really good.. i got the carnitas burrito with BLACK beans and everything else i think. i was kind of drunk so i dont really remember but when i ate it,it was good .. but i wish it was a little spicier. other then that it was good at 2 in the morning. and i should of got steak because it looked hella good.(next time)
author: N.J. L.

description: A sizable burrito at a very reasonable price.  Looking at the chicken scared me into the 'vegetarian' section of the menu, though.  The guacamole had the consistency of whole milk with green coloring.  The rice was undercooked.  On the positive side, the salsa had fresh cilantro in it and was pleasantly quite spicy.  The horchata was tasty and not 'chalky'.  I'd try it again, but still, only for the vegetarian items.
author: ben y.

description: Best Mexican here by far. Deliciously fresh ingredients of high quality and well sized portions come with everything you order. Its a bit like a bar as well in that you can choose in the window what you do and don't want in your stuff. Plus they take card. This is my favorite Mexican in San Francisco by far, but dont take my word for it, try it yourself!
author: Aaron Q.

description: 4 stars for the food. and 5 Stars for the alfajores cookies.  Crumbly and covered with powdered sugar and caramel on the inside. The best anywhere...I've searched far and wide, nothing tops this taqueria for the alfajores cookie!
author: joan l.

description: Reviewing people please stop.  Most of you haven't the foggiest about what to order.  Here are your choices:  Deluxe burrito or deluxe taco;  chicken or steak;  black beans or refried beans; hot salsa or mild salsa.  Any combination of these choices and you can't go wrong.  Also, Man v Food is stupid, don't listen to their recommendations, stick to these!
author: Tim W.

description: i finally get there after i drove 39 miles the service was awful! i ordered i Al Pastor burrito . The lady had an attitude and rushed me even though it wasn't that busy. I finally got my burrito and bit into it and it tasted like  anything but al pastor  burrito. I asked the lady if  she it was  Al pastor and she gave a nasty look.I will never trust this Man v/sFood program again . I drove 39 miles each way just to check out this place and even you may have a bad experiense some time but here everything was bad.Service,food ,fresheness etc.I had paid $7.00 for a burrito in places like Pancho Villa but that was a 10000 % much better than this place.Here it was almost $10 dollars for a burrito.
author: J T.

description: You can always count on a good steak burrito at this place.  I have been coming here since i was little.
author: Shannon M.

description: "I'd Really Love to See You Tonight," the mellowly upbeat tune by '70s pop duo England Dan and John Ford Coley, was wafting through the sound system while I waited for the lady to make my burrito at La Cumbre.  I hadn't thought about that song in years, and I love it.  And the people working there were nice, and the terra cotta tiley atmosphere is comfy, but the food is pretty awful.  The veggies were flaccid, the meat was chewy and worse, flavorless.  I'd tried this place years ago and thought it was mediocre, and thought I'd give it one more try, since the lunchtime lines at Pancho Villa and Mariachi's were too long.  Duh!  Lines=good.  So, unlike the sub par  carne asada, the 70s lite rock playing at La Cumbre truly hit the spot.
author: bree z.

description: carne asada burrito all the way!  wash down with ice cold strawberry drink.  use red sauce at table....great with the burrito.  not a fan of the chicken, pork, or just veggie.
author: Dickson S.

description: Okay, the steak is delicious. Very soft and full of flavor. Not sure if they marinate the meat but it is very good. I never have them cut the meat in little pieces as it takes flavor out of the meat. I like fajita strips for my tacos, burritos, taco salad...etc..They cook the meat over a grill which makes a hugh difference to me in taste. This is my favorite burrito joint!
author: Pet R.

description: this place is dericious and fresh, nice friendly service and staff.  hola mamcitas!
author: Pickle R.

description: Not sure why this place isn't more highly rated so had to jump on here and do my yelping duty.  The food here is awesome. You can't beat these burrittos with a stick. The atmosphere is not the greatest, but don't pass it by just because it's a little rough around the edges.  I lived in the mission for 5 years in the 1990s and ate here often and just visited a month or so back and it was as good as ever.
author: Laura B.

description: Thanks for being open late. Come early to beat the line and use the restroom after frolicking in the Mission neighborhood. My burrito tasted like peanuts, (my friend concurred), and there were lots of seating available so you could at least try to enjoy your messy burrito or open-faced taco while resting your tired feet. Too much rice and dry beef in my burrito, and don't get the refried beans because I think that is what made it taste like peanuts. $7.75, whoa! that's a steep price. -Matt
author: Matthew C.

description: Anyone that says " Its too dry"    Well.... wa wa wa bitches you took  your food to-go (maybe Elixir like that one loser) and didn't participate in their SALSA BAR. Half the red salsas and a green have huge chunks of avocado, there is fresh cut lime, tartar sauce and corn. Yep...corn of there. I did a quadruple take. WTF. Corn. Yes.....corn. So if your burrito is too dry maybe you should lock your single track bike and stay awhile.
author: Joe G.

description: I love la cumbre. I've spent many drunken after-hours nights in here, having a veggie burrito in place of a night cap, so to speak. The perfect place to go on weekend nights after hitting some bars on 16th, since Arinell's will be closed (WHY?!?) but la cumbre will be open late! YES! They do a great job here, and once I ordered a fish taco, but asked for salmon instead of white fish, and they gave me this HUGE taco that was just overflowing with grilled salmon, for like four bucks. Sweet deal for sure. I also really like their aguas frescas. There is this one guy who usually cashiers there (he has two diamond earrings) and if you happen to be female, and you feel like being friendly, chances are you will get some kind of fat discount or an item on the house. He's actually a very nice guy. Just a tip.
author: Shannon R.

description: well, this place used to be good, but now i consider this overpriced and the food is mediocre at best   I ordered the steak burrito and the steak was gristle and gross!   Chips were stale and all of this for almost $9.00  I used to go here years ago and it used to be good.   I felt like throwing up when I left.
author: bruce r.

description:
i have come here several times, giving it chance after chance because my best friend loves it. but it just keeps getting worse.  the last two times were expecially bad.  

the second to last time, i went in and asked for a tostada salad and asked if i could have it on a plain tortilla instead of the fried shell. this is a pretty standard request and i've never had a problem before, but the woman was like: "so, a burrito". 
and i said "no no - i'd like the salad,  just not the fried shell."
"well then you want a burrito". 
"no, i dont. i want the salad. i just dont want the shell."
"..."
"can't i just have the salad?"  
"no."  
"why not?"  
"no".  
"jesus. fine, i'll take a burrito."  
"fine".

The last time (i was clearly drunk, considering how awful it had been before) was a post bar late night escapade. we got a quesadilla suiza and super nachos to share. We actually had to stop eating them both they were so gross." a friend came in and we offered her some and she looked at it and just went "ew. no that looks disgusting."
it takes a lot to make a bunch of drunkards refuse greasy food.

never again.
author: Lily S.

description:
things that were wrong with my veggie deluxe burrito:

1. slices of cheese, steam-melted onto the tortilla. gooey.
2. steamed tortilla=moist and sticky, rendering my burrito into a big tubular wonton with rice in it.
3. guacamole looked like green elmer's glue. more gooeyness.
4. salty, salty rice.

sad. no guilt here when i couldn't finish it. maybe the meat ones are better?

note to thadd: we may not have burritos, but we have whiskey.
author: Adrienne Y.

description: I am proud to report that my hometown of San Mateo California 's La Cumbre, which yes is owned by the same people as the one on Valencia rules . I was really pride filled. But with that said i want to say, this place blew. Slow service. crappy comida. Ill stick to the one in SM
author: Lauren V.

description: I was underwhelmed by Taqueria La Cumbre. First of all, I was immediately insulted because they didn't give me chips with my burrito.  I mean, did they just not ask me if I want them or are they extra?!  Either way, that stinks.  Also, they my burrito was not that great.  The guacemole was a little too thin for my taste and there was not enough cheese.  In this neighborhood, they have to do better.
author: Joanna S.

description: Microwave food. The purpose of me eating out is that I don't get nuked food. Sure they have all these accolades hanging there (from 10 years ago) but the place was ...man I can't even say it. UGH! Did not feel like I was getting any kind of value. First and last time. Hasta la vista baby.
author: Gwen D.

description: This has to be one of my favorite types of food to eat and they do it right at a good price. The carne asada is of the more decent I have had, and I always look forward to coming here after a night at the dive bars. The nachos are cheap and plentiful and serve just as much as their burrito. Though most weeknights they close earlier than poncho villa, I am always sad when I see their light off when my stomach is empty walking by.
author: Bowser J.

description: I have been a fan of La Cumbre since forever, and this place has never let me down. An incredibly varied menu of meats and seafood with probably the largest menu selections I have ever seen at a taqueria as well as a salsa bar that is vastly superior to most similar types of restaurants, and  the nicest people running the place, not too crowded and not on 16th St. Need I say more?
author: Sharon J.

description: I used to love coming here years ago when it tasted better...guess you know where this is going? The last two times I've been here the carnitas was BEYOND salty (more so than typical) and the carne asada was just bland...somehow I still come here because it's almost 2nd nature...burrito = La Cumbre...i'm on auto pilot BUT I think i'll try some of the burrito joints on here...or if you really know of an awesome burrito joint let me know....
author: Karen B.

description: After watching Man Vs Food  and reading the reviews here I  decided to give it a try.. NOT a good idea.. Meat was tough and the place was dirty.. Gross!
author: M M.

description: I love this place!  I still come from across town just for the supreme nachos.  Whether you are looking for a well priced lunch/dinner or some late night bites, this is the taqueria to go to.  Everything is fast and fresh & tailored right to your tastes.  Skip the lines at Pancho Villa & go around the corner for better food & service here!
author: Jessica H.

description: The competition among taquerias in the Mission is fierce and La Cumbre does nothing but surpass expectations and deliver!  All I can say about this place is "sabroso!" (which means "flavorful!" for all you non-Spanish speakers)!
author: I B.

description: Not bad...not impressed with their guacamole (it's the runny kind that reminds me of the stuff in a bottle) and they really don't have anything corn (aka corn chips, corn tostadas, etc) but they do have very small corn tortillas which worked out for me. I payed $8 for a chicken tostada which I believe was a little high for what I got. No chips or anything either. This isn't my first stop on the list, but it did the job tonight.
author: Stephanie J.

description: I'm surprised this place isn't as packed at Pancho Villa around the corner.  Maybe because they don't know how awesome this place is and they may think this place is like any other Taqueria in the area.  The Steak Taco Salad ($8.00) is yummy.  They have a location in San Mateo (used to work nearby) and didn't know about the San Francisco location until recently.  If you're on a budget, the taco salad is so huge that it can feed two.  Their burritos are good too.  Try it!
author: Erika C.

description: Basically I am giving the carnitas tacos five stars because it is all I ever order here. I have tried their burritos, and have no lasting memory of them, but the carnitas tacos make me very happy. Oh, and also the verde salsa at the salsa bar! FIVE stars! I only wish they'd give you bigger containers that were not disposable because I end up using at least six, and feel guilty. The verde salsa is especially good on days when they make it extra spicy.
author: Lindsey H.

description: I was having drinks with a friend at a bar nearby and I had heard a lot of good things about this place so I decided to try it out. Let's just say I was HIGHLY disappointed. I ordered a super burrito with prawns and it was $13 which is over priced. My friend got 2 prawn tacos (regular) and it was $10. I was annoyed by the price but if the food was great then I'm willing to pay. There was no one else in front of me and we waited 10 minutes for our food. I expected the shrimp to be nice a cooked (judging by how long we waited) and the ingredients to be fresh. But, the burrito and tacos were absolutely awful. There was 1 prawn per taco and the food was ridiculously bland. Absolutely no flavor and the prawns were soggy! I went to get some salsa to try and liven it up and I was told I could not get more than 3 salsas. Are you kidding?? Neither one of us could finish our food, it was that bad. I will never go here again. Pancho Villa forever!!
author: Allison F.

description: Before their long hiatus in 2005, this was the best burrito place for two square blocks.  Since they reopened, they've lost a step.  The chicken doesn't have the kick it used to, the guacamole is thin and tasteless, and the carne asada is a little gristly.  It would be sad if Pancho Villa weren't right around the corner.  Move on.
author: Christian C.

description: When I was a wee teen, I used to wonder what the floating square things in red sauce were.  Then I learned about the evils of red meat at University and tried them for myself.  This is one of the first taquerias in the Mission that actually offered tofu as a burrito filling, so it earns high marks in my books for not ignoring the vegetarian folks.  My tummy always feels happy when I've finished a burrito from here, so I always keep coming back.
author: brenda b.

description: First time I went here. The regular burrito (with only rice, beans, and meat) was definitely big! Huge chunks of meat all the way to the last bite is what made the burrito so good. I had to save half, which tasted just as good the next day.  I ended up paying $16 for super nachos and a regular burrito, so not that cheap. The long line moved extremely fast. The puke in front wasn't very appealing, but hey what can you do about novice drinkers!  A satisfying late night place. La Cumbre is definitely not "the summit" of taquerias.
author: Sumant C.

description:
Got a carne asada burrito here, it filled me up and it tasted pretty good. normal price for a burrito pretty much. nothing special but its a taqueria and it will do the job when you are hungry.

 one time i came here late nite and bought a premade burrito with some weird azz shiet in it for like 3 bucks out the door. fools were done making burritos but they had some stashed away. it was pretty good and they came thru when i needed them the most. I wouldve had to hit up j-bo instead but i got a burrito.
author: Wats C.

description:
Average.

Everything was average. Mind you it is not bad, just not good either. Meet was average in terms of how moist it was [pollo asada] and the tortilla felt a little too stiff. There was too much rice in the burrito, which I never thought would happen in SF. 

I dunno. I have been a to a lot of good places. At least I know those places still exist.
author: Rahul T.

description: This place isn't bad, but it's not in my top list of Misison Taquerias. The burritos are rolled tight, which I like. I definitely will have to try a sauce next time, because my burrito was pretty dry, meat included.
author: m t.

description:
I have made it my solitary goal in life to keep people from eating here.  

So picture it:  Late Saturday evening, drinking with my buddy Kyle (who does not believe San Francisco extends more than 2 miles past the Mission, whatever) and after many many beers, we gotta pee..bad.  Few places were open so late and we had already left the bar.  We pop into La Cumbre for the first time in both of our combined residence in the City.  I order the super nachos for us to split and then high-tail it to the potty.  When I come out I find complete shenanigans on a plate!  It suddenly dawns on me why this place is so empty when the streets are full of hungry drunk kids.  The nachos came complete with canned "nacho" cheese and the super neon "guacamole sauce."  I was horrified.  What self-respecting taqueria uses fake cheese???  I couldn't eat it.  Kyle took it back and asked them if they could make it over with real cheese.  They did, but that crazy green sauce was still on it.  Yeach.  We couldn't finish it between the two of us and that is saying a lot.

And oh, the gas that ensued.

I will be fair and give them a bonus star for having a clean restroom and remaking the otherwise inedible nachos for me.

But don't go.  Save yourself and anyone who may encounter your gassy personage in the days to come.
author: Carmen R.

description: We saw this place on Man Vs. Wild with all the hype.  My wife said she used to come here for burritos many years ago and like it.  I was expecting a some good burritos but was disappointed.  The service was terrible.  The woman behind the counter could not communicate.  We went in circles trying to order four of the same burritos.  She got irritated when we couldn't understand what she was saying.  The steak in the burritos were chewy and cut too large.  When I took a bite, the whole chunk of meat came out and it was hard to chew through it.   It was $8 for a super burrito which was about the size of a regular burrito in other places.  I gave it a try but I won't be coming back anymore.
author: Jim T.

description: Pretty good. Pancho Villa is better but this is passable. Was open late one night after bar hopping on Valencia. Good and fresh food. I like Pancho Villa on 16th better OR Taqueria El Buen Sabor on Valencia and 18th for shrimp tacos. Very pretty mural inside.
author: julie q.

description: I LOVE THEIR SALSA bar.  fresh salsa. seriously.  you can't find that anywhere with a decent burrito price.  poncho villa has better burritos but no salsa or corn.  their vege burrito is a bit greasy, but in general i have left happy and full here.  atmosphere medicore.. service good smiling friendly staff persons.  food -eh,  salsa bar - yay!
author: Ann M.

description: The only reason I give La Cunbre 2 stars instead of one is because I have only eaten there once so I am trying to leave room for it just having been a bad day at the taqueria.  Otherwise, my super carnitas burrito was terrible 5 minutes after I ordered it and it was even worse when i tried reheating it for lunch the next day.  I think I'll try Pancho Villa, even if it is too bright and too clean to be considered a true taqueria by some.
author: Talia L.

description: Fights for being the best with El Mariachi and Pancho Villa. Really depends what you're in the mood for. Pancho's got the most spiciest, Maricachi's got the most fruity and flavorful and Cumbre's got the most filling.
author: Andrew L.

description: So many mixed reviews! I had a carnitas burrito and it was fine. I don't think anybody would disagree with me however that the salsa bar is sooooooooooo MOTED!!!! The guacamole also tends to blow a few goat holes. But I've had worse burritos(AAHEMM!under breath:Los CoyotesCOUGH!) I'm talking mad shit and there are better options but sometimes I don't have time to wait in line at Pancho Villa or walk to La Corneta.
author: Boxxxman J.

description: i went based on man vs food show .. umm the show did not match the place.. i know i was at the right place.. they messed up on my order, lady seemed like she had an attitude! and they over charged me by $30!!  its a thumbs down. Not worth what i ended up paying
author: Yolanda C.

description: All I order here is the all meat carne asada burrito with avocado, jalapeno peppers, and salsa.  The meat has a great beefy flavor.  As I eat, I drizzle it with lime and munch on chips, radishes, and more jalapenos and hot carrots.  This is a great meal for carnivores.
author: John T.

description: Last night, I ordered a strawberry agua fresca (pitstop for hungry friend en route to Blondie's).  White board said $1.65, was charged $2.70.  When I asked what this charge was, cashier said, "It's after 10 o'clock" and pointed to some ridiculous picture of a cat wrapped in mardi gras beads w/ a text bubble saying, "Unfortunately, due to circumstances beyond our control, we must raise our prices."  Agua fresca sucked too, no fruit chunks.  Never coming back.
author: Ellen L.

description: I had the chicken fajita burrito, standard version [without guacamole, cheese and soured cream] and I have to say that I enjoyed every moment of it. The chicken was tasty, there were plenty of vegetable extras, and the salsa bar is great too. On the minus side, I tried some of a friend's guacamole and it was rather reminiscent of mayonnaise, and the tomatillo salsa isn't as tasty as some I've had. Nonetheless, a very pleasing Mexican experience!
author: Amelia I.

description:
Best late night burrito joint around 16th.  The freshly cooked carne asada is ridiculously good.  If you're stumbling out of the bar around 1 or 2am, this is the best spot to hit.

Edit:  I no longer use the above qualifier to justify the rating.  La Cumbre is just good, regardless of what hour you're there.  I've been to probably 80% of the taquerias in the Mission (I've lived in SF for over 23 years), and think that La Cumbre has the best value.  The people that work there are super courteous.

Overall this place is clean, given it's an old school building/taqueria.  The salsa bar is decent, but not quite as good as pancho villas around the corner.  They take CC, which is nice for those of you that don't carry cash in the Mission.
author: Darcy M.

description: Used to be my favorite, not anymore,something has happened over the years. Maybe things aren't as fresh as they once were.. they surely aren't as busy these days. When I want quick fast mex. it's Poncho Villa or Taqueria Cancun.....
author: don l.

description: This place used to be good. I don't know what happened, but it's gone waaaaay down hill.
author: Matt W.

description: I've going there since the mid 80's. I love this place. Get the steak tacos or if you are really hungry a burrito. And my parking karma somehow always finds me a parking place right in front.
author: Chris R.

description: Terrible!  I made it out to SF on Saturday to eat at La Taqueria on 25th and Mission.  Unfortunately it was closed.  So i remembered a Man vs. food episode at Taqueria La Cumbre.  I thought "I have to try it".  I have the perfect excuse.  WOWWWWWW, what a travesty.  I walked in and it was like any other taqueria.  The line was long and I thought they would probably rush right through like La Taqueria.  Not the case.  After about the first ten minutes I started thinking this burrito will probably be pretty damn good with all of  these people waiting.  After fifteen minutes I began thinking, this burrito BETTER be damn good.  The burrito was at best warm, truly unflavourful (thank god for their ok salsa bar) and worst of all it was so dry that I could barely swallow the few bites that I did eat.  The challenge on man vs. food must have been just to eat this brick of a burrito.  Just as tasty as a ceramic brick.  Don't waste your time or calorie intake on this place.
author: mich m.

description:
Total disappointment! Never returning.

Poor service, poor food - rates a big fat ZERO

they didnt bother to take the time to hear our orders and I kept repeating the spinach tortilla...when she finally looked up she was so angry she threw the regular tortilla down on the counter, huffing and puffing.
We asked for everything in both, and she neglected to add the salsa to mine. I had to use the restroom, thus missed noting it hadnt been added.
They were bland, tasteless, boring. 
The lettuce was awful, no flavor - this is California, the land of year round produce, organics are even better!
Crappy meat - no flavor either, it was the grilled chicken. 
Restroom facilities - slimy floor, smelled of PineSol so strongly. You could slide on the floor, soft shoe shuffle anyone?
When we were @ the register, she kept repeating - for here or to go, we looked @ her and said 'to go', multiple times, and you know what, she gave it to us in a basket w/ chips. When she figured out that wasnt what we said, she blew up - temper temper!!!

We went based on Man vs Food episode, but hey Adam, check your work before you go, dont presume your foodie scouts know what they're talking about. We cant believe he actually liked this place. 
Will stick to a few of our favorites in the Mission. Thankfully there are plenty of well deserving taquerias that I will give my hard working money to, and enjoy the ambiance, staff, food and music.
author: Theresa L.

description: LA CUMBRE is one of my three burrito go to places, depending on area i'm in and style of chicken i feel like.   my must have for a burrito is the avocado vs guacamole option.  all three of my picks have that.  there was a time a few years ago when I was in need of a new burrito place so I asked around and this was the best one i tried.  i was hipped to this place by El Vez and he was right, they rock!
author: misskim f.

description: I think they put a lot of emphasis on the carne asada- it's fresh off the grill, but they seemed rather tough to put inside a burrito.  It tastes good by itself, but it just doesn't blend in with the rest of the goo.  Complimentary chips and the extensive salsa bar is definitely a plus.  They have a lot of menu for a taqueria, which will definitely be a reason to go back more than once.
author: Passdatanqueray M.

description: I GIVE THIS PLACE 5 STARS FOR BEING OPEN TO SELL ME A DAMN GOOD BURRITO AT 1:30 IN THE FUCKING MORNING... god bless the burrito. It's a little pricey but you try and find me another place that will sell me a burrito at that time at night
author: Rich V.

description: I've been coming to La Cumbre for years and unfortunately the quality of their burritos has declined steadily.  Their carne asada burritos used to be tasty and with lots of filling.  Now they are on the smallest side compared to other taquerias.  The meat's a bit dry and the chips not as fresh.  Still a decent place for burritos but there are certainly better places in the Mission.
author: Kenneth L.

description: I don't get the positive ratings for this place.  The ingredients are old.  The place has no vibe.  Anywhere else for burritos practically but this one.  Yech.
author: Chris A.

description: i wouldn't say the best burrito ive ever had, but pretty close. the steak is just good, but the chicken is out of this world.
author: Tyler F.

description: super duper fantastic nachos. cheese sauce, not shredded 'solidifies into a clump' cheese. good chips, great stuff-to-chips ratio, etc etc. this comes from the ultimate nacho snob. btw, i had it with carne asada. afterwards, walk 2 blocks to bi-rite and have the salted caramel ice cream, and it will be the best afternoon ever.
author: soomp a.

description: I just recently heard of this taqueria thru my kids,who love watching man vs. food,after watching the show i was suspicious because Adam the host was raving about the burrito like he just discover the cure for cancer.Well i took my family last night for dinner,wow what a dissappointment,1)The carne asada was rubbery,hard to chew,the rice,beans.tortilla salsa very bland 2)The Horchata tasted like water no cinnamon,vanilla,sugar in it. 3) The service was awful the girl who made the burrito's mislabeled them so we started eating the wrong ones.4) I saw no latinos eating in there that alone should have told me to stay away.If you want real good Mexican food there are far better places like El Toro,Panchovilla,La Corneta,El Farolito.
author: AL R.

description: Veggie and super veggie tacos were fresh but not very tasty. Salsa was decent. Cool decor, love the tile and skylight. Wouldn't go back, there are much tastier taquerias in the Mission (and really, if you can't get great tacos there, then where?)
author: Bob S.

description: La Cumbre wasn't what my sister in law and I expected it to be. We went here in search of a SUPER large burrito and in return got a regular sized burrito for a super burrito's price. They're supposed to be America's Greatest burrito ? I think not. The burrito in itself was good but it was just the size that was disappointing. If you're looking for a burrito, I suggest you either go to the nearest burrito truck or a different Taqueria. You will be much more satisfied. :)
author: Mika S.

description: read about this place in maxim magazine. im always in frisco so why not? its ok in san jose we have a place called PINK ELEPHANT their carne is way better. this place the food is cooked fresh in front of you but its too soft and chewy. i like my carne kind of done, not too chewy but kind of crunchy with bacon thats what i like.  its ok
author: Tony T.

description: Took a chicken super burrito to go and wait to enjoy a few hours later. The chicken was deliciously smokey in flavor. Asked for menudo but didn't any at the time. Maybe they only do that for the weekends?? I'm a girl that's addicted to AC when it's over 80 degrees out so being in there was a bit warm for me since they only had fans going. Wouldn't mind going back for to-go if i were back in town.
author: Miss E.

description: La Cumbre is everything a burrito could be. Meaty, beany, ricy, and nicy. Heavy as a brick in the hand. And the salsa!  Oh, the salsa.  As fresh as a spring day and twice as fun.  This is one of the five original burritos designed by god herself.  Definitely one of the best burritos in the city.
author: James C.

description: It was a big burrito, fine, but it was kind of bland.  I've certainly had better.  The guacamole was boring and the chicken was really nothing special.  I thought I couldn't go wrong with a burrito in the Mission, but I left wishing I'd eaten somewhere else.  The dingy feel of the restaurant certainly didn't help.
author: Julie H.

description: My favorite burrito place of all time.  Highly recommend the grilled steak.
author: mo y.

description:
Satan gave me a taco and it made me really sick
The chicken was all raw and the grease was mighty thick
The rice was all rancid and the beans were so hard
I was gettin' kinda dizzy eatin' all the lard
There was aphids on the lettuce an' I ate every one
An' after I was done the salsa melted off my tongue
Pieces of tortilla got stuck in my throat
An' the stains on my clothes burned a hole through my coat
My stomach was a-tremblin' and I broke out in a rash
I was so dry and thirsty and I didn't have no cash
So I went and found a hose, tore off all my clothes
Turned on the water and it shot right up my nose
Some old lady came along and she thought I was a freak
So she beat me with a handbag till I could hardly speak
I was lying there naked, my body badly bruised
In a pool of my own blood, unconscious and confused
Well, the cops came and got me and threw me in their van
And I woke up on the ceiling and I couldn't find my hand
They took me to the judge, his eyes a-glowin' red
The courtroom was filled with witches and the dead
Well, the sheriff was a hellhound with fangs and claws
The prisoners were tied up and chained to the walls
The air was gettin' thick; the smoke was gettin' thicker
The judge read the verdict: said, "Cut off his head!"
Well, they placed me on the altar, and they raised up the axe
My head was about to explode when I noticed the Marshall stacks
I noticed all the smoke machines, cameras and the lights
Some guy with a microphone, runnin' around dancin' in tights
And I noticed the crew and the band playin' down below
And I realized I was in a rock video

(Beck, Satan gave me a taco)
author: sam s.

description:
i was having performance anxiety last night because i was completely exhausted and trying to think of a fun yet cheap place to take a small tribe of native americans; some place that wasn't too far from their hotel.  
la rondella was having an event, and all other taquerias/restaurants in the mission were packed and/or closing.
thank god for la cumbre.
their food may not be THE BEST (fucking snobs) but they have SUPER spicy salsa with thick freakin chunks of habanero in it and that pretty much settles it for me.  plus they are open really late... although for some reason they closed kinda early last night and people kept coming up to the closed gate and looking lost and oozing with disapointment.
anyway the best thing about la cumbre is that it turned out to be a great place to take my indians.  
their portions are gigantic right? - i usually eat half my burrito then go give the rest to one of the bums invariably found outside.  indian dude though had another way.  he packed up the rest of his.  when my friend devin grinned, nodded knowingly to him and said "to eat later huh?"  homeboy answered back.
"no... it's for my soul."

yes. what? yes.

taqueria la cumbre - feeds the body & leaves some for the soul.
author: marin m.

description: This used to be my favorite burrito place. I was a regular. Recently, they changed process in which you order. In the past, you were able to watch them make your burrito and request how you wanted it as they were making it. Now, they make you order at the register, pay, then sit and wait for your food. They got both of our orders wrong the past two times (I decided to give them one more chance) I went. Everyone who goes in who doesn't know about their ordering process change wander around until they figure it out themselves. Meanwhile, the employees just stare at you like idiots when you go to the old area to make your order and don't mention things have changed. They have always been rude and even tried to short change me once, but the consistent messing up of my order has sent me searching for a new burrito place.
author: Emily W.

description: I to come to check this place out after it was it in Man vs. Food and I should have known better. Trying different kinds of Taqueria on mission and around San Fran but i had to check it out for my self. After waiting in line for 45 min. in the heat and putting another hr in the meter so i can not get a parking ticket I told my self that I should go around the corner and get burrito from Pancho Villa I said NO if it was on TV I should just order what he did. Wrong I was so disappointed the meat was chewy, watery, and the seating arrangement is uncomfortable because the line to order zig zag around the seating area and makes it uncomfortable to enjoy your meal as others are standing over your shoulder and looking at what you eat. This place is not for me but you can check if for your self . GOOD LUCK!
author: michelle D.

description: After watching Man VS Food I decided to check this place out. I like that the food is prepared right before your eyes. I had the carne asada burrito delux.I hate to say it but, I have had better burritos out of a lunch truck in East Oakland.
author: Mr. Ehmz M.

description: Three stars which would be four if this place was in the burbs of the East Bay....but as it is, there's some serious competition in SF and this place hasn't quite kept up...a largish barn of a place with Nortena music blaring, it has a nice divey feel, which the whole Mission area has. The prices keep getting raised so much that they just put stickies with new prices over the old ones on the wall menu.....Mexican burrito places are all about the flavor, and this place, though decent, isnt it any more. The burritos have no zing, and you need to drown them in hot salsa to bring out the taste. Even the pico de gallo was bland, and that takes some doing. Now it is possible that with creeping age my taste buds are losing their efficacy, but everyone in the group, including young whippersnappers, agreed....this place needs a flavor upgrade. Ok to go to if youre in the area, but no longer worth a special trip.
author: Tom B.

description: I used to come here as little kid with my mom, and I remembered it being totally delicious.  More recently, I've come a couple of times with mixed results.  I think it all depends on what kind of a burrito person you are.  For example, since I was a vegetarian for many years, I'm a fan of the tomato and lettuce in the veggie burritos, but since becoming a meat eater, I don't like them in meat burritos.  Basically, it's a good standard burrito place, but nothing special.
author: Moira W.

description: Just tried this place a couple days ago after reading and hearing so many good things (most notably the praise in the Chronicle).   I tried to keep it simple (carne asada burrito), but still was exttremely disappointed.  Why go here when there are so many other great taquerias in San Francisco (Cancun, Farrolito, La Taqueria)?
author: Jose W.

description:
i am giving this place a 2 star rating since i have only eaten there once- but i do not expect to go back. i will give them the benefit of the doubt that they have some decent items on their menu AND i know they have some street cred history that i will respect.

i should have known that something was wrong since i have pretty much made a point to eat my way around tons of taquerias in the mission and had never ventured into cumbre nor have i had a friend, colleague or passerby utter any words of  "mmmm la cumbre" but my life is one of risks and new experiences so i took the gamble recently.

anyway this is how it goes- when the boy placed our order for super nachos they asked him what type of cheese he wanted. he must have been hungry because rather than being alarmed, he asked, "what types do you have?" the staff member then said, "well, 1- american." now any mission taqueria that serves liquid velveeta cheese does not deserve to called a taqueria-la cumbre please update your name to taco bell! and the boy- well he needs to know better to stop the madness before it happens but since i was already happily drinking my pacifico at the table he must of thought that we were stuck. living dangerously i say.....
along with the horror of the cheese was soppy, creamy slop in a greenish tone that was suppose to be guacamole and some tough stringy microwaved tidbits of carne asada. the sheer wrongness of some many things!! we barely ate, slammed down our beers and quickly got out of dodge.
author: CTP p.

description: I'd heard that La Cumbre could roll with the best of the burrito spots in the Mission so naturally I had to give it a try. The sense of deja vu as I walked through the door tells me I may have even eaten here a time or two before  (what can I say? so I like to get black out drunk from time to time..!?). I went with a carne asada super burrito. What immediately caught my eye is that they're always grillin' fresh meat, and they don't chop your meat until they're ready to put it in your burrito. This is probably the secret to why their carne asada is freakin juicy and wonderful! Now this place does defy the law of burrito spots in that their chips suck, AND you have to pay extra for them. Usually a bad chip is the sign of a bad burrito joint and their chips are so bad I feel like I should almost take another star off, but their burritos are good enough I'm gonna leave that fourth star juuuuust where it is.
author: Jeff S.

description: Cheap and good, just like every burrito place in the Mission.  The Chile Relleno was huge and delicious.
author: Saikat C.

description: my favorite taqueria. i started speaking spanish to them and they all acted like i was jesucristo back again! very sweet staff, best al pastor outside mexico that i've had, and they are great liars (quote: you're spanish is so good! har har!)
author: Lisa M.

description: Quesadillas and tacos are ok but not amazing. To me, still pretty far from el farolito
author: laurent i.

description: the best burritos, man, but i'm not sure why they liquify their guacomole.  the mural/painting on the far wall inside will help you remember this place even if you've been drugged and buried in a shallow grave somewhere in Mexico and have to walk your way home or at least to the American embassy.
author: Jonny L.

description: being a san diego native im kind of like a taco shop connoisseur, i was a little skeptical. we were ravenous and kind of buzzed, i was so excited, this place was like chipotle, but legit. i didn't really know what i wanted but having everything in front of me definitely made it easy to fill up that tortilla. my burrito was like a small child, and oh soo tasty(good thing i split it.) we also got this shrimp cocktail situation that was like ceviche, but it was hot? it was delicious none the less. oh and they had beer, yay! i loved the decor of the place, its very exciting. i even stood on a one of the tables and took a picture with the giant guitar  on the wall!!
author: phoebe r.

description: I went there after a night of drinking, perfect, I was quite the drunk and it probably made the burrito taste fantastic. The staff was pretty nice considering how rowdy we were, and yet it wasn't total chaos either
author: xo x.

description: Great burritos, been going here for at least 15 years and its still going strong. Especially like the carne asada burrittos.
author: John S.

description: Fresh, Fresh, Fresh. Yes , the burrito I ordered tasted like if the ingredients were just picked. Line was a bit long but what can you expect when the food tastes this good. Only complaint is I wish there was one closer to where I live.
author: Ben M.

description: i dont like eating inside the place, but i love their food. they have grilled chicken which has great flavor. i like the super nachos too. this is not gourmet food, but really good for a fast meal.
author: City G.

description: Taqueria La Cumbre San Mateo - 4 stars. This location - dry, tasteless grilled chicken burrito, stale chips, and hot salsa that was full of sad looking tomatoes and was more than half jalapenos.
author: Mark S.

description: the barbcue chicken burrito is the best in the city. the steak is good too. this was the first place i found in the city as a teenager to eat. the prices are relative to the economy and the atmosphere is cool. the only drawback is finding parking in the mission but they do have a parking lot on 16th st.
author: steve s.

description: I had to give La Cumbre 5 stars because I eat so many of their burritos and I think they are the best (I guess. its hard to decide something like that; different burritos are good for different reasons.) But for value, and actual cuts of lovely skirt steak used for their carne asada, they are truly remarkable. The cheese they use is also especially tasty. Their beans are really great too. The spicy pico-de-gallo also. The guacomole they use is really the iffy part of the equation, but I just love La Cumbre.
author: Ben B.

description: La Cumbre serves the best carne asada in town, period.  I've been going here for more than 25 years. I had moved to L.A. for 12 years, and during that whole time couldn't find a place there to compare to La Cumbre. It's the meat. It's high quality, seasoned just right, and cooked pretty much right before they make your burrito. That's right, it's not supposed to sit in that warmer for hours at a time. Although the prices have gone up, it's still worth it. I recently went to La Taqueria, which is good also, but their prices are way up there now too. Plus, La Taqueria always had this fly problem. It looks like they finally got some no-pest strips or something.  For the folks who think El Farolito is the bomb (quite possibly the worst Mexican food you could find)-----please. You've got to try La Cumbre. This is what carne asada is supposed to be. They put something in their fresh chopped salsa (the hot version) that gives it a really unique taste. A certain pepper, I don't know, but it's great!!
author: Michael F.

description: New years day. Pancho VIlla and El Torro are closed but La Cumbre is open. I haven't been in this place for about 10 years so I figure I will give it a try. Walking down 16th eating my burrito the first thing I noticed was that the meat was tough as nails and that the burrito was luke warm. I ate about half of it and threw it in the trash. One of my teeth started to hurt because there was a big chunk of gristle stuck there. About 5 minutes later my stomach started to hurt and eventually I had trouble walking my stomach ache was so bad. I went in to Walgreen's and bought some floss and some Pepto Bismo. Back out on the side walk I took a double dose of Pepto Bismol but it didn't help and I accidently spilled half the bottle all over the sidewalk and on my pants and shoes. Pink liquid everywhere. I stumbled into the McDonalds, went into the bathroom and tried to puke but only watery pink liquid came out. I ordered a Sprite and sat in the McDonalds until I started to feel a little better but once I got up and started moving around my stomach pain came back. I could barely walk so instead of taking the bus back to Bernal I hailed a cab. I am at home now. My stomach feels a little better but not much. I am still having trouble trying to puke up the burrito so I have decided to try and pass it through my system. I still have a piece of gristle stuck between my teeth that I can't get out with the floss. I will take some Ibuprofen and hope the stomach pain and tooth ache go away.
author: Robb M.
